HEADLINE: Going Beyond Black and White, Hispanics in Census Pick 'Other' 

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Patria Rodriguez, an advertising sales director for a women's magazine in New York, takes after her father. With light brown skin and thick, curly hair, she says she resembles the actress Rosie Perez, but some people have asked her if she is Italian, and others have told her she looks like the singer Sade.
 Like many Hispanic Americans, Ms. Rodriguez does not think of herself as black or white. "I acknowledge I have both black and white ancestry in me, but I choose to label myself in nonracial terms: Latina. Hispanic. Puerto Rican. Nuyorican," Ms. Rodriguez, 31, said. "I feel that being Latina implies mixed racial heritage, and I wish more people knew that. Why should I have to choose?" 
 As the Hispanic population booms, the fluid ways that she and other Latinos view their racial identities are drawing more attention and fueling the national debate over racial classifications -- what they mean, what they should be and whether they are needed at all. 
Now members of the United States' largest minority group, the nation's 38.8 million Hispanics, nearly half of them immigrants, harbor notions of race that are as varied as their Spanish and that often clash with the more bipolar views of many other Americans. 
White? Black? Try "moreno," "trigueno" or "indio," terms that indicate skin shades and ancestry and accommodate several hues.
This heterogeneity has stumped the Census Bureau. In its 2000 count, almost half the Hispanic respondents refused to identify themselves by any of the five standard racial categories on the census forms: white, black, Asian, American Indian or Alaska native and a category that includes natives of Hawaii and the Pacific Islands. The agency has since been surveying Hispanics to find a way to pinpoint them racially.
In the census, respondents can mark their ethnicity as Hispanic, but then they are asked to choose a racial label. In 2000, almost half of the Hispanic respondents, 48 percent, identified themselves as white. Only 2 percent chose black.
But from the light-complexioned to the dark, more than 14 million, or more than 42 percent of all Latino respondents, marked the box labeled "some other race" and wrote in such disparate identities as Mayan, Tejano and mestizo. (An additional 6 percent said they were members of two or more races.)
The category "some other race" was used almost exclusively by Hispanics; of all those who chose it, 97 percent were Latino. Claudette Bennett, chief of the Census Bureau's racial-statistics branch, said follow-up research showed that a large portion of these respondents wanted Hispanic to be considered their race.
A recent study by the Lewis Mumford Center for Comparative Urban and Regional Research at the State University of New York at Albany noted that the popularity of the "some other race" category came at the expense of the "white" category, which was the choice of the majority of Latino respondents in 1980.
"There may have been a sense that being white was part of the process of being assimilated," said John R. Logan, Mumford's director. "There's a trend toward rejecting whiteness as a way of expressing success."
"That's the big change over time. There's a Latino identity that's neither white nor black, and it's a positive identity."
While there are clearly white Hispanics and black Hispanics, many more come from racially mixed stock, with white, black and American Indian or other indigenous strains. Even within one family, one sibling may look black by many Americans' standards, another white, and another in between. And factors as disparate as hair texture, education, income and even nationality matter almost as much as skin color in racial self-image. 
Israel Coats, 24, a Dominican who moved to New York when he was 11 and is now studying marketing at Baruch College, is black in physical features and in the way he identifies himself. But in the Dominican Republic, he says, he is called "indio," Indian. That is because even the darkest-skinned Dominican often regards "black" as a synonym for Haitian; the two nations, which share the island of Hispaniola, have a long history of conflict.
Physical appearance is not even a factor in how some Latinos sort themselves into racial categories.
Mario Goderich, 36, a police officer in Miami Beach, Fla., who has light brown hair, green eyes and the white skin of his Puerto Rican mother, identifies himself on the census forms as Hispanic and white. His father, Rene Goderich, 62, also identifies himself as white, even though he describes himself as "jabao," the Cuban term for a light-skinned mulatto.
"Over here there's no 'jabao' or 'mulatto,' so I say white," said the elder Mr. Goderich, who is from Santiago, Cuba, and lives in New Jersey. "We're all mixed."
Ms. Rodriguez, the advertising sales director, said one reason she is uncomfortable picking one race is because the words white and black carry political baggage that she does not feel she shares. "White means mostly privilege and black means overcoming obstacles, a history of civil rights," she said. "As a Latina, I can't try to claim one of these."
Among people of Mexican descent, who make up more than 65 percent of Hispanics in the United States, the racial background includes a strong indigenous influence. Eva Blanco, 32, a college admissions official in San Jose, Calif., said she wished there were a census box labeled "red." 
"In college, a friend would call me a Mayan princess, because I have the nose you see in the pictures of Mayans," she said. "I feel there's nothing that describes my race per se. For the most part, I say I'm Mexican."
Ellis Cose, who examined racial identity in Latin America for his 1997 book, "Color-Blind: Seeing Beyond Race in a Race-Obsessed World," said these malleable views were quickening the pace of a shift in this country that began in the 1960's, after legal segregation ended and intermarriage became more common.
Growing numbers of interracial unions are also making the color line a moving target. By 2000, the census showed, interracial couples, including those in which one person was of Hispanic origin, made up 7 percent of marriages and 13 percent to 15 percent of households with unmarried partners.
"For the first time, the American construct of race is making room for a large group of folks it never made room for before," said Mr. Cose, who is also a contributing editor for Newsweek.
The growing multiracial population has interfered with the government's accounting of people by race and has become one of the top issues of research and debate among scholars. On Labor Day weekend, Harvard University drew more than 1,000 participants to a "color lines" research conference that delved into the implications for a nation where so much depends on racial categorization: antidiscrimination and voting-rights laws, health and educational statistics and social policies like affirmative action.
Joel Perlmann, a senior scholar at the Levy Economics Institute of Bard College who was a co-editor of "The New Race Question," a 2002 book about how the census counts multiracial people, said the changing demographics were casting doubt on the rationale for the categories themselves.
"Where do these categories come from?" he asked. "What are their justification? It helps delegitimize race."
In California, a movement to shelve racial classifications altogether was behind Proposition 54, the unsuccessful measure on last month's recall ballot that sought to halt the collection of most racial and ethnic data by the state government.
One proponent of the measure was Ward Connerly, the black California businessman who led the winning push for laws in California and Washington State that ban the consideration of race in public university admissions, hiring and government contracting. He argues that racial classifications have become so imprecise as to lose all meaning. 
"We ought to be trying to find a better way of detecting discrimination than this crude way," Mr. Connerly said, adding that he planned to bring another version of Propostition 54 to voters.
But many civil rights advocates and government officials counter that racial categories, as imperfect as they may be, are the only way to measure disparities among groups and provide remedies. And they say that the way Hispanics see themselves may ultimately be irrelevant if they are still subject to other people's biases.
Letvia Arza-Goderich, a lawyer in Los Angeles and a cousin of Mr. Goderich, the Miami Beach police officer, said she felt that she was not regarded as white in the United States except among Latinos. Her family left Cuba in the late 1960's, and as a teenager in Wisconsin, Ms. Arza-Goderich said, her white schoolmates regarded her as dark-skinned and used a slur to describe her. It did not matter that she had pale white skin that looked even whiter against her black wavy hair.
"We were Cubans, and that wasn't white," she said. "My answer was, 'Not that it matters, but I'm white just like you because the people I came from were from Spain.' They'd look at you in disbelief.
"If you're Latino, you're not white-white in the eyes of white Americans," Ms. Arza-Goderich said.
Still, white Hispanics are more prosperous than other Latinos, the Mumford Center study found. Hispanics who described themselves as white on the 2000 Census had the highest incomes and the lowest rates of unemployment and poverty, and they tended to live closest to non-Latino whites, the study said. Black Hispanics, who live in neighborhoods that have nearly as many African-Americans as Hispanic residents, the study found, had lower incomes and higher rates of poverty and unemployment than other Hispanic groups. In those ways they were similar to non-Hispanic blacks.
Those who identified themselves as neither white nor black, the study said, were less affluent than white Hispanics but considerably better off than black Hispanics.
Race relations among Latinos, however, are informed by starkly different experiences compared with those between other groups in America. Among Hispanics, skin color still counts, because Latin American countries have caste systems that discriminate against the dark-skinned. But Latin America did not have Jim Crow laws, or their legacy of bitterness.
Even in the United States, Hispanics who complain of discrimination by other Latinos do not cite race as a major factor, said a national survey last year by the Pew Hispanic Center and the Kaiser Family Foundation. Among those who said they were the victims of bias, the survey found, 41 percent attributed it to disparities in income and education and 34 percent to differences in country of origin. Only 8 percent said it was because of skin color, the survey said.
Hispanics, of course, are not the only ones bending racial identity. Matt Kelly, founder of the Mavin Foundation, a national organization based in Seattle that advocates for multiracial Americans, noted thatin the 2000 census, nearly seven million Americans identified themselves as belonging to two or more races, not counting the Latinos who picked "some other race."
And the culture is offering up role models, like Halle Berry and Tiger Woods, who celebrate their multiracial background.
In Los Angeles, where Hispanics are the largest ethnic group, Ms. Arza-Goderich said she and her husband, who is also Cuban, have never discussed with their three sons "whether they are white, or moreno or what," she said. 
"Race takes a back seat to what they listen to on their CD players, what movies they see," she said. "One is into Japanese anime. Another is immersed in rap. Basically it's the ghetto culture, but ghetto doesn't mean poor or deprived, but hip."
Her 16-year-old, Ray, has adopted a hip-hop persona and hangs out with Vietnamese, Indian, Chicano, white and black friends. Ms. Arza-Goderich said most of them had Asian girlfriends. 
"They say they're hot," she explained.

HEADLINE: Rich Colleges Receiving Richest Share of U.S. Aid 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER

 BODY:
If there is any grand, elegant logic behind the federal government's dispersal of more than a billion dollars in college aid, then Maria Hernandez is humble enough to confess that it has escaped her.
 Consider her point. Poverty is hardly a rarity among the students of California State University at Fresno, where she is the director of financial aid. Many come from families working in the fields nearby, on farms where students spend their summer and winter vacations harvesting peaches and sugar beets to stay in school. 
 About three hours and a world away sits Stanford. Far fewer of its students are poor, yet the federal government gives it about 7 times as much money to help each one of them through college under one program, 28 times as much in another and almost 100 times as much in a third, government data show. 
"Pretty sad," if you ask Ms. Hernandez. 
Similar discrepancies emerge across the nation, adhering to a somewhat counterintuitive underlying theme: The federal government typically gives the wealthiest private universities, which often serve the smallest percentage of low-income students, significantly more financial aid money than their struggling counterparts with much greater shares of poor students. 
Brown, for example, got $169.23 for every student who merely applied for financial aid in order to run its low-interest Perkins loan program in the 2000-1 academic year. Dartmouth got $174.88; Stanford, $211.80. But most universities did not get nearly that much: the median for the nation's colleges was $14.38, according to a New York Times analysis of federal data on the more than 4,000 colleges and universities that receive some form of federal aid.
Nearly 200 colleges received less than $3 per applicant for financial aid. The University of Wisconsin at Madison got 21 cents. 
Harvard, Princeton, Yale -- and all the other members of the Ivy League, for that matter -- were also given 5 to 8 times the median to pay their students in work-study jobs. That is money the institutions got directly, to be spent on behalf of needy students. 
And they got 5 to 20 times the median amount of grant money to look after the everyday needs of their poor students, despite having some of the largest endowments in the nation, if not the world. (Harvard and Yale both have endowments of more than $10 billion. Princeton's is $8.7 billion.)
Such disparities have been a sore point among universities for years, leftovers from an era when federal money was given to colleges on an individual, almost negotiable basis. Now, for the first time in more than two decades, the nation's financial aid officers are calling for the imbalances to be wiped away, replaced by a system that steers financial aid toward the universities that poor students actually attend, rather than those with the biggest reputations.
"We're saying, 'Hey, is this really fair?' " said Dallas Martin, president of the National Association of Student Financial Aid Administrators. "The money ought to follow where the neediest students are. That's the equity piece and that's what's missing."
At first glance, it may seem that some universities receive more money simply because they cost more to attend. But try telling that to Heather McDonnell, director of financial aid at Sarah Lawrence College, which costs just as much as its Ivy League competitors, yet in one category received only a sixth as much money as any of them. 
"It's not even touching reality," Ms. McDonnell said. "It's not even acknowledging any changes in the economy and how my families are doing." 
Even some of the beneficiaries of the imbalance concede that it is not entirely rational, and say they would consent to shedding a few dollars for the sake of parity.
"How could we complain, really?" said Sally C. Donahue, director of financial aid at Harvard College. "We have been very fortunate to receive the money that we have. And the barriers facing low-income students are considerable, so anything increasing their access to college nationally is something we would support wholeheartedly."
As for the origins of the disparities, most veterans of university finance agree that they date back at least to the 1970's, when regional panels of educational experts, not formulas, decided how much colleges would receive. Because each university had to make its own case for the money, those with long histories and a certain financial savoir-faire tended to do particularly well. In fact, the panels were sometimes composed of their peers. 
"If a school was politically savvy and well connected enough, they would end up with the lion's share of the funds," said Ken Redd, research director of the financial aid officers association.
Congress tried to correct the imbalance in 1980, voting to divide the aid according to a "fair share" formula. But that applied only to whatever new money flowed into these programs, guaranteeing that no college would receive less than it was already getting. It is a guarantee that still exists.
The compromise averted a political melee over redistribution, but because spending in these programs has grown relatively slowly in the last 20 years, it did little to eliminate the disparities. Today, about 60 percent of the money is still spent honoring old pledges.
"I wish I had been at the table when the decisions were being made," said JoAnne Boyle, president of Seton Hill University in Pennsylvania. "It just drives me nuts." 
It is the magnitude of the disparities that irks many college officials. At most universities, for example, whenever low-income students get money from the federal government under the Pell grant program, the college receives some, too -- to help the student with tuition, books, housing, meals and so forth. 
For every Pell dollar one of its students received in the 2000-1 academic year (and they could each get up to $4,000), the median college got an extra 7 cents. Harvard got 98 cents. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology got $1.09. Princeton got $1.42. 
At the other end of the scale sit institutions like the City University of New York, which had the most financial aid applicants in the nation that year. It got 4 cents on the dollar. More than 50 colleges got a penny. 
So what does this mean for students? For Princeton in 2000-1, a poor student meant up to $5,680 in extra grant money from the government, money that could have gone toward the student's tuition, room, board or other educational expenses.
The same student would have brought in only $2,000 at Sarah Lawrence, even though its tuition is higher than Princeton's. Sarah Lawrence could have spent its own money making up the difference (although its endowment is less than 1 percent of Princeton's). Or the student could have taken out bigger loans. 
Then there is the money that campuses receive to place students in work-study jobs. For each of its aid applicants, the median college got $87.67 to help pay wages. Yale got $592.75. Duke got $600.28. Columbia got $677.93. But nearly 100 other colleges got less then $20. 
Even under the fairest of systems, college officials say, some protections need to be built in so that low-income students continue to attend elite universities. And given that private colleges typically cost more than twice what public universities do, even after accounting for living expenses, they should usually receive more money, the officials say. But 10 times more than the median? Or 20? 
"The problem is, once people start to see resources start to shift away from them, they do what's necessary to protect their interests," said George Chin, director of financial aid for the City University of New York. 
Indeed, the call for redistribution has put many universities on the defensive, particularly those that worry about doing worse under new rules.
"Any time you talk about reallocating money when there isn't new money, you're going to pit institutions against one another," said Kate Jeffery, director of student financial support for the University of California. In some areas, her campuses do worse than most universities. In others, they do better. "It just doesn't seem appropriate to take it from one school and give it to another," she added.
In fact, few universities seem to know exactly how they would fare under a new system, though the financial aid officers association has a pretty good idea of who would be the big beneficiaries: community colleges and, perhaps most surprisingly, for-profit universities. 
A generation ago, neither kind of institution had the same national presence it does now, and both enroll high percentages of low-income students. These two factors would probably win them a greater share of federal dollars.
The geography of higher education has also changed. Enrollments in Arizona, Texas, Georgia and other states have more than doubled in the last 30 years, while the cluster of Northeastern states that once seemed to anchor higher education have not grown nearly so fast. That, too, could affect where the money goes. 
But, some wonder, at what cost?
"The idea of fairness is certainly a valid one, but there are so many schools below their fair share that any redistribution may have a very negligible impact on their schools," said William Schilling, director of financial aid at the University of Pennsylvania. "But the schools that would lose money would face a major problem."

HEADLINE: Intimate Escapes 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE LYNESS

 BODY:
THOSE of us who are romantic types cling to the fantasy that there are still lovely spots, as yet undiscovered and not too far from home, where we can escape for a quiet weekend in the country. Like M.F.K. Fisher, we'll eat simple but delicious food in sweet local restaurants within walking distance of our charming, inexpensive hotel. 
 I gave up trying to live a romantic life when I realized that it wasn't much fun. You're pining after some guy, traipsing around bleak landscapes looking for a nice hotel, and your luggage is too heavy. After years of experience and plot development, I've figured out that what you want to do is to play at romance. And that requires a lot of practical thinking. 
 Recently, I got some help with the practical part when I ran into marketing on the Web for an area of northeastern Connecticut that has been dubbed "the Quiet Corner." It promises the romantic fantasy: a beautiful, relatively unpopulated area, little traveled by tourists, with historical interest, quaint restaurants and cute bed-and-breakfasts. 
My first stop was the town of Pomfret, and Celebrations Inn, a bed-and-breakfast. A B&B would not have been my first choice - I don't like them as a rule. It's a question of style: I'm looking for a place with a lot of privacy, which B&B's typically don't have. You're in someone's house; they are in fact hosting you and that demands a certain amount of generosity and friendly interaction on the part of both host and guest. Call me curmudgeonly, but I'm usually down on my reserves of both qualities by the time I go on vacation. 
I also want a room with a seating area where I can hang out comfortably with my main squeeze if it rains -- my own room, not the kind of communal area that B&B's usually provide for that purpose. I also want a view of a good enough restaurant within walking distance or in the lodging place itself and some access to the outdoors, perhaps a garden or a deck, or a quiet road nearby for walking. My preference is therefore for a hotel that is small enough to have character, but large enough to house a restaurant. (There is at least one small hotel in the area - the Inn at Woodstock Hill - but by the time I checked in early September, weekends were booked into November.)
Celebrations Inn walks the line quite elegantly between small hotel and B&B with just enough formality to suit me. It is a large, very pink Victorian house on Route 169. There are several rooms; those that I stuck my head into were reasonably large and pretty without being fussy or precious. (Rooms are $125 to $175 a night, double occupancy; there is often a two-night minimum on weekends.) The hosts, Jean and Bill Barton, are friendly and professional, and not intrusive. There is a garden out back with interesting corners to explore. The Bafflin Nature Sanctuary, an Audubon Society Preserve, is a short walk or drive down the road. Most of the trails are about a mile long; the trail we walked, Beaver Pond trail, was a gentle walk through woods and fields, with information about the birds posted along the way. (The inn can give you a trail map).
A few minutes up the road, you can get a friendly lunch or dinner at the Harvest in a large, pretty Colonial house. There are several small dining rooms, including an enclosed porch - ask for a room with a fireplace. The food is continental and Japanese; this unusual combination worked surprisingly well for our dinner here. The gyoza were what you would expect from these dumplings and my sauteed shrimp pasta was well cooked, tasting of garlic, white wine and lemon. A specialty of the restaurant is steaks. 
Also close to the Harvest and Celebrations is the Vanilla Bean Cafe, which is reminiscent of a 60's coffee shop, where Arlo Guthrie might have played. I was in there only for coffee; people have told me that the sandwiches and breakfasts are very good. 
But my favorite place to eat in this area is Sharpe Hill Vineyard, also an easy drive from Pomfret, although a little hard to find. This small restaurant in a faux Colonial barn serves good, solid food and wine in sight of the vineyard. . Meats and fish grilled over a wood fire are delicious here and desserts are beautifully done; or have the cheese plate for dessert with the dregs of your wine. You can do a formal wine tasting -- the vineyard produces eight varieties -- before or after the meal if you like. Or buy wine by the glass during the meal and drink something different with every course. 
I recommend lunch -- I almost always do -- so that you can enjoy the place in the light. After lunch, we came across a trailhead off Route 97, just opposite Kimball Road, marked H.E. Preston Sanctuary Nature Preserve. I didn't have the time to explore the trail that day but I wished that I had; it had a deliciously private feel, as if perhaps no one else had ever been there. A call to the Joshua's Tract Conservation and Historic Trust revealed it to be a one-mile walk through upland meadows and woods.
Later, we drove to the Creamery Brook Bison Farm on Purvis Road in Brooklyn. There is a spectacular view west off Allen Hill Road, near Route 205, but the bison made me sad. I returned to the Quiet Corner for a second time on a prime fall weekend. The area was as trafficked as I think it gets - leaf peepers, of course, and people attending events at a number of private schools in the area. While the area still didn't feel crowded, finding accommodations and making restaurant reservations were more difficult. 
Benefiting from a cancellation, I got a room at the Corttis Inn bed and breakfast, a farmhouse on 900 acres in North Grosvenor Dale, almost to the Massachusetts border. A more traditional B&B, the Corttis Inn is also more intimate than Celebrations. The host, Herb Corttis, is extremely congenial and the rooms are comfortable and inexpensive (for $65, I had my own room and shared a bathroom with a friend, which worked just fine). The inn has a large family suite, as well. The host makes a great breakfast -- not fancy, just really good food. 
On a beautiful fall day, we first explored Bigelow Hollow State Park, a spectacular drive west from the inn, along Route 197. With the exception of the people pulling their boats out of the lake, there was almost no one in the park; we walked a wooded trail around a lake that was with views that reminded me of the Adirondacks. 
From the park, we headed to Putnam, an old mill town, very different than Pomfret, with the feel of industrial revolution New England. The large red brick Main Street is lined with antique stores. I don't go antiquing but if you do, there is a great selection here. . There is also a lot of good food. We ate lunch at Pyzzz, down the hill from the railroad station; it's funky, has beer on tap and serves good pizza with some creative combinations, including dessert pizza and a special that day of mashed-potato pizza. That night, we had an excellent dinner at the Vine Bistro in Putnam. The restaurant has a modern feel and serves contemporary, urban American food. I had low expectations: it seemed unlikely that such a restaurant could be successful in such a small town, but I was wrong. The food is well prepared by anyone's standards. 
If you want to buy lunch for a picnic or a walk in one of the parks, Jessica Tuesday's is a small upscale deli by the railroad station serving soup, sandwiches and salads - both eat in and take out. The enormous cinnamon rolls are of good, homemade quality. And then we were surprised to run into Mrs. Bridges Pantry, a British tea shop and grocery store down the block run by a British couple. The store was originally a little grocery store of British foods; it now sells British food and gifts, and you can have an authentic British tea there, too.
The Quiet Corner is still surprisingly rural, with rolling hills (less hilly than the Berkshires), woods and lakes reminiscent of the English countryside; lovely in the summer and stunningly beautiful in the fall. The landscape has a classic New England feel - red barns, white churches with steeples, and colonial architecture, and red brick commercial. There are still working farms, animals and orchards, with farm stands along the road in season. 
In addition to the excursions I've already mentioned, I particularly like the area south of Pomfret near the vineyard, including Hampton and Mashamoquet Brook State Park for the small, winding roads and intimate landscapes.
There are also lovely areas to walk, or hike, for the more energetic. In addition to the two parks, the Nature Conservancy maintains walking trails, as do a couple of land trusts; the Kimball Road trail is owned by Joshua's Tract Trust. 
What I like about this part of Connecticut is its honesty. Despite its picture book vistas, it doesn't put on airs (not yet, anyway). It's an authentic rural and industrial area that has seen economic hardship and it shows: there is New England charm, to be sure, but towns are also a little beat up in the way that Hudson Valley towns are beat up.
Tourism hasn't made the area precious or quaint. And lest you begin to drift too far into romantic reverie, there are frequent squads of motorcycles racing along Route 169 to bring you briskly back to reality.

Stops Along an Unbeaten Path

HEADLINE: Turning Menus' Pages To Travel the World 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN HODARA

 BODY:
READ between the lines of menu offerings from restaurants throughout Westchester and you're bound to find sagas of journeys from far-off lands, memories of grandmothers' kitchens and youthful dreams fulfilled. Following are five options for dining that serve up ethnic dishes as well as tales from across the globe. 

Caribbean Harmony
 Christopher McDonald, the owner and chef at Chows Caribbean Cuisine in Tarrytown, earned his nickname, Chow, as a young boy in Jamaica where he was known for his passion for cooking. 
 Though he traveled regularly between this country and Jamaica as a photographer shooting reggae musicians in the 1970's and 80's, he never intended to settle here, even after moving to Brooklyn in 1984.
"I didn't feel comfortable in Brooklyn," he said. "It was too different from where I grew up. I was heading home when I discovered Westchester." 
Mr. McDonald, 46, now lives with his wife in Ossining, and for nearly two years, has devoted all his time to his 49-seat restaurant, where reggae music sets the mood and an outsize decanter of Jamaican rum punch perches by the cash register. 
Photographs of musicians including Bob Marley and Jimmy Cliff, some taken by Mr. McDonald, decorate the walls. 
"Everything you eat here -- it's my food," Mr. McDonald said, meaning his brand of authentic Jamaican dishes, from fried plantains, conch soup and warm codfish salad, to entrees like the seafood medley he calls wobo, curried goat, escovitchfish, and, of course, jerk chicken. 
Another specialty, a combination of salt fish and a fruit called ackee, is described on the menu as "The Jamaican National Dish!!!" Among the dessert selections are Chow's Pineapple/Mango Caribbean Cream and a pastry called gizzarda baked with coconut, ginger and other spices. Beverage offerings include Red Stripe beer, D&G Jamaican sodas and Blue Mountain coffee. 
Mr. McDonald said his restaurant is a tribute to his great-grandmother and his grandmother, both of whom inspired his love of good food. "I still remember the smells of the spices from the time I was 2 and hanging onto my great-grandmother's skirts in her kitchen," he said.
Chows Caribbean Cuisine, 49 Main Street, Tarrytown, (914) 332-9111. 
Entrees $12 to $20. Open Tuesdays to Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 11 p.m., Fridays to Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 2 p.m., Sundays, 2 to 10 p.m. 

Brazilian Close-Up
The only staff member at Pantanal who is not Brazilian is its owner, Richard Cuddy, 40, a resident of Danbury, Conn., who bought the 10-year-old Port Chester restaurant last February. Since then, he has redecorated with a tropical theme -- yellow walls and green linens (colors of the Brazilian flag), trompe l'oeil murals of oversize plants, and an entryway painted with scenes from the Amazon with piped-in sound effects to match. 
Pantanal is the first restaurant venture for Mr. Cuddy, whose background is in real estate. He had been managing the building that housed the restaurant, a building that his father owned, when the restaurant became available and he decided it would be a lucrative opportunity. 
Pantanal draws diners -- a mix of Brazilians, Portuguese and Americans of all ages (a children's menu is available) -- not only from Westchester, Mr. Cuddy said, but also from Manhattan and as far north as Kingston. They come for karaoke on Thursdays; jazz on weekends; an assortment of Brazilian bar drinks, including A Marca Bavaria beer, caipirinha and batidas; and an elaborate salad bar. Mostly, though, they come for the traditional Brazilian fare. 
This includes 39 choices of Brazilian pizza, prepared by a specially trained chef called a "pizzaiola," with extra thin crust and toppings like chicken, corn, figs and imported catupiry cheese. "This is pizza you eat with a knife and fork," said Mr. Cuddy, who is studying Portuguese so he can communicate better with his customers. "Brazilians don't eat with their hands." 
He added that the only other restaurants he has heard of that serve such pizza in this country are in Newark, N. J., and Boston, Mass. 
Another specialty is rodizio, an all-you-can-eat selection of grilled, skewered meats, including homemade sausage, chicken hearts, picania (fillet), and, soon, buffalo. Those who order rodizio are provided with a small, tri-colored, wooden cylinder with which they signal their server, or "passar carne," whether they are ready for more (green), taking a break (yellow) or sated and ready to stop (red).
Pantanal Restaurant, 29 North Main Street, Port Chester (914)939-6894. Entrees $14.95 to $27.75 (for rodizio). Open seven days, noon to 3:30 p.m. and 5 to 11 p.m. 

Turkey Transplanted
Well before his emigration from Turkey to the United States in 1997, Bekir Helvacioglu, 29, was preparing for a career as a restaurateur. Throughout high school, he worked as a dishwasher. He studied culinary arts in college, then spent two years learning hotel management, honing his skills in housekeeping, sales and reception, as well as food preparation and pastry creation. Rounding out his education, he earned an M.B.A. in finance after arriving in New York. In April 2002, with two partners who have since left, he acquired Turkish Meze in Mamaroneck, then called Just Meze. 
With Middle Eastern music as backdrop, the decor of Turkish Meze evokes Mr. Helvacioglu's birthplace, with its claret-red walls adorned with woven carpets and photographs of Turkey. "This is where I honeymooned with my wife," he said, indicating a picture where the tip of a sunny peninsula juts into an impossibly blue sea. 
But it is the menu that offers Turkey's true flavors, with specialties including ezo gelin soup, blending pureed lentils, bulgur and onions with mint and garlic; appetizers like lebni (homemade yogurt with peppers, garlic and walnuts) and patlican (a salad of chopped grilled baby eggplant, tomatoes, onions and peppers); and entrees like kebabs, sebzeli guvec (fresh vegetable casserole) and manti (tiny lamb-stuffed dumplings topped with tomato sauce and drizzled with butter). 
In addition to shopping, food preparation and some cooking, Mr. Helvacioglu said he "tweaks" traditional recipes to create his own versions of many of the dishes on his menu, using hard-to-find spices like sumac and the spicy aleppo. He credits his mother as his mentor in the kitchen. 
"My mother is the chef," said Mr. Helvacioglu, who commutes to Mamaroneck from Queens. "Whenever I have a question about the food, I call her in Turkey and she tells me what to do." 
Turkish Meze Restaurant, 409 Mount Pleasant Avenue, Mamaroneck,(914) 777-3042 
Entrees, $10.95 to $19.95. Open Mondays to Thursdays, noon to 9:30 p.m., Fridays to Saturdays, noon to 10:30 p.m., Sundays, 3 to 9:30 p.m.. 

Italian Via Albania
Ask the owner John (Fuffi) Nikci, 39, about Albanian cuisine and he'll tell you it's too heavy and too simple to comprise an entire menu. 
"For 500 years, Albania was occupied -- by the Ottomans, the Serbs, the Bulgarians, the Italians," Mr. Nikci explained. "The only Albanians who preserved their national identity were those who took refuge in the mountains. In the cities, they ate all kinds of cuisine -- Italian, Greek, Russian, Polish. In the mountains, they ate simple, heavy food -- roasted lamb and roasted potatoes. That's about it for strictly Albanian cuisine." 
Which is why Mr. Nikci, who emigrated from Albania for political and economic reasons when he was 18, includes only a few Albanian and Croatian offerings on his predominantly Italian menu at Fuffi of Irvington. These include the appetizer animella di vitello, sweetbreads made with cornmeal ("the way the poor made it in Albania," noted Mr. Nikci); fresh fig salad; orecchiette piemontese, a pasta with sausage and feta cheese ("too heavy for the northern Italians," he said); and shell steak Gjovalini, topped with sopresatta and Gorgonzola. 
Mr. Nikci began learning his trade as a dishwasher at age 14, and later as busboy, waiter, captain and cook. He lived in the Bronx for 14 years before moving to Westchester, where he owned restaurants in Ardsley and Larchmont. But it wasn't until he discovered his current location six years ago that he felt he had found home. 
"I love it here," he said. "I love the space, I love the town. It's the first place I've called home in 20 years." He serves as a volunteer for the Irvington fire department and ambulance corps, and through Fuffi, holds annual fund-raisers for local charities. 
In the inner of Fuffi's two intimate dining rooms, alongside a collection of artwork from around the world, hangs a painting created by one of the restaurant's regulars. It is a portrait of Mr. Nikci and his newly-wed wife, Kathy, who works as Fuffi's manager. Along the top is a message written in Albanian that refers to the "kisses on both cheeks" and "Albanian hospitality" that greet Fuffi's diners. 
"That's how it is here," Mr. Nikci said. "You feel it the instant you walk in. Our customers are no longer customers; they become friends." 
Fuffi of Irvington, 12 North Astor Street, Irvington, (914)591-0099. 
Entrees, $16 to $27. Open Mondays to Thursdays, 5 to 10 p.m., Fridays to Saturdays, 5 to 11 p.m. 

Portuguese, to the Detail
Each Wednesday, a ship leaves Portugal laden with fish caught off the coast, and heads across the Atlantic for the Portuguese market in Newark, N.J. Which means that every Thursday, diners at Churrasquiera Ribatejo Portuguese Grill, situated in the heart of Ossining's burgeoning downtown, can enjoy specials like grilled linguado (sole), robalo (striped bass), bacalhau (codfish) and other seasonal fresh fish. Also on the menu, which is presented in both English and Portuguese, are frog legs in garlic sauce, octopus salad and grilled quails, along with more familiar dishes like barbecued chicken and a surf and turf combination. 
Daily specials include cozido, a combination of boiled meat, cabbage and potatoes, and dobrada, a stew of tripe, beans, carrots, chorizo and other ingredients served with rice. 
Churrasquiera Ribatejo is owned by Jose Laranjeira, 39, and his wife Rosa, 42, Ossining residents who, Mr. Laranjeira said, "are involved in every little detail" of their business. Their 18-year-old daughter, Christina, a Marymount College student, waits tables after class. 
The environment here is casual and welcoming, with a diverse blend of clientele.
The front area by the entrance is a gathering place for local workers, whose laughter travels to the 30-seat dining area in the rear, where the stucco walls, sponge-painted a warm peach, are adorned with photographs of Portugal. 
"We love kids, and everyone is welcome," Mrs. Laranjeira said, adding that the couple have been pleased by the number of Americans who enjoy their food. "We weren't sure our American customers would like it," she said, "but once they try it, they order it again and again." 
Mr. Laranjeira, who was born in Tarrytown but lived in Portugal as a young child, bought Churrasquiera Ribatejo three years ago with only his passion for cooking and knowledge of good food to guide him. (He worked previously at General Motors in Tarrytown and as a landscaper.) 
As a self-taught chef ---- "He reads cookbooks all the time," said his wife ---- he enjoys concocting his own recipes.
He makes flan daily for his dessert menu, which also offers chocolate mousse and tiramisu, because, he said, "It's something I like to do." 
Churrasquiera Ribatejo Portuguese Grill, 39 Spring Street, Ossining, (914) 941-5928. Entrees $8 to $25. Open noon to 10 p.m. weekdays, noon to 11 p.m. weekends; closed Tuesdays.

HEADLINE: Bankrupt. Who Pays? 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

DATELINE: PARAMUS 

 BODY:
IN the final days at Workbench on Route 17 here, the store was as spare as the sleek, modern furniture it sold.
 Huge black and yellow signs screamed: "Nothing Held Back. Selling out to the Bare Walls." The showrooms were nearly naked, with a few entertainment units, one Milan dresser marked down from $1,299 to $779.40 and a lone dining set. 
 Marlee Laks poked through the remains with warm memories. 
"I did my first apartment all in Workbench," Ms. Laks said, 20 years, 3 children and a house in Montclair later.
"It's the end of an era," she said. "I can't do Workbench anymore. It doesn't exist."
In New Jersey, where malls and strip-shopping centers dominate the landscape, retail bankruptcies like the one that closed the doors at Workbench have become a part of everyday commerce.
Kmart. Macy's. Bloomingdale's. All have done time in bankruptcy court, where a judge's signature can wipe away millions of dollars in bad business decisions, leaving banks, investors and creditors with a few cents on the dollar.
For the 12 months ending in September, the total number of business bankruptcy cases in New Jersey rose to 28,059 from 26,045. Of those, 349 were reorganizations, a decrease of 4 percent from the previous 12 months; the remaining 27,710 were liquidations, up 23 percent, according to the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey.
The demise of Workbench, which had its headquarters in Bayonne for the past 10 years, is a story of bankruptcy that begins with debt and revolves around lending squeezes and balky vendors. Overseeing the company was Kenneth Peskin, a chief executive from Summit with a supermarket background. Some creditors say he was better equipped to sell Danish pastry than Danish Modern.
"You really don't care where you buy your Kellogg's cornflakes," said Warren Rubin, who founded Workbench in 1955. "Furniture is different. Furniture is about style and taste."
The final act, which has just about played out, is a court-ordered liquidation that left creditors, investors and customers of Workbench out millions of dollars and 298 employees out of work.
"Bankruptcy is so much a part of the business cycle, it is almost built-in," said Dean Waldt, a lawyer in Voorhees who represented several landlords in the Workbench bankruptcy. "The retailers know they can expand and be overly aggressive in getting stores open and shut them down if it doesn't work out. While there are some smaller chains that just fail, more and more, Chapter 11 is a part of retail. It's a safety valve, and people know it's there if they need it."
Workbench was not always a staple of suburbia. In fact, Mr. Rubin started it as a storefront in Greenwich Village in 1955. By last year the company had 40 outlets nationwide and $44 million in sales. 
But that was not enough to keep the business out of the hands of the court-appointed trustee. The owners -- primarily Mr. Peskin and a Morristown venture capital firm -- who bought the chain from Mr. Rubin in 1998 and 1999, said in court papers that Workbench was done in by a weak economy, bad weather and the war in Iraq. The company lost $2.8 million in 2001, $1.6 million in 2002 and $2.6 million in just the first quarter of 2003.
When reached for comment at his home in Summit, Mr. Peskin declined to discuss the business.
For their part, employees, landlords and Mr. Rubin, the company's founder and longtime owner, say the new management took on too much debt and mismanaged the business.
"They were having problems by 2000," said Ross Levin, a former Workbench franchisee in North Carolina, who is owed $377,776 by the chain. "It wasn't 9/11, or snowstorms or the current economic conditions." 
Mr. Rubin's reaction was far more visceral. "I feel my baby has been murdered," he said in a recent interview.
In addition to business creditors, consumers were also caught up in the case this summer as Workbench continued to take deposits on merchandise even as the company was in the throes of bankruptcy.
"The real crime here is that several thousand customers won't get their deposits back," Mr. Rubin said.
As a result, the attorneys general in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York are monitoring the case. Customers who put deposits on their credit cards have been told to dispute the charges; the cases of those who paid cash or put down deposits after the company's bankruptcy filing are in the court's hands.
"As with any bankruptcy, where consumers are impacted we're keeping watch on it," said Genene Morris, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey attorney general's office. "Our concern is for consumers who have made deposits,"
Mr. Peskin, the chief executive of Workbench since 1998, resigned from the company on Oct. 23. The next day, a federal trustee determined that the business was insolvent and converted the case from a voluntary bankruptcy liquidation under Mr. Peskin's control to a forced sell-off overseen by a court-appointed trustee.
Michael Holt, law partner of the court-appointed trustee, Charles Forman, said Mr. Peskin's resignation as well as a dispute over the value of the remaining merchandise were among the reasons the federal trustee stepped in. 
Gordon Brothers of Boston, the nation's largest retail liquidating firm, had agreed to run Workbench's going-out-of-business sale in return for a percentage of the proceeds, based on an estimate of retail inventory valued at $11 million to $13 million, Mr. Holt said. But after reviewing the inventory, the liquidator learned the remaining merchadise was worth only $7 million.
"It doesn't surprise me the figures don't match, knowing the incompetence of the management," said Mr. Levin, the former franchise owner from North Carolina.
Mr. Peskin, who has had his share of successes and failures, worked as a grocery clerk while growing up in the Bronx. After graduating from Harvard Business School he went to work for Pathmark, the grocery chain based in Carteret. He rose through the ranks and in 1987, at age 47, was named chief executive of Pathmark's parent company, Supermarkets General.
But the company was struggling because it had just gone through a $1.8 billion leveraged buyout deal in an effort to retain control of the company after a hostile takeover attempt. In 1989, Mr. Peskin left the company, but the debt remained.
"While the stores operated successfully, the penalty of the heavy expense impacted the company's cash flow and management's ability to keep its stores current and competitive," Jonathan Ziegler, an independent research analyst with J.M. Dutton, wrote in a report on Pathmark.
In the end, Pathmark filed for bankruptcy court protection in 2000, wiping away $1 billion in debt.
"The entire morale and spirit of the company lifted because the company was able to cancel approximately $1 billion of its subordinated debt," Mr. Ziegler wrote.
As for Mr. Peskin, after leaving Supermarkets General he met with some success when he took over the management of a bankrupt boating supply company, E&B Marine of Edison, and in 1996 merged it with a competitor, West Marine, according to Mr. Levin. 
At about the same time, Warren Rubin, the founder of Workbench, was nearing 70. Neither of his two daughters was interested in taking over the business, so he decided to cash out.
Through an acquaintance at Harvard, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Peskin were introduced, and Mr. Peskin lined up financing through MidMark Capital, a Morristown venture capital firm that specializes in using Small Business Administration guarantees to buy small to medium-sized companies.
In 1998, MidMark and Mr. Peskin paid Mr. Rubin more than $20 million for Workbench, where Mr. Rubin continued to work as a consultant. At the time of Workbench's bankruptcy filing, MidMark owned 66 percent of the company and Mr. Peskin owned 32 percent, with Mr. Rubin and several other lenders holding the remaining 2 percent.
In addition to its own capital, MidMark borrowed $9 million from IBJ Whitehall, a subsidiary of the Industrial Bank of Japan, to buy Workbench, according to Mr. Rubin. 
"They used too much borrowed money and got into big trouble with their banks," said Mr. Rubin. Mr. Levin suggested that it was not only the debt, but also the price paid to Mr. Rubin -- $20 million -- that was too high for company sales to sustain. 
"More power to him," Mr. Levin said of Mr. Rubin, "but now I'm the one who's out."
There were signs of trouble early on. In July 2000, MidMark, Mr. Peskin and Mr. Rubin put up more than $800,000 to recapitalize the company. But by 2001 the company was in default on its loan from IBJ Whitehall, according to bankruptcy papers.
In December 2001, the General Electric Capital Corporation replaced IBJ Whitehall as the main lender at a lower rate, Mr. Levin said, reducing the debt payment from $587,000 to $125,000 each quarter. But by April 2003 the company was again in default and General Electric called in its loan, according to court papers.
In the meantime, vendors were not being paid. McCreary Modern, a North Carolina furniture manufacturer, the company's largest unsecured creditor, is still owed $963,462. D-Scan Inc., a Massachusetts furniture maker, is owed $307,696. Workbench also has creditors in Denmark, Italy and Portugal.
"It was unbelievable," Mr. Rubin said. "Ken thought the vendors would go along with him. They felt that they were damned if they were going to carry him any further."
For a store like Workbench, which sold much of its inventory off the floor, that was deadly, said Lisa Acevedo, who managed a Workbench store in Raleigh, N.C..
Ms. Acevedo and other managers said their stores had been doing well despite Mr. Peskin's claims that the war in Iraq and a slowing economy had hurt sales.
"I'm sheltered from the corporate headquarters so I didn't see everything, but in the end they just didn't have the capital," she said.
On June 23, Workbench filed for protection from its creditors in federal bankruptcy court in Newark. At that time, the company said it planned to close 11 stores, mostly in the Midwest, and 3 warehouses in an effort to restructure and save the business. The closings, along with cuts in corporate overhead, were expected to save $2 million a year, according to Workbench's bankruptcy papers.
But on Sept. 4, Workbench returned to the court and asked to liquidate after major suppliers refused to extend additional credit. On Sept. 22, Judge Donald H. Steckroth granted Workbench's request to hire Gordon Brothers to sell off the remaining merchandise and close the last 29 stores.
Last weekend, Workbench sold off the last of its inventory at its warehouse in Bayonne. On Tuesday, the company's own office furniture and equipment were auctioned off. "There's nothing left for any of the creditors," said Wendy Marcari, a lawyer with Traub, Bonacquist & Fox in New York, who represented a group of unsecured creditors.
Those who blame Mr. Peskin for Workbench's fall say it seems to have been more a case of ineptitude than avarice.
"As far as I can figure out there was no hanky-panky," Mr. Rubin said, "and believe me, I've looked."

Wheeler for The New York Times)(pg. 1); Only days before it closed, a customer looked over the remaining merchandise at the Workbench store in Short Hills. (Photo by John W. Wheeler for The New York Times)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: In Many Recruitment Efforts, Health Benefits Act as Lure 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
When Maggie Mateer was offered a job last July as an accountant for the Xerox Corporation, she hesitated. It wasn't that she did not want the job, or that the salary was too low. Ms. Mateer, who had five years of experience as a certified public accountant, wanted to pore over the details of the company's health plan before she signed on.
 Only after grilling a Xerox human resources representative for more than half an hour -- and finding out that she would be paying $100 less a month out of pocket for health coverage than she had been -- did Ms. Mateer, 26, accept the job. She is now based at the company's headquarters in Rochester. 
 "Good benefits were very important to me," Ms. Mateer said. "I wasn't going to take any job without doing my homework."
With the ranks of uninsured Americans rising sharply -- the number of Americans without health insurance increased by 2.4 million last year, according to the Census Bureau -- and with health care costs for employers rising at double-digit rates, more job seekers are taking a keen interest in the benefit packages offered by potential employers. It is a striking change from the late 1990's, said Emmett Seaborn, a principal at Towers Perrin, a benefit consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn. 
"A few years ago, the only thing people were looking at were salary and potential for career advancement," he said. "Employees weren't asking about benefit plans at all, other than maybe saying, 'Oh, do you have medical benefits?' as they're walking out the door. Now, many start with, 'Tell me about your health plan,' and ask about salary later."
A survey of 865 workers conducted this summer by Center for Survey Research at the State University of New York at Stony Brook reveals strong concerns about health benefits. When asked whether they would prefer a job with health coverage and a lower salary or a job with no health coverage and a higher salary, 71 percent of the respondents opted for the lower salary with benefits.
In addition, 20 percent of those who responded said that they were dissatisfied with the health benefits their company offered, and 50 percent said that they were worried that their health benefits would be cut back in the coming year.
Employees may have reason to worry. According to a survey released last month by Towers Perrin, employees will contribute an average of $59 a month in 2004 for employee-only coverage (up from $38 a month in 2002) and $196 a month to cover their families (up from $134 a month in 2002). Most will also pay more in co-payments for physician visits, deductibles and prescription fees, according to the study.
Such fees have some workers feeling increasingly pinched. One marketing executive who joined a small brand-development firm in New York City in 2001 said that her firm made her wait a full year before giving her health coverage. Even with that coverage, she says she has racked up several hundred dollars in co-payments to doctors this year alone.
"It's getting to the point of being ridiculous," said the executive, who said she was considering looking for work at a company that provides better health coverage.
The promise of 100 percent paid health benefits helped lure Kat McAndrew to Ferrare & Fleming Advertising in Philadelphia last April. 
Ms. McAndrew had previously worked for a dot-com company that did not offer any health benefits, and later for a maternity clothing company that paid only a portion of her health plan costs. "In this day and age, paying nothing for your health coverage is practically unheard-of," said Ms. McAndrew, who works as an account executive in the company's public relations division. "For me, that was a big draw."
Unfortunately for most workers, few companies are offering extensive health benefits in this economic climate. But some are creating and refining other, less expensive benefits as a way to attract and retain workers, said Barry Schilmeister, a principal at Mercer Human Resources Consulting. 
Some companies are increasing the number of vacation days given to employees, or considering a variety of other benefits, including a broader range of retirement options, retirement planning assistance and backup child care programs, Mr. Schilmeister said. At the end of 2001, for example, Ernst & Young, the professional services company with headquarters in New York, began giving new employees three weeks of paid vacation instead of two, and added paternity- and adoption-leave benefits, according to a spokeswoman.
These enhanced benefits helped to entice one Ernst & Young alumna, Lisa Meyer, to rejoin the company earlier this year. One big reason she came back after a brief stint with a real estate firm, she said, was Ernst & Young's flexible hours policy, which allows Ms. Meyer to take her three children to school before arriving to work at 9:30 each morning. 
The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca plans to roll out a new health plan in January that will require some employees to pay more out of pocket for medical expenses, but the company is also expanding the range of flexible work programs it offers. 
In March, the company added an on-site child care center, said Andrea Moselle, senior manager for work-life programs. And in September, it opened an on-site kindergarten, and a before- and after-school program for children in kindergarten through 12th grade. "We tout these benefits as a competitive advantage" at recruiting fairs and in job interviews, Ms. Moselle said.
In one recent case, she said, a physician who had job offers from both AstraZeneca and one of its chief competitors had his wife come in and check out the child care center before making his decision. He ended up taking the position at AstraZeneca. "The child care center was the tipping point," she said.
Job seekers who are not satisfied with the benefits offered by a potential employer have some room for negotiation, said Pam Sednak, managing partner at O'Brien & Company, an executive search firm based in Cleveland. While very few companies will haggle over health care plan costs, some are willing to shorten the amount of time it takes for such benefits to take effect or to cover stopgap insurance. And benefits like vacation time are highly negotiable, Ms. Sednak said. 
But Ms. Sednak cautioned that job seekers should not insist on too many additional benefits. "You don't want to appear too greedy, especially in this job market," she said.

HEADLINE: Court Treatment System Is Found to Help Drug Offenders Stay Clean 

BYLINE:  By PAUL von ZIELBAUER

 BODY:
Nonviolent drug offenders who complete judge-supervised treatment programs are significantly less likely to commit crimes again than those who serve prison time, according to a new study by an independent research arm of the New York State court system.
 The study underscores what New York's chief judge, officials at the United States Justice Department and local judges across the country have believed for years, without the benefit of formal research: that state-run "drug courts" offering court-supervised treatment programs are far better at preventing future criminal behavior than prison is, and that they do so at a fraction of the cost. 
 The study of New York's drug court system, by the Center for Court Innovation, found that in six sample jurisdictions -- including three in New York City -- the rearrest rate among drug offenders who had completed a court-monitored treatment plan was 29 percent lower over three years than the rate for the same type of drug offenders who opt for prison time without treatment.
"These are very positive findings, I think, getting to the answer of whether drug courts work in reducing recidivism," said Deborah J. Daniels, an assistant United States attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's grant-making arm, which gives millions of dollars to local drug courts. "It shows that drug courts continue to be a very promising way of dealing with a first-offender or nearly first-offender population." 
Drug courts focus on a limited, voluntary group of offenders and generally do not admit hard-core criminals, like major drug traffickers, multiple-felony offenders or anyone with a history of violence. 
New York drug courts, which have included 18,000 nonviolent drug offenders who have volunteered to participate in court-monitored treatment in lieu of incarceration, have saved an estimated $254 million in prison-related expenses, the report said. 
They have also helped low-level offenders like Jimmie Bellamy, 24, of Jamaica, Queens, stay out of trouble. Mr. Bellamy, arrested twice since 2000 for possessing a small amount of cocaine, is one of 250 participants in Judge Leslie G. Leach's Queens Treatment Court, one of 13 in the city.
A third conviction would send Mr. Bellamy to jail. But next month, Mr. Bellamy, an airport freight handler, will complete his one-year program under Judge Leach's guidance and graduate out of drug court.
"Before I started with the program, I thought it was a joke," Mr. Bellamy, carrying a sign-in sheet for his Narcotics Anonymous meeting, said in an interview after an appearance before Judge Leach on Thursday. "I didn't have my G.E.D., I didn't have a job. Now, I'm working on my G.E.D., I got a job. I just bought me a car." 
The need for drug courts, judges and prosecutors say, has increased as the number of drug arrests nationwide has exploded over the last two decades. New York State recorded 145,694 drug arrests in 2000, a sixfold increase from the 24,407 arrests made in 1980. More than half of New York State prisoners convicted of drug-related crimes are arrested again within three years.
Court-ordered drug treatment has been a fixture in states' criminal justice systems for years. Drug courts are distinguished by their requirement that judges and prosecutors monitor an offender's progress in treatment. There are now more than 1,000 state and local drug courts across the nation, including 106 in New York, the second-largest state system next to California's.
New York State's drug court system is regarded as one of the best in the nation, said John S. Goldkamp, a professor of criminal justice at Temple University, who has studied the impact of drug courts in several states.
New Jersey operates about 20 drug courts in 13 counties, but budget cuts have delayed plans to open them in the state's remaining 8 counties. 
Connecticut is planning to reopen its half-dozen drug courts soon. They were closed for budget reasons last year; at the time, the state court system's chief administrator, Judge Joseph H. Pellegrino, said drug courts "may not have been as successful as we may have thought," the Associated Press reported.
Judge John R. Schwartz began New York's first drug court in Rochester in 1995, over considerable doubts among some of New York's most influential judges. But within months, city courts in Buffalo and Syracuse, and a district court in Suffolk County, had drug courts.
The first drug court started in 1989 in Miami -- the illicit gateway for South American cocaine -- as local criminal courts were being overwhelmed with drug cases. Dade County jurists and officials formed a committee to discuss creating incentives for addicts to get treatment. 
"They invented a model that they never meantto be a model for the country," Professor Goldkamp said.
That Janet Reno was the Dade County prosecutor at the time and Hugh Rodham, Hillary Rodham Clinton's brother, was a local public defender also helped garner attention. President Bill Clinton appointed Ms. Reno attorney general in 1993, and the next year, Congress, led by Democrats, passed a crime-prevention bill that sent $6 million toward drug courts in local jurisdictions around the country.
This year, a Republican-controlled Congress approved nearly $45 million for drug courts in all 50 states, Washington and Puerto Rico, and President Bush's budget proposal for next year includes $64 million.
The administration has consistently supported increased financing for drug courts; President Bush's niece Noelle Bush is one of the 100,000 people who have entered drug courts over the past 14 years. 
In January 2002, Ms. Bush, now 26, the daughter of Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, was charged with prescription fraud after she posed as a doctor to fill an order for an anti-anxiety medicine. Her case was referred to a drug court, and the judge supervising her treatment program dismissed the charge last August.
In New York State, as in other places, drug courts emerged over the objections of many jurists who saw them as a form of social work, an inappropriate departure from the business of interpreting the law and deciding punishments. 
"I was a skeptic," Joseph J. Traficanti Jr., a New York deputy chief administrative judge and the current director of the state's 106 drug courts, said in an interview on Friday. Judge Traficanti, a prosecutor in the 1960's and 70's, said his philosophy for fighting drugs was, "Lock them all up and solve the problem."
"Of course, that didn't work," he said.
Judge Traficanti said he changed his mind in 1997, when he traveled to Rochester to observe Judge Schwartz's "graduation" of drug-court participants. "I couldn't really believe my ears and eyes," Judge Traficanti recalled. "These tough street people got up one after another and said, 'Judge Schwartz, thank you for saving my life.' "
In its study, the Center for Court Innovation also notes the limitations of the impact of drug courts on participants, who are, according to statistics, as likely to fail to finish their treatment as they are to complete it. 
Offenders who enter drug court but fail to complete their treatment, in fact, are often more likely to commit new crimes than offenders charged with similar crimes who never participated, the study found.
In drug courts, prosecutors put aside the usual adversarial approach to defense lawyers and their clients and, instead, everyone works with the judge to foster compliance. But as the New York study shows, each court's rules and requirements for admitting participants vary almost as widely as do their rates of success. 
Their individual rules may cause the disparity. Many drug-court jurists, like Judge Leach in Queens, use a system of encouragement -- a round of applause, for instance, for a clean urine test -- and punishments that increase in severity with each misstep. Most of his clients, as he calls them, are unemployed; most are charged with cocaine-related crimes; and most, he said, are addicted to marijuana. 
Judge Leach's approach, like many drug court jurists', is to be strict but encouraging. "You end up establishing a relationship when you see a defendant once a week," he said. 
So when, say, an offender fails a drug test, Judge Leach may express his displeasure and demand that the person compose an essay explaining his decision andways to avoid making another bad one. If a participant seems blase about his treatment, the judge might force him to spend the day in the "penalty box" -- the jury box -- where he can witness drug court failures being handcuffed and led straight to jail.
At the center of the drug courts' success, judges say, are the participants who turn their lives around.
"When you see a parent get his case dismissed, with his children in the courtroom, or a wife with tears in her eyes, it really is a rich, rewarding thing to see," Judge Leach said in an interview. "Because they can actually see a light."

HEADLINE: North Korea's Bomb: Untested but Ready, C.I.A. Concludes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency has told Congress that it now believes that North Korea has mastered the technology of turning its nuclear fuel into functioning weapons, without having to prove their effectiveness through nuclear tests.
 The C.I.A. report goes beyond previous public statements suggesting that North Korea built one or two weapons in the early 1990's, a figure many intelligence experts believe has risen in the last few months. Those statements carried the presumption that the North had developed the technology to detonate weapons, but in background briefings, some American and Asian intelligence officials expressed doubts. They said that in the absence of a North Korean nuclear test, there was no way to be certain of its capabilities. 
 Now those doubts appear to be gone. But the reason why is still a mystery, perhaps buried in a classified annex that the C.I.A. also sent to Congress. 
The C.I.A.'s notification to Congress, sent in mid-August, reports that while North Korea could conduct such a test, it was probably refraining from doing so to avoid "precipitating an international backlash and further isolation." For the first time, the agency has publicly stated that the North's technology is advanced enough that a highly visible test -- like those conducted in China in the mid-1960's and in India and Pakistan in the 1990's -- is unnecessary.
The agency's new assessment, first reported by Reuters, came in a series of written, unclassified responses to questions posed by members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.
The conclusion, if accurate, would give credence to recent statements by North Korean officials that they already possessed a working "nuclear deterrent," and to their assertion that it was too late for the Bush administration to stop it from becoming a full-fledged nuclear power.
The C.I.A.'s judgment complicates the diplomatic task facing President Bush as the United States moves toward another round of six-nation talks with the North, probably next month. Mr. Bush, who declared this year that he would never tolerate a nuclear North Korea, has said the United States is prepared to offer, with other nations, some form of security guarantees to the North in return for its agreement to disarm.
But even if the North agrees, defining "disarmament" may be very difficult. American intelligence officials acknowledge that they do not know exactly how much weapons-grade fuel North Korea has produced this year, since international inspectors were expelled on Dec. 31. 
One senior official said on Saturday that the significance of the C.I.A.'s conclusion was that "we may never know for sure how many weapons they manufactured and then hid away in some tunnel." Even if North Korea agrees to give up both its production facilities and the weapons it has already produced, a step many Korea experts in the administration believe is unlikely, "how would we ever know that we've gotten all of it?" the official asked.
The C.I.A. report was in reply to questions posed by senators in the spring. The answers were submitted on Aug. 18, but were not made public until recently. They are written in the arcane language of nuclear intelligence.
"We assess that North Korea has produced one or two simple fission-type nuclear weapons and has validated the designs without conducting yield-producing nuclear tests," the report to the committee said. The agency appeared to be referring to the kind of basic bomb containing plutonium extracted from North Korea's nuclear power reactors, not to warheads made from highly enriched uranium.
The agency noted news reports that the North had conducted "high-explosive tests since the 1980's in order to validate its nuclear weapons design(s)." Those tests, it suggested, made it unnecessary to stage a full nuclear explosion to be confident that the designs would work.
The full document, and another assessment by the Defense Intelligence Agency, were posted on the web site of the Federation of American Scientists (www.fas.org), an independent group that analyzes arms control and other issues. The D.I.A. report also concludes that Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, appears to have a "secure" hold on power.
It concludes that the chances for the reunification of the Korean peninsula, divided since the Korean War ended a half century ago, are "low" in the next five years, and that if Mr. Kim were displaced, he would probably be replaced by a military official.
The conclusions give little cause for optimism among those in the Bush administration who hope -- as the Clinton administration did -- that the government would collapse because of North Korea's deep economic troubles.
On July 1, a month and a half before the report to the Senate, The New York Times reported that American satellites had been studying an advanced nuclear testing site in an area called Youngdoktong, and that the C.I.A. had told allies it believed that the North was working on designs there that would produce a compact nuclear warhead that could fit onto a missile. Since then, a number of officials have said they believe that there is a weapons laboratory adjacent to that facility; it may be there that much of the work the C.I.A. described has been conducted.
The unclassified version of the statements sent to the Senate make no reference to the size of the nuclear weapons that the North can now produce, or whether they could be fitted onto its missiles, including those that can reach Japan and beyond. Nor does it disclose which nations may have helped the North.
Decades ago, the country received early aid on its nuclear program from China, which is now working with the Bush administration to prevent North Korea from going nuclear. Several years ago it reached a deal with Pakistan that swapped North Korean missile technology for Pakistani nuclear aid; many experts believe that it was the Pakistani connection that allowed North Korea to make the final leap.
Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, has denied that his country is currently helping North Korea, but he has been vague when asked about any past assistance. He repeated those denials last week.
Pakistan's aid was chiefly related to a second, secret nuclear project in North Korea, involving the production of highly enriched uranium, which intelligence agencies concluded probably had not yet produced a weapon.
It is unclear if Pakistan or other nations have given recent help to the older North Korean project, which involves producing weapons from spent nuclear fuel.
Pakistan and India each conducted nuclear tests in 1998, and the United States responded by imposing sanctions on both. It removed them later, in Pakistan's case after it offered help after the Sept. 11 attacks.

HEADLINE: Bayonne Is Proud Of Golf Course Plan 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Although we in Bayonne always welcome the occasion to tell the rest of the world about our wonderful city, we take issue with "The View's Great, But the Course Is a Real Dump" (front page, Oct. 26).
 Your premise that most people associate Bayonne with "pizza," "tanker" and "landfill" is stereotypical and myopic. We Bayonnites can indeed boast of the best pizza in New Jersey, but ours is a vital, growing community. In fact, New Jersey Monthly magazine called Bayonne one of the best cities in the state in which to reside, ranking it No.1 in public safety and in the quality of its schools. 
 Moreover, while Bayonne would have greatly preferred to have a public golf course built here, this was simply not practical. The nonprofit National Golf Foundation, which we engaged to study the feasibility of a public course as opposed to a private one, concluded that it would have been economically suicidal for Bayonne to get into the golf course business. And it would be difficult for me to justify the construction of a golf course using public funds when we are fighting to maintain our high level of police and fire protection and other city services.
In a hard year of bargaining with Empire Golf, we won concessions -- beyond those that you mention -- that will allow Bayonne residents to play 1,000 discounted rounds at the four other Empire Golf courses in New Jersey and have unfettered access to the course here a half-day a week during maintenance time. This is of no small consequence because even as you depict Bayonne as a "blue-collar port city," thousands of golfers reside here who will take advantage of these opportunities.
Finally, the quotation that golf courses are among "the biggest wastes of prime real estate" belies what you set out earlier in the piece: that the course is being built on a defunct garbage dump. You neglect to say that part of the site was owned by Public Service, which planned to build a nuclear power plant there in the 1970's. I don't know about you, but the citizens of Bayonne and I will take a golf course over a garbage dump or nuclear plant any day of the week.

Mayor Joseph V. Doria Jr.
Bayonne
