HEADLINE: For Gephardt, Congress Role Is Both Platform and Hurdle 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
His wife of 37 years, Jane Gephardt, did not really want him to make another race for the presidency, and much of the conventional wisdom argued against it.
 This was not the political year, many of the pundits said, for a consummate insiderlike Representative Richard A. Gephardt, inextricably linked with every Democratic compromise, victory and defeat on Capitol Hill for the last 20 years. Indeed, to some Democrats Mr. Gephardt's support of President Bush on the war with Iraq seemed an example of all that was wrong with the party establishment. 
 But Mr. Gephardt, a 62-year-old Missourian, decided to run anyway. To him the question was different: How could he not? He has worked under five presidents, "and I just know I can do this," he said. "And I know I can do it better than the present occupant." 
The time is right for his economic message, he argues, and for a revival of the great Democratic cause of universal health insurance. And after the experience of his 1988 presidential campaign, he knows the challenges and the rhythms of the race, "the ebbs and flows of the thing," that "people go up, people go down." 
Dick Gephardt wants to do it right this time. It is, in many ways, one last chance for political vindication -- of his career, of the Congressional wing of the party, of a set of beliefs. At 7 a.m. in Florence, S.C., or 8 p.m. in Clinton, Iowa, he delivers his basic stump speech with the same urgency. "My name is Dick Gephardt, I'm going to win the Democratic nomination, and I'm going to beat George Bush in November," he says. "Everything we care about is vanishing before our eyes."
He has already lived through too many missed opportunities -- for himself, the party and the country, he suggests. His 1988 presidential campaign famously faltered when he ran out of money on the eve of Super Tuesday, a round of critical Southern primaries. He chose not to run in 1992, which turned out to be a Democratic year. Instead, he led House Democrats through the brutal and sometimes fruitless legislative struggles of the 1990's, a history that he now angrily defends against the sweeping dismissals of other candidates, like the "outsider" Howard Dean. 
"I don't mind him congratulating himself for what he's done," Mr. Gephardt says coldly, "but don't say we're all laggards and have done nothing, because it's just not true."
He had to hand over the speaker's gavel to Newt Gingrich in 1995, after Democrats lost the majority for the first time in 40 years, and he led the even more bruising political battle to try to win it back, four elections in a row, falling short each time. He is, in short, the paradigmatic Congressional Democrat -- too tactical and attuned to the polls, critics say, but battle-tested by a generation of partisan combat and hungry for one more race.
He has suffered setbacks in recent days. He had hoped for solid backing from organized labor, after years of loyal advocacy for the unions on trade and other issues. But while the industrial unions are, in general, rallying to his side, two of the most politically potent ones -- the Service Employees International Union and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees -- have endorsed Dr. Dean.
Moreover, Dr. Dean's decision to opt out of the public financing system means he can exploit his formidable financial advantage against Democratic rivals in states with early caucuses and primaries like Iowa and New Hampshire. Still, the Gephardt camp has been cheered by a recent poll showing Mr. Gephardt holding his own in Iowa, a must-win state for him that could position him as a leading Dean alternative.
If he fails, Mr. Gephardt says, it is almost certainly his last campaign. If he wins, he knows what he wants to do and how to do it.
"I spent a lot of time with Clinton and a lot of time with this president, especially after 9/11, when we met almost every week," he said one night in Iowa, driving back to Des Moines, reflecting on the difference between Gephardt '88 and Gephardt '04. "I feel more confident that I could walk into that office tomorrow and do a good job. I've seen what it takes to be president, what it's like to go through it day by day -- the pressures, the travel, the decisions, the whole thing."
Even in an era when outsider insurgencies are running strong -- Howard Dean, Arnold Schwarzenegger -- experience has to matter to voters in the end, Mr. Gephardt argues. 
So he persuaded his wife that, as he put it, "we couldn't just wave this guy through for another four years." He held a conference with his three grown children and found them far more enthusiastic about this race than they had been about the last, when he had moved the family to Iowa to campaign. 
He sat down with his daughter Chrissy, who recently came out as a lesbian, and her partner, and told them, "This is all going to come out, and if this is a problem and you don't want me to do it, I'm not going to do it." They told him to push ahead.
And he called the sprawling community of his former staff together and heard them out on the pros and cons. 
"At the end, Dick thanked us all, said that you all are the best friends I have ever had, and he broke down," said Donna Brazile, who worked for his 1988 campaign, and managed the Gore-Lieberman campaign in 2000. "I broke down, too." 
Much of the old crowd has returned for this campaign, including Steve Murphy, who ran Iowa for him in 1988 and is now his campaign manager, and Bill Carrick, his media consultant.

Inhaled Only the Heartland Air
This is his 18th campaign. The son of a milk-truck driver and a secretary, he is a lifelong politician, elected to the St. Louis Board of Aldermen at the age of 30 and to the House at 35. He is a famous straight arrow -- Baptist, Eagle Scout, scholarship student. He spent six years in the Missouri Air National Guard. The counterculture passed him by.
When past drug use became an issue among the baby-boomer Democratic candidates in November 1987, Ms. Brazile was sent to quiz Mr. Gephardt about his own. She asked if he had ever smoked reefer. He looked at her blankly. 
"Reefer?"
He went to Congress in 1976 as an anti-abortion, anti-mandatory-busing, relatively conservative Democrat whose political philosophy mirrored attitudes in the working-class district that elected him. But issue by issue, as he moved up in the Congressional leadership and on toward a presidential campaign, he became more liberal, more of a national Democrat.
That metamorphosis haunted his 1988 campaign. He was easy to mock as a shape-shifting careerist who changed his beliefs to improve his chances for the nomination; his opponents ran hundreds of commercials ridiculing his "flip-flops" on the issues, in one advertisement using an acrobat to execute flips. Then as now -- current detractors cite his role in brokering President Bush's Iraq war resolution -- his strength is his weakness: He is deeply political.
Critics of the 1988 primary campaign asserted that even over its narrow course, Mr. Gephardt moved seamlessly from one consultant-shaped message to another. The New Republic suggested that only a body-snatching by aliens could explain "the fact that Gephardt, who until a few months ago was a sort of neoconservative neoliberal, has suddenly begun talking, in his slow, robotic voice, like a devotee of the cult of Populism."
No group was more aggrieved than the anti-abortion movement. Even today, Douglas Johnson, legislative director of the National Right to Life Committee, says that Mr. Gephardt's shift to support of abortion rights 17 years ago "suggests that he will abandon what he professes to be deeply held views on a fundamental ethical issue for political expediency."
Mr. Gephardt responds a little wearily. "Every one of us evolves, changes, because conditions change, and issues change," he said. "You learn as you go. You are affected by what you learn, and you are affected by what you hear.
"Yes, I changed my view on abortion. I grew up in a Baptist household, I was taught certain things, I came to Congress with those beliefs. But I listened to members of my family, I listened to women, I listened to lots of people and came to a different view."
Yet even though Mr. Gephardt's voting record has remained fairly consistent in recent years, the accusation that he lacks a core lingers among his critics. It may be, some colleagues say, an inevitable result of a career spent in Congressional leadership, trying to find common ground in the ideologically sprawling Democratic caucus. 
History suggests that legislative leaders become, in a way, their party's sin eaters, too loaded up with baggage and compromise for the message-driven simplicity of a modern presidential campaign. Senator Bob Dole ran into this problem when he ran in 1988 and 1996; Mr. Gephardt faces it now. Howard Dean's trademark refrain -- "I'm from the Democratic wing of the Democratic Party" -- is squarely aimed at the Congressional candidates, like Mr. Gephardt, the inference being that they give too much, cooperate too much, fight too little.
So Mr. Gephardt is trying to reclaim -- and ennoble -- his history.
On the campaign trail he talks about the 1993 deficit reduction plan, pushed through by him and other Congressional Democrats without a single Republican vote, as a moment of great pride and high drama, when lawmakers took a stand that cost some their political careers. He has attacked Dr. Dean as not standing with the Democrats in the great budget battle of 1995-96, when Republicans sought to extract $270 billion from Medicare. Dr. Dean was governor of Vermont and chairman of the National Governors Association.

Personal History in Public Policy
Flying over South Carolina on a campaign trip this fall, Mr. Gephardt said, somewhat ruefully, that it sometimes seemed as if the great battles of the 1990's had been forgotten, "like Greek and Roman history." Yet he also reflected that when Democrats had the majority, "we didn't value it enough, we didn't do enough, to get things done and unify our party."
So Mr. Gephardt is also trying to transcend his legislative past. He says he wants to show the roots of his political philosophy and policy proposals. To put some big ideas out there, and explain why they matter -- to him, and to average working Americans.
He began his campaign with a comprehensive plan for universal health insurance, one that went back and tried to fix the problems so politically deadly to the Clinton plan (although critics say he does so by proposing to spend an unrealistic sum).
"I wrote this plan," he recently told an audience from the United Food and Commercial Workers union in Davenport, Iowa. "It comes from my head and my heart."
To prove that, Mr. Gephardt invariably tells audiences the story of his son, Matt, who was found to have cancer at 18 months old and was expected to live only a few months longer. The doctors found an experimental treatment that looked promising, and equally important in the American health care system, the Gephardts learned that their insurance would cover it.
"We lived in the hospital for five years," Mr. Gephardt said. "Today, he's 32 years old. He's married. He's a gift of God."
"There's nothing you can tell me about this," Mr. Gephardt tells his listeners, who are utterly quiet by the end. "I get it."
In Davenport, and elsewhere when he tells the story of Matt, Jane Gephardt struggles with tears as she listens. "It brings up a lot of very, very painful memories, and it's not easy," she said later in an interview. But she said she understood the necessity of this kind of campaigning. "People need to know what Dick really is. He's been criticized as bland and stiff and a Washington politician, and he's not that at all."
Mr. Gephardt's economic message is also framed in personal terms: his father eking his way into the middle class with a union driver's job; his mother making her way through a series of secretarial jobs that left her with a $42-a-month pension; the help he got along the way; the college loans he is still paying off for his daughter Kate. (Mr. Gephardt remains a man of comparatively modest means, after educating three children on his salary and that of his wife, an administrator for a pediatric practice.)
"My philosophy is different from W's," he says in his basic stump speech. "We're all interconnected, dependent on one another. I would not have accomplished what I've accomplished without a lot of help."
Much of the energy at his events comes from union members, who show up in their union T-shirts, ask hard-nosed questions about trade and job loss and know they will get the answers they want. Mr. Gephardt, a leader in the unsuccessful fight to block Nafta, argues that time has vindicated his position on the toll of globalization and some trade agreements, on the need to secure greater protections for workers here and abroad. He scoffs at some of his Democratic rivals as Johnny-come-latelies on the trade issue and its impact on manufacturing jobs.
He has steadily acquired the endorsements of labor unions, more than any other candidate, although not enough to get the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s umbrella endorsement.

On Iraq, Out on a Cracking Limb
Mr. Gephardt's roughest moments on the campaign trail come around his support for the war with Iraq; he helped broker the resolution authorizing Mr. Bush to use force. It is, for his critics in this campaign, the heart of the case against Dick Gephardt. Again, it comes down to the charge of being too political: being too acquiescent toward a popular president heading into the 2002 elections, too careful about his own political exposure as he moved toward 2004.
From the very beginning, his position was problematic. He returned to Capitol Hill from a Rose Garden news conference with the president in early October of last year, and met with House Democrats in caucus. "I got some real heat," he acknowledged.
Saying he told Democrats to vote their conscience, he added, "I don't need lectures about why I was wrong, or that my motives were wrong." 
His decision, he explained, was an outgrowth of meetings with many intelligence and foreign policy experts, in the Bush and Clinton administrations. And his goal was to influence the president, to push him toward closer cooperation with the allies and the United Nations.
In the end, the caucus voted overwhelmingly against Mr. Gephardt's position -- 126 to 81. One of those antiwar Democrats, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, is now running against Mr. Gephardt and has used the debates to mount some of the most scathing attacks against him.
Mr. Kucinich said at the debate in Baltimore, "Dick, I just want to say that when you were standing there in the Rose Garden with the president and you were giving him advice, I wish that you would have told him 'No!' " 
Campaigning, Mr. Gephardt is asked regularly about the vote, usually by a disappointed Democrat. He answers the question, patiently, as if it were the first time.
He is, by all accounts, superbly disciplined. In a small plane buffeted by turbulence over the humid skies of South Carolina, he was the only one who did not blanch. He kept focused on his interview. He answered the next question.
David Dreyer, who worked for Mr. Gephardt from 1989 to 1993 and is now a corporate communications consultant, said of Mr. Gephardt: "Say what you will about Dick -- he's 'too old,' 'too Washington' -- but he does know how to do this. He knows how to run a long campaign. He knows that what he says today could come back and haunt him tomorrow. When he wakes up in a hotel room in the morning, he knows where he is. He knows who he's supposed to call."
Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and a supporter, says: "If you want to know when Dick is angry, it's when he stops talking. It's a cold heat."
Whatever his hopes for influencing Mr. Bush on Iraq, Mr. Gephardt is now contemptuous of him. After the terrorist attacks of 2001, when Mr. Gephardt was still the minority leader, the two men met regularly.
"I've watched him up close and he's not a bad person, he's a fine person, but he's not doing the job," Mr. Gephardt said. "In some ways, he's inexperienced. In other ways, he's unknowledgeable. In other ways, he's rigid and unwilling to change policies that I think just obviously need to be changed."
Like a budget laden with tax cuts, Mr. Gephardt said, a budget that now faces huge deficits.
When he seeks advice on the economic front, Mr. Gephardt said, he talks with several Clinton-era officials, like Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary; Leon E. Panetta, the former White House chief of staff; and Gene Sperling, the former chief White House economic adviser. He also talks to economists like James K. Galbraith, Barry Bluestone and Harley Shaiken.
On foreign policy, he talks to Clinton veterans like Richard Holbrooke, former ambassador to the United Nations, and Madeleine K. Albright, former secretary of state, as well as a longtime foreign policy aide, Brett O'Brien.
At times, all the frustration of the Congressional wing of the Democratic Party comes bubbling out of Mr. Gephardt. He has witnessed everything -- from the Reagan revolution to the government shutdown to the impeachment of a president.
With so much history, he simply could not walk away from one more race -- even if the spirit of the times has seemed against him in recent months. Supporters like Mr. Obey express outrage at the idea that somehow, by the rules of presidential politics, it would be better if Mr. Gephardt had not been involved in the last 20 years of Democratic struggle.
"Every day -- every day! -- he was the point man," Mr. Obey said. "He's been slogging for rational policy and progressive values every minute he's spent in this puzzle factory."
So he runs. He had difficulty earlier this year meeting fund-raising goals, and he faces an extraordinary challenge from Dr. Dean in Iowa. Still, Mr. Gephardt seems at ease on the campaign trail compared to the last time. Donna Brazile remembers she told him: "This is your last shot. If you're going to go for it, remember this is it." 
He is at peace in battle.

Challenging Bush
This is the first in a series of articles examining the lives and careers of the candidates seeking the Democratic presidential nomination. In addition, an audio slide show narrated by Robin Toner can be found online at nytimes.com/campaigns.

HEADLINE: Bush's Allies Plan to Block Effort to Ease Ban on Cuban Travel 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
President Bush's allies in Congress quietly eliminated a widely supported provision easing restrictions on American travel to Cuba from a major appropriations bill to save him from embarrassment over his political designs in Florida, officials from both parties said Wednesday evening.
 Leaders of a House-Senate conference committee removed the provision on Wednesday before the bill reached the president, who had threatened to veto any legislation that lifted sanctions against Cuba, the officials said. 
 "You're not going to put a bill on the floor that potentially embarrasses the president," said a senior Republican staff member. Referring to the Cuba provision's bipartisan supporters, he added, "I'm sure there will be some gnashing of teeth." 
The provision, which would bar Treasury Department authorities from enforcing a ban on travel to the island, was approved by the House in September 227 to 188, and by the Senate last month 59 to 38. Last week, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13 to 5 to scrap the ban outright.
Since the language of the Cuban travel provision approved by the House and Senate was identical, it would not ordinarily have been subject to action by the conference committee, which sought to reconcile differences in bills that finance the Treasury and Transportation departments, advocates say. But Republican committee leaders, including Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska and Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, were determined to remove the Cuba measure, aides said.
The legislation might have drawn Mr. Bush's first veto, and risked derailing important appropriations for highway construction, Amtrak, election reform and other programs.
Some Congressional officials said they were appalled that the will of Congress could be thwarted in the back-room negotiations that drive conference committees. Republican leaders have removed Cuba-related language at the same juncture in previous years, though never against such an overwhelming mandate from their colleagues.
"The fact that it could be undermined is mind-blowing, and more reminiscent of the Politburo than Congress," said Steven C. Schwadron, the chief of staff of Representative Bill Delahunt, a Massachusetts Democrat, who has been a driving force behind lifting the travel ban. "It suggests that a handful of people can vaporize the will of the majority."
Some conservatives were troubled as well. Steven Johnson, an analyst at the Heritage Foundation, said the administration was missing an opportunity to fine-tune tough sanctions that have failed to bring change in Cuba. "The administration takes a hard line meant to please a certain crowd in Miami," he said.
The president's political strategists attach huge importance to Florida, which was crucial to Mr. Bush's narrow victory over Al Gore in 2000. The state's 833,000 Cuban-Americans were especially loyal to Mr. Bush, with about 80 percent of them voting for him.
"Cubans believe their vote determined the last president of the United States," said Lisandro Perez, a Miami sociologist. "People in Miami are pretty confident that Bush won't let anything past him on this."
In August, 13 Republican state legislators, including 10 Cuban-Americans, warned the president that Cuban-Americans would rethink their support of Mr. Bush unless the Justice Department indicted Mr. Castro and took other hard-line steps.

HEADLINE: Economist Pleads Guilty in 30-Year BondTrades 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
John M. Youngdahl, a former senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal charges in connection with the purchase of millions of dollars of 30-year bonds and bond futures minutes ahead of the Treasury Department's announcement in 2001 that it was ending the sale of such bonds.
 Mr. Youngdahl, who appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan, also settled a separate insider trading case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. neither admitting nor denying any wrongdoing in that case. 
 If approved by the court, Mr. Youngdahl would pay a civil penalty of $240,000 to the S.E.C. Under the plea bargain on the criminal charges, which included insider trading, theft of government property, wire fraud and conspiracy, he faces 33 months to 41 months in prison. 
Mr. Youngdahl received advance notice of the Treasury's decision to halt sales of the 30-year bond on Oct. 31, 2001, from Peter J. Davis, a Washington consultant. Mr. Davis regularly attended press briefings on the government's quarterly auctions of notes and bonds, although he was not a reporter.
The information from these Treasury briefings is embargoed until the Treasury makes its announcement public. But according to the original indictment, Mr. Davis had been giving his clients information from the briefings during such restricted periods since about 1999.
In the announcement of the plea bargain, James B. Comey, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said that Mr. Youngdahl and Mr. Davis had agreed before the Oct. 31 briefing that Mr. Davis would call Mr. Youngdahl before the embargo was lifted. 
The call came at 9:35 a.m., well ahead of the scheduled 10 a.m. Treasury announcement. Mr. Youngdahl, who along with other Wall Street analysts was not expecting the Treasury to end 30-year bond sales, told a Goldman senior bond trader, "I wouldn't be short bonds if I were you." In Wall Street language, that was an instruction to buy 30-year bonds right away.
Over the next eight minutes, Goldman traders bought almost $318 million worth of 30-year bonds and bond futures, according to the government filings. Goldman began selling its positions, which resulted in a profit of $3.8 million, at 9:51 a.m. At 9:43, the Treasury confused the situation by inadvertently announcing the end of 30-yearsales on its Web site 17 minutes early. The announcement set off one of the biggest one-day gains ever in 30-year bond prices. 
In September, Mr. Davis pleaded guilty to felony charges of insider trading, theft of government property and conspiracy. He also settled civil fraud charges with the S.E.C. without admitting or denying wrongdoing.
Goldman also settled with the S.E.C. Without admitting or denying the accusations, it agreed to pay back the $3.8 million in profit, as well as $500,000 in interest and a $5 million penalty. 
In court yesterday, Mr. Youngdahl, 44, told Judge Denise L. Cote that "I expected that Goldman would profit from having this information, and that this would ultimately benefit me as a member of Goldman," according to Bloomberg News.
"There was an annual bonus procedure," he added, "and it was my expectation that the bonus could be enhanced." 
In a statement released by his lawyer, Alan Levine of Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman, Mr. Youngdahl, of Summit, N.J., said: "Over the past two years, I have engaged in serious errors of judgment and lapses of integrity. I know these personal failings have inflicted unwarranted pain on my family, my friends and many of my former colleagues." 
"It is my sincere hope that those I have hurt will see in my plea of guilty an expression of my deep regret for the pain I have caused and an acceptance of responsibility for my misdeeds," the statement concluded.
Mr. Youngdahl also admitted in court that he lied to federal agents to obstruct the investigation and gave perjured testimony to the S.E.C., though he did not face those charges under the plea bargain.
In a related announcement that came as a surprise, the S.E.C. said it was dismissing its civil fraud case against Steven E. Nothern, a portfolio manager at MFS Investment Management, a mutual fund company in Boston. The S.E.C. statement said the commission retained the right to bring the case again. 
Mr. Nothern, who left MFS more than a year and a half ago and was contesting the accusations, also received a tip on the elimination of the 30-year bond from Mr. Davis, and together with three other portfolio managers bought a total of $65 million in 30-year bonds for MFS funds. Their profit was $3.1 million, according to the S.E.C.
Stephen J. Crimmins, a partner at Pepper Hamilton in Washington and a former deputy chief litigation counsel at the S.E.C., said, "This action by the S.E.C. suggests that they are thinking about adding defendants and they would want to have all the defendants in the same lawsuit."
MFS consented to an S.E.C. censure and agreed to pay a $200,000 penalty and $717,858 to cover the losses of a bond dealer who sold bonds to the MFS after the tip to Mr. Nothern.
Stephen M. Cutler, director of the S.E.C. enforcement division, said the civil action against Mr. Youngdahl sent a clear message. "If we catch you trafficking in or trading on confidential information that could affect the market for any security," he said, "you will pay a substantial price. This is true whether the securities are stocks or bonds, and it's true whether the securities are issued by the federal government or by a public company."

HEADLINE: GREEN VS. GREENBACKS; 
A Shrewd Eye for the Wash Cycle

BYLINE:  By LISA GUERNSEY

 BODY:
CARROLL LANCASTER, a 74-year-old Texan with the drawl to prove it, is all for saving Mother Earth. So when he and his wife, Catherine, built their retirement home a few years ago near Zephyr, Tex., they bought a front-loading washing machine, which uses less water and energy than a regular model; installed compact fluorescent lighting, which consumes less electricity than incandescent lamps; designed a two-foot roof overhang, which provides shade in the sizzling summers; and paid for a heating and air-conditioning unit so energy efficient that their utility company gave them a rebate. 
 Yet there was a limit to Mr. Lancaster's environmental friendliness. In his research, he learned that one way to consume less electricity was to use double-paned windows sealed with argon gas. But he discovered that his savings would be so small that it would take 10 to 20 years to justify the purchase. "I didn't think I would live that long," said Mr. Lancaster, who decided to use plastic double-paned windows -- without the argon. 
 In the past few years, the popularity of green buildings has expanded beyond die-hard do-gooders. (An exhibition titled "Big and Green: Toward Sustainable Architecture in the 21st Century" opened last month at the Museum of the City of New York.) Even builders are pledging to design environmentally responsible homes under a program called Energy Star, which is administered by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Department of Energy. 
The E.P.A. says that 20 percent of homes built next year in Florida, California and parts of the Southwest will earn the Energy Star label, meaning they are at the top of their class for energy efficiency. As earth-friendly labels become more common, consumers like Mr. Lancaster have more questions. If misused, do some energy-efficient appliances consume more electricity than conventional ones? Could changing habits be as effective as changing dishwashers? 
The answer depends on regional electric costs, climate, a home's age, the vintage of its appliances and whether the house is occupied by a family of six or a workaholic bachelor who is never home. 
Still, there are a few good rules of thumb. Buying an energy-conserving new refrigerator-freezer like the Sun Frost RF16, which has two separate cooling compartments and no fan, will lead to more savings than installing solar cells to generate electricity because an investment in solar cells takes decades to recoup, but the cost of a new refrigerator can be recovered in a few years. Not surprisingly, those who live in New York and California, where energy costs are high, will always save more with energy-efficient products. Most importantly, when consumers buy something labeled green or energy efficient, they have not necessarily helped their pocketbook or the planet.
"Nothing is as important as occupant behavior," said Ken Sheinkopf, a spokesman for the Florida Solar Energy Center, a research institute. "Depending on the way you use the appliances, the cooling system and the lights, you are going to be the final determinant on whether you save energy or waste it."
Mr. Sheinkopf, for example, is on a mission to re-educate people about ceiling fans. Rather than replacing an air-conditioner with a ceiling fan, many people use both. They assume that when the fan is on the air-conditioner's automatic thermostat will adjust, reducing its output. Not so, he said; the air-conditioner will not be able to tell that the room feels cooler. "This is a very major problem in trying to save energy," he said.
Or consider refrigerators. No one disputes that if your refrigerator is more than 20 years old, a new one will be better for your wallet and the environment. According to government statistics, a typical 2003 refrigerator uses about 500 kilowatt-hours of electricity per year, while a 1972 model consumes more than 2,500. At New York City's average price of 21 cents a kilowatt-hour, the newer version saves more than $420 a year. 
But if people "buy an Energy Star fridge, but then move their old fridge into the garage to keep a couple of six-packs cold, they aren't saving anything," said Jennifer Thorne, a research associate with the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy, which has published a guidebook on home energy savings. "They are continuing to run an energy hog that is very inefficient."
Those who laud themselves for buying an energy-efficient washer like the 12-cycle Whirlpool Duet ($1,300), which uses 67 percent less electricity than a standard machine, or a dishwasher like the Double Dish Drawer ($1,600) from Fisher & Paykel, which uses less water because one drawer can be used at a time, may want to hold their applause. Someone who buys a Duet or Fisher & Paykel's Ecosmart washing machine and then runs it to wash a pair of socks is wasting water -- and energy. And today's dishwashers require no prerinsing, according to Consumer Reports, which has tested plates coated with, for example, congealed spinach. "If you buy an energy-efficient dishwasher but prerinse your dishes, you are throwing all those energy savings out the window," said Mark Connelly, the director of appliances and home improvement for Consumer Reports. 
Some products are simply more cost-effective than others. Insulation will quickly pay for itself if installed correctly because it immediately reduces the workload for heaters and air-conditioners. Sealing drafty gaps around windows and doors is also a smart and cheap way to cut back on heating and air-conditioning bills. 
Earning a quick payback from more expensive products, like the high-efficiency windows that Mr. Lancaster passed on, can be more difficult. Photovoltaic cells that turn sunlight into energy are a pricey item, unless you live in a state that offers tax incentives and has a lot of sunshine, like California.
Then there are the hidden costs. James and Claudia Horn, architects in Santa Fe, N.M., are renovating their home using as many environmentally sensitive products as possible. They plan to install a cistern to collect rainwater and a gray-water system that irrigates their backyard with bath water. To do so they must buy the cistern and gray-water tanks, the pumps and the extra piping. Burying the cistern underground would add another cost. "In the long term, you do save money," Mr. Horn said. But he does not know how soon he will see those savings. 
Taking out the guesswork is a primary goal of Energy Star. Since its inception in 1992 as a program to label electricity-efficient office computers, it has grown to include products in 35 categories. Maria Vargas, an Energy Star spokeswoman, said that it focuses on products that pay for themselves in four to five years. "If you are in the market anyway, there is no reason not to buy Energy Star," Ms. Vargas said.
But the Energy Star logo is no guarantee of maximum savings. The program typically singles out products that exceed the federal efficiency standards by 10 to 20 percent, but those standards can be so lax that surpassing them is no great feat. Standards for air-conditioners, some environmentalists say, are not nearly strict enough. 
There are also problems with appliance testing that can skew results. The government's test for dishwashers measures water and energy output on dishes that were never dirty to begin with. When dishwasher manufacturers began adding "soil sensing" technology to their products, which adjusts the amount of hot water needed, environmentalists successfully argued that a more realistic test should be used. New standards will be in effect next year.
With all these complexities, wouldn't it be easier to save energy and money the way people did 50 years ago? Why not go back to living in smaller homes that require less energy to heat and cool, purchasing fewer and smaller appliances and going without digital clocks or timers and touch screens that soak up electricity even when the appliance is not in use? 
Nah. 
As long as consumers can find products that are both cost-effective and environmentally friendly, they will buy them, Ms. Vargas said. People want to reduce pollution without giving up quality or convenience -- while saving money. "This is having your cake," she said, "and eating it too."

A Penny-Wise Guide to 'Buttoning Up Your House'
THE first chapter of "Consumer Guide to Home Energy Savings," published last month, promises that it is possible to pay just $200 to $300 a year for energy bills. 
That may sound too good to be true, but the authors of the guide, Alex Wilson, Jennifer Thorne and John Morrill, insist it is a reasonable goal for those who own new homes built with the best insulation, tight windows and the right ventilation systems.
The chapter on "buttoning up your house" provides step-by-step instructions and advice about how to lower energy bills. Drafts can sneak in, even around recessed lighting; caulk gaps or seal them with foam. And check your heating and air-conditioning ducts: if you see dirt streaks near the seams, seal them with mastic tape not duct tape; it's thicker and can be made of rubber.) 
The guide, which is in its eighth edition, tries to go beyond the simple Energy Star ratings to determine the best products in each category, even for appliances like kitchen ranges and microwaves that are not required to have Energy Star labels. 
The book takes a jaundiced look at things like glass cooktops whose halogen elements have "instant heat" capabilities: "The improvements in heating speed do not generate enough energy savings to justify the higher cost of halogen cooktops," the guidebook says. 
Halogen torchier lamps used for just two hours a day consume as much as $18 worth of electricity a year. Because they are so common in dormitories, Ms. Thorne said, "these lamps were costing the colleges a fortune." 
The book can be ordered for $8.95, plus shipping costs, from the association's bookstore at www.aceee.org or by calling (202) 429-0063.
At the Energy Star Web site, www.energystar.gov, people can learn which appliances will work best for their homes. LISA GUERNSEY

GRAPHIC: Photo: DRAFT CONTROL -- Carroll and Catherine Lancaster chose regular, not argon-sealed, windows. (Photo by Gerald Ewing for The New York Times)(pg. F13) Drawings (Drawings by Richard Tuschman)(pg. F1); (pg. F13)

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: James Zemaitis; 
Blue-Chip Modern. It's So Fly.

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

 BODY:
DRESSED in a track-suit jacket, a skateboarding T-shirt and blue jeans, James Zemaitis, 35, looks like a fairly average young professional living on the Upper West Side. This, despite the fact that Mr. Zemaitis is the new director of 20th-century design for Sotheby's in New York, where even the publicists live in suits. 
 Mr. Zemaitis's first sales, on Dec. 11 and 12, will culminate in Lot 800 -- otherwise known as the Farnsworth House, designed by Mies van der Rohe and one of the most famous Modernist residences in the world. The presale estimate is $4.5 million to $6 million. The total estimate for the two days is $13.6 million to $18.9 million, the highest anywhere for 20th-century design. 
 "I'm the 'vibe' guy at Sotheby's in my department," Mr. Zemaitis said, with a kind of apoplectic pleasantness that is his trademark. He sat in his clinic-white apartment last week on a Grasshopper chair designed by Eero Saarinen in the 1940's. His bare feet were propped on the matching ottoman. 
The vibe for collecting modern design could not be more critical right now. Tastes are changing, and prices are reacting. Flagship venues like "Modernism," the four-day show at the Park Avenue Armory in New York, which opens today, will be viewed under a strong light. The audience is changing, too. Collectors and enthusiasts are competing with interior decorators and their clients, a well-moneyed contingent that is driving a demand for novelty before scholarship.
"It is a very interesting time indeed -- changes of strategy, new blood, quite a lot of musical chairs," said Nicola Redway, who became head of the 20th century department at Christie's America in February. "The market seems to be incredibly buoyant and hungry."
Mr. Zemaitis's design auctions at Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg in New York, from December 2000 to June 2003, brought wide notice in fashionable spheres, with their club-opening-style parties and sleek catalogs. "I put Dan Johnson on the cover because I just thought he was fly," Mr. Zemaitis said of his last sale at Phillips and the American midcentury designer whose chair graced the catalog's cover. 
It is a tactic Mr. Zemaitis brings with him. He said he believed a profile in House & Garden in May nailed the Sotheby's job. With their smart, graphic design, the December sale catalogs could be issues of a shelter magazine. 
Experts agree that a shakeout in modern design is under way, comparable to that in the area ofArts and Crafts in the late 1980's, when the truly exceptional parted company with the merely stylish. The giddiness and splash of the 1990's, when midcentury modern design looked newer to the dot.com generation than contemporary design did, has calmed. The popular designs, flushed out of every middle-American attic, basement or office, are widely available and being reissued.
Ray and Charles Eames, patron saints of 20th-century design whose every molded chair was treated as a holy relic four years ago, are mortals again. The bulk of their work is achieving newly sober sale prices as handsome furniture, not rarities. An early ESU-400 shelving unit, with its characteristic colorful panels, sold at Rago Modern Auctions in Lambertville, N.J., in October for $4,750, well below its $6,000 to $9,000 presale estimate. 
But the Eameses' contemporaries, Isamu Noguchi and George Nakashima, are ascending in value because of their attractive idiosyncrasies as artists or craftsmen. A Noguchi rocking stool, estimated at $10,000 to $12,000, sold at Phillips in June for $25,095.
Less-explored names like Alexandre Noll, a French sculptor and woodworker who died in 1970, are emerging rapidly, groomed for stardom. And designers working today like Marc Newson and Karim Rashid, whose designs are available new, are entering the market, at its invitation, and are eager for major collectors and museum recognition. Mr. Zemaitis pushed the approach at Phillips, to the point of commissioning new design for sale at auction. Testing the waters, Mr. Rashid, the creator of the Garbino trash can, has consigned a prototype of a chair designed in 1999 (it was never produced) to Sotheby's December sale; it is estimated to sell for $15,000 to $20,000.
Recent sales at auction houses specializing in modern design like Wright in Chicago and Rago Modern Auctions have shown sharply mixed results, especially for postwar design. Even the power of provenance at Wright's Sept. 14 sale from the Gabrielle and Michael Boyd collection made a poor showing: 20 percent went unsold, including the most expensive lots. Richard Wright, an owner, said it was his first auction in years to realize under $1 million.
The Boyds, who live in Santa Monica, Calif., in a house designed by Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect, are perhaps the most conspicuous of the modern-design collectors. Their collection was exhibited at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 1998. The Boyds, who also have a reputation as preservationists, bought and sold the architect Paul Rudolph's triplex in New York. But they have become increasingly controversial for entering the market repeatedly as sellers as well as buyers.
Several people in the field said that the Boyds had their eyes on the Farnsworth House, but Mr. Boyd said yesterday, after hesitating, that they were not going to bid. A consortium of preservationists is trying to protect the 1951 house on its site in Plano, Ill., by raising money to buy and maintain it as a property open to the public. By Tuesday, the group had received less than $4.5 million, the low estimate, in contributions.
Driven by optimism in the economy and a return of collectors' confidence in antiques, especially relatively low-priced modern designs, Sotheby's and Christie's are reassessing their positions on 20th-century decorative arts, and they have taken different tacks. Sotheby's has pushed less expensive pieces by Dan Johnson and T. H. Robsjohn-Gibbings into its important December sales, cheek by jowl with expensive pieces by Tiffany Studios and Frank Lloyd Wright. Its December sales bridge the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries, from the Scottish designer Dr. Christopher Dresser to Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec, the contemporary French designers. Christie's will sell postwar design in the fall and spring, but not as a part of its "Important 20th-Century Decorative Arts" sale on Dec. 9.
"The enduring core of the market is still prewar decorative arts," said Ms. Redway, who is including a significant portion of work by the Wiener Werkstatte, which is 100 years old this year, in her sale. She referred to the validation of less expensive objects by selling them next to more expensive ones as "mixing sows' ears with silk purses."
For the moment, Mr. Zemaitis, who got his start collecting beer-bottle caps when he was 5, is the center of attention, or at the center of the storm.
"I used to almost get run over, hit by cars, because I was always like jumping out in the street to get a smashed Michelob cap," he recalled. Mr. Zemaitis, an only child, grew up near Morristown, N.J.
Mr. Zemaitis now collects Russel Wright, modernist American salt and pepper shakers and Walter R. Brooks's Freddy the Pig books. Brooks, a short-story writer who published 26 titles between 1927 and 1958, was the creator of Mr. Ed, the talking horse.
Mr. Zemaitis's most aggressive move at Phillips, and at Sotheby's, was his decision to promote and sell work by young living designers, whose sales outlets typically have been retail design stores and contemporary design showrooms. You shop. You like it. You buy it. The imprimatur of importance is your own, not an international auction house's. 
Some of Mr. Zemaitis's designers, like Marc Newson, have a track record and are being actively collected. Some, like Mr. Rashid, do not. Mr. Zemaitis sees himself as an editor and a curator, as well as a specialist, and a retailer too. He takes as his model the contemporary art market, where material sold as new comes to auction more quickly.
"It's a blurring of the primary and secondary markets," Mr. Zemaitis said. "The most cutting-edge contemporary art market at auction has already blurred these boundaries. It has quickly become the spot where someone buys a Gursky photo from a dealer for $30,000 and flips it in an auction the next year for $100,000, because the artist is exceedingly hot."
New design keeps the excitement fresh, and also keeps new material on tap, as great midcentury material disappears into collections. Designers like Mr. Rashid, it would seem, are only too happy to cooperate.
"Karim is the designer who is looking for ways to expand his marketing vision, in every way, from mass market to high end," Mr. Zemaitis said. "I'm the businessman." 
Buyers who don't make it to Sotheby's can always hedge their bets at Bed Bath & Beyond, where this week Mr. Rashid's Garbino was still $4.99.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
For a Man in Pain, Progress Is a Wearable Pair of Shoes

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO

 BODY:
All his life, Frederick Hart, 46, has been trying to stand on his own two feet. The problem is his feet won't cooperate.
 "If had a wish, I would wish to have a doctor who could tell me what's wrong," said Mr. Hart, taking off his shoes in his landlord's living room to reveal a pair of clean but battered, misshapen feet. "I need somebody really special that can look at my feet and say, 'This is the problem.' Come on, half my life is gone." 
 Mr. Hart has had three operations to shave bone from his feet and place metal straightening pins and screws in his toes to ease the pain. He rests and prepares his "dogs" with creams for a fungus that afflicts the skin on his soles, and uses a razor blade to slice off the thick calluses and dead skin that keeps returning and turning his feet black.
The records from various doctors over the past 23 years are filled with mysterious-sounding medical terms: peripheral neuropathy, peripheral motor axonal polyneuropathy, xerosis and hammer toes. Peripheral neuropathy is a painful condition that causes a pins-and-needles sensation in the soles of the feet and the legs.
Mr. Hart said his father, a New York City police sergeant, and his uncle Herman Hart, a maintenance man, both complained of the same excruciating pain.
"We used to make fun of my uncle Herman because he would slide down the steps because his feet would hurt him so much," Mr. Hart said.
But long ago, Mr. Hart wished he could take back the laughter at his uncle's expense.
"He drank himself to death," he said.
Mr. Hart traces his own problems to his pain: his honorable discharge from the Marine Corps, his divorce, his problems keeping a job and his occasional homelessness. Mr. Hart says he does not want to end up like his uncle. He says he is scared to drink but sometimes he uses the morphine and hydrocontin his doctors prescribe for him.
Mr. Hart was discharged from the Marines after three months of pain.
"They were slicing the skin off and they would cut too deep and I'd see the blood and say, 'Look, I appreciate what you guys are trying to do, but just stop, I'll do it myself,' " Mr. Hart recalled, looking at his right big toe, which has no nail.
Ever since, he has been reluctant to entrust his aching dogs to anyone.
Mr. Hart has worked many jobs but themost money he has ever been able to make is $17,278, as a bus driver in 1999 for the New York City Transportation Authority. Often Mr. Hart says, he is fired for lateness on the days when the unbearable aching and sharp pains make him walk slower than his already deliberate strides.
Between jobs, Mr. Hart traveled to Washington, where he has family. He stayed in a homeless shelter, ashamed of having leaned on his family for help.
"It was like being in jail or something," Mr. Hart said of the shelter. "I'm not a person just out of jail. I'm not of the streets."
But a shelter visit led to one of his best stretches of work. In 1994 while staying at the CCNV Federal City Shelter in Washington, Mr. Hart entered a driver's training program and soon had a job with Fairfax Connector, a bus service. Initially Mr. Hart thought a driving job would mean less pressure on his feet. But pressing the brake and gas pedals caused intense pain, too.
Since that first job, Mr. Hart has worked for several bus lines. But for all that traveling, his anguish is never too far away. 
His operations, one in 1995 and two corrective operations in 2000 and 2001, have eased but not eliminated his pain. He has been largely unemployed since June 2001 and receives $126 in food stamps monthly. Public assistance pays $400 monthly rent for a room in his landlord's attic in Queens Village.
In February, Medicaid provided Mr. Hart with a pair of $400 podiatric orthotics, special inserts that cushion and give support to his feet. His doctor suggested that Rockport shoes would be the most comfortable shoes for him to put the orthotics in. They felt better than most shoes he had worn, but cost $100, money he did not have.
A friend suggested he call Catholic Charities, Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Catholic Charities secured $99 of Neediest Cases money for the shoes.
The orthotics and Rockports, while not relieving his pain completely, have made it bearable enough for him to go to Goodwill Industries in Long Island City, Queens, where he hopes to find a sitting job and enroll in computer classes.
But the shoe soles are getting very worn and his landlord has asked him to leave before Christmas.
He just wants relief as he tries to put one aching foot in front of the other.
"I want to be a human being," Mr. Hart said, pleading. "I'm ashamed. I never did something with my life. I haven't accomplished anything."

HEADLINE: At Play in Chinatown's Backyard; 
Eastern Chess Meets Western Basketball Under the Mulberries

BYLINE:  By ANDREA ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Blind Man Chin shuffles into Columbus Park in Chinatown, lifts his wooden chess set and shakes the pieces inside, sounding a crackle that scatters the pigeons. It is his invitation to play.
 Someone always accepts, rising from among the dozens of Chinese chess players to lead him to a picnic table and set up his board. Mr. Chin, 60, whose first name is Wing, plays from memory, shouting the moves he wants to make and listening to those called out by his opponent. He plays game after game until the sun sets over Lower Manhattan. Then he takes the train home to Brooklyn. 
 Benson Li, 19, enters his own piece of the park on the opposite end, three basketball courts away. He glides across the concrete pavement in a baseball cap and cargo pants, shaking friends' hands with a special finger snap that is their private greeting, and then settles in for a game of cards, usually hearts or spades.
Mr. Chin and Mr. Li have never met. They live in distant worlds, separated by language, age and, in some ways, cultural identity. But they share one palpable need: to keep coming back to the same small and crowded patch of green that is Chinatown's communal backyard. 
It is a pull that the park's regulars, including the many who have moved to Queens, Brooklyn and New Jersey, grasp for words to explain. 
"It was a part of me growing up," said Mr. Li,a freshman at the Borough of Manhattan Community College who still lives in Chinatown. 
The park is where Mr. Li came of age; he climbed the monkey bars as a 6-year-old and broke his arm twice playing basketball and football in his early teens. "That's how I got my love for the park: I got hurt."
For the man known to everyone as Blind Man Chin, the park is a sanctuary in a land that still seems foreign. Mr. Chin's youthful memories belong to Toisan, China: he immigrated to Chinatown in 1978. He later moved with his wife and four children to Bensonhurst in Brooklyn, but he has returned to the park at least three times a week over the last 25 years.
"I've made many friends with this board," Mr. Chin said in Chinese, speaking through a translator, as he smoked a Marlboro Red at one of seven dark green picnic tables that have become permanent chess playing stations. 
The life of Columbus Park begins in the early morning hours, when men and women arrive to practice tai chi and toddlers clamber around the park's playground. 
At lunchtime, the park calls forth lawyers, jurors and probation officers from the Criminal Court building across Baxter Street, along with the occasional Wall Street analyst. 
Older Chinese women sit under rainbow-hued umbrellas at the Bayard Street entrance, waiting to tell the fortunes of passers-by. Sometimes they are joined by a small troupe of Chinese opera singers. 
Schoolchildren rush to the paved field for recess. In the early afternoon, teenagers begin to gather at the park's south end, near Worth Street, to play basketball and cards.
But if the park has a daylong anchor, it is the dozens, and sometimes hundreds, of men who come for Xiangqi, or Chinese chess.
The game is similar to Western chess: its object is to capture the opponent's leader. The general is to Chinese chess what the king is to Western chess. The Chinese pieces -- flat round wooden or plastic chips engraved with Chinese characters -- are placed on the intersections of the board's lines. 
Every day, groups of men begin to gather around 10 a.m. to watch, play and sometimes bet on games. As the sun moves overhead, the men lift the tables to the shade of the mulberry trees. When too many pigeons congregate on the branches, the men nervously move the tables back into the open. At sundown, the players reluctantly go home.
During the blackout last summer, they stayed through the night and played by candlelight.
A sign near the tables warns that gambling is illegal, and the police occasionally make arrests. But, because the players are of modest means -- many are unemployed or retired -- the bets are usually a cup of coffee and rarely exceed a $10 bill. 
"In Chinese they say your life is like a chess game," Mr. Chin said. "Each game is new. It's just like us. Every day is not the same. Chess is life."
The same faces appear, day after day. 
There is Kar San in his black poncho, 3 feet 4 inches tall, smoking a pipe and listening to country rock on a hidden Walkman. There are the Detectives, two former officers of the Royal Hong Kong Police. There are the park's revered champions, men like Bond Tam and Lo Ming; when they arrive, space is immediately cleared for them to play. 
Then there is Loud Mouth Ming, who earned his nickname with superfluous and unsolicited spectator commentary. When a game turns suspenseful, though, dozens of men press around a table, hurling suggestions at the players. 
The advice comes in at least five Chinese dialects, from Cantonese (the most common dialect in Chinatown) to Toisanese and Shanghainese. Mostly, the men understand one another.
"If you move that piece, you'll have checkmate," a gray-jacketed spectator told a man playing in the early evening.
"That won't do," the player replied.
"Why don't you just do it?" the man insisted.
"I don't need your advice right now. Your bad advice."
There are younger Chinese among the chess players, but they are Chinatown's newest immigrants, mostly from the Fujian province. They scarcely relate to their basketball-toting peers at the park's south end. 
"Their Chinese is like our English -- just as poor," said Eagle Chen, 28, huddled over his chess board. He came from China 10 years ago.
For the younger Chinese-Americans at the south end, raised playing both Monopoly and Chinese chess, the gap between the two groups is hard to define, said a 21-year-old Baruch College finance major who identified himself only as Eric. "It's just something you feel, like an uncomfortable silence," he said.
Still, the park's current of Chinese culture draws the younger group, which includes high school freshmen from Bronx Science or Stuyvesant who hop off the train en route to their homes in Brooklyn for a quick game of cards and a snack at the Tasty Dumpling on Mulberry Street.
"You feel like you know everything here," said Elizabeth Wang Yo, 16, of Brooklyn, who said she added "Elizabeth" to her name because she "really wanted" an English name. "It's like we belong here."

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
A 16-Acre Memorial That'll Never Be

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap

 BODY:
TAKE a deep breath.
 A week from now, many New Yorkers may be consumed by the question, "Which memorial should we build at the World Trade Center site?" Eight designs culled from 5,200 submissions will be on display at Battery Park City as the memorial jury prepares to choose a winner. The aesthetic appeal, spiritual resonance, public mindedness and financial soundness of each proposal will be the subject of soliloquies, arguments, essays and chatter. 
 So take a breath now, because this may be the last opportunity to contemplate quietly the entire 16-acre World Trade Center site as a memorial. 
The point is not to second-guess the competition but to affirm the magnitude of what is being remembered, since the devastation was not confined to the corner where the twin towers stood, now a 4.5-acre memorial polygon, 384 feet along Liberty Street, 552 feet along West Street.
Theoretically, proposals may exceed these boundaries, but they must be deemed "feasible and consistent with site plan objectives" by the jurors and by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is running the competition. There is little chance that any plan would be chosen that foreclosed a new PATH terminal, office towers, cultural centers and stores.
"By and large, people believe that it's imperative to rebuild the site," said Kevin M. Rampe, president of the corporation. "There is a question of the mix of uses and what predominates. But the debate as to whether to rebuild has passed."
That particularly New York conviction that construction equals regeneration may have obscured other voices, but they are still out there. And they are worth listening to, if only because they may offer a useful yardstick for gauging the gravity and scope of the eight proposed plans.
"Nothing could more faithfully represent the loss we suffered on Sept. 11, 2001, than a big, terrifying, unhelpful void," Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic, said yesterday. "There should be a substantial patch of ground that one is almost afraid to approach, but that one must. There should be something frightening about it."
Or something lovely.
Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland of the Yale School of Medicine, the author of "How We Die: Reflections on Life's Final Chapter," imagines a "parklike oasis of foliage and trees and benches and secluded walkways and fountains and small statuary and above all retreat, in the midst of the towering city and the din around it."
"One of the things Americans do least well," he said, "is to contemplate, meditate and be alone with themselves and with their thoughts."
Dr. Nuland conceded yesterday that this garden of meditation would never come to pass. "I was told rather harshly that commerce is all, and that it is impossible for such a valuable piece of real estate to be put to the use that I suggested," he said. "Of course, it represents a huge sacrifice, but what a small price to pay for the opportunity to discover and rediscover ourselves."
By contrast, he said, a building is "a monument not to the people who died, but it becomes a monument to the brilliance of the architect."
There are architects who have thought along the same lines. Tadao Ando, for example, who won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1995, has proposed a "memorial tomb" in the form of a spherical mound 90 feet high.
"If we are to fill the void at the site of the lost World Trade Center, it should not be with architecture but with a 'place' to remember and reflect," he wrote. "What we need now is the courage to construct nothing more."
And Michael Sorkin, an architect and director of the graduate program in urban design at City College, would create a "great space of gathering, something between a plaza and a park," he wrote in a recent essay. He called for federal financing, on the grounds that "no less than Gettysburg or Pearl Harbor, this is the site of a national trauma."
"If terror demands a civic reply," he wrote, "what better one than a solemn memorial to those lost and a space for the most fundamental exercise of democracy in space, the freedom to gather in a place that is our own."
MANY family members of those who were killed are focused on preserving the footprints of the twin towers, outlined 70 feet below street level at bedrock. But that does not necessarily rule out development on the east side of the site.
"My opinion is that there needs to be a balance between the commercial component and historic preservation, with the memorial done as the centerpiece," said Anthony Gardner, a board member of the Coalition of 9/11 Families. His brother Harvey Joseph Gardner III died in the attack.
Asked yesterday about leaving the whole site vacant, Nikki Stern, who lost her husband, James E. Potorti, said, "Anything that economically devastates New York would not be a good legacy in terms of remembering our loved ones."
"Besides," she said, "I wouldn't want to send the message that no one could ever again work where the towers once stood."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Study On Housing Costs 

BYLINE:  By David W. Chen (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 Government regulations are largely responsible for the high cost of housing construction in Manhattan, according to a study released yesterday. The study -- "Why Is Manhattan So Expensive?" -- was published by the Manhattan Institute, a policy research group that favors less government regulation. 
It focused on why so few new apartments have been built in Manhattan since 1980, despite a solid economy and escalating real estate prices. The study's authors -- Edward L. Glaeser of Harvard and Joseph Gyourko of the University of Pennsylvania -- concluded, by a mathematical analysis of costs, that government regulations were a form of tax. It can amount to as much as 50 percent of the total price of the median condominium, for example, the authors said. The study did not cite specific regulations. Some housing experts said the study neglected difficult-to-measure factors, like demographics. David W. Chen (NYT)

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
36 Hours Charlotte, N.C.

BYLINE:  By LOUIS JACOBSON 

 BODY:
 OVER the last 20 years, Charlotte, North Carolina's biggest city, has remade itself from a textiles town into an investment and banking center, the nation's second-largest financial-services hub after New York City (and about to become bigger if the proposed merger of Bank of America and Fleet goes through). The moderate Carolina weather makes the city a pleasant place to stroll in winter, while museums and hip shops are also a draw. And though the city has a thriving historic-preservation movement, you get the unmistakable feeling that Charlotte sees itself as a city of the future -- and it has the new skyscrapers to prove it. LOUIS JACOBSON

Friday

7:30 p.m.

1. Beyond Gritty, and Grits
When the Pewter Rose Bistro (1820 South Boulevard; 704-332-8149) moved to the South End section of Charlotte 15 years ago, the neighborhood was scruffy and all but abandoned at night. But its building, a onetime industrial site, had 30-foot ceilings, great light and enough room for a big kitchen. Now the South End is gentrified, and Pewter Rose remains one of the city's most eclectic restaurants. The executive chef, Blake Dewey, prepares appetizers like fried chevre and chipotle and tiny tacos filled with tuna sushi smothered in a creamy sauce ($8.95 to $10.95), and entrees like salt-fried duck for wrapping in lettuce leaves and Indonesian chicken and shrimp ($15.95 to $16.95).

9 p.m.

2. Vodka Nocturne
Luckily, you don't have to waddle far from a table at Pewter Rose to the comfortable couches of Tutto Mondo (704-332-5142), the nightclub that shares owners -- and the second floor of the former industrial building -- with Pewter Rose. The club says it caters to 30-something professionals, and it starts most weekend nights with mellow jazz by local musicians and becomes more lively as the night goes on. Behind the bar are almost 50 vodkas, from Karl Marx to ruby-red grapefruit Charbay, so make your choice and settle in with a cocktail.

Saturday

8:30 a.m.

3. Soaring Heights
Downtown Charlotte -- actually called Uptown -- is eminently walkable, with sidewalk benches and marble plazas scattered among the cluster of postmodern skyscrapers. At 60 stories, the Bank of America Corporate Center (100 North Tryon Street), designed by Cesar Pelli, towers over Independence Square -- the crossroads that gave birth to Charlotte -- with its crown of icicle-sharp points. One block north is the new 47-story Hearst Tower; finished in 2002, it bows outward as it rises, ending in an angular neo-Deco cap reminiscent of the Chrysler Building in Manhattan. The retro lobby includes the Bank of America Gallery (214 North Tryon Street; 704-388-3104), which holds exhibitions from the bank's collection. The current show is "The Photo League: Photographs of Urban Life in American From the 1930's and 1940's."

9:15 a.m.

4. A Grocery Stop
Recharge yourself at Reid's Fine Foods (Seventh Street between College and Brevard Streets; 704-377-1312), an upscale grocery store that has been in business since 1928. On Saturday mornings, the store's bakery turns out croissants filled with cream cheese or jam ($1.29), apple and cherry strudel ($1.29) and almost a dozen kinds of muffins ($1.59). From the coffee bar you can get espressos, lattes or cappuccinos. For a real taste of the Carolinas, pick up a fiery Blenheim Ginger Ale (99 cents), which has achieved cult status. Carry your haul a few blocks away, to the Fourth Ward Park, a patch of greenery just beyond the skyscrapers. Then wander the narrow streets of the Fourth Ward, a leafy neighborhood of quiet fountains, aromatic wildflowers and charmingly restored Victorian homes.

10 a.m.

5. A Quilt of Garbage
Backtrack a few blocks and visit the Mint Museum of Craft and Design (220 North Tryon Street; 704-337-2000), occupying a renovated department store among the Uptown towers. Don't expect to find only folksy, backwoods creations: the museum's vibe is avant-garde, stylish and contemporary. You'll find fanciful animals made from beer cans by an anonymous South African artist; a quilt made from garbage discarded along a trail in New Mexico; and a pair of bracelets that turn tiny glass beads into Warhol-style portraits of the Dalai Lama and the Mulder and Scully characters from the "X-Files." Save your ticket stub ($6 adults); it allows admission to the Mint Museum of Art (2730 Randolph Road; 704-337-2000), the craft museum's older sibling.

11:15 a.m.

6. Meet the New South
Just a few blocks from the craft museum, the Levine Museum of the New South, (200 East Seventh Street; 704-333-1887) offers a hard-hitting social history of Charlotte and the South, beginning just after the Civil War. The exhibition includes a reproduction of a tenant farmer's house and "white" and "colored" water-fountain signs from Charlotte City Hall. The story concludes with discussions of suburban sprawl, economic growth, ethnic diversity -- and Nascar. Visitors are encouraged to express themselves by posting notes, which recently ranged from "this kind of stuff is so cool!" to "I think is boring." Admission is $6.

12:30 p.m.

7. Chicken Run
Return to the South End and get in line at Price's Chicken Coop (1614 Camden Road; 704-333-9866), the home of perhaps the best fried chicken in Charlotte, and beyond, since 1962. Orders are for take-out only, and everything is packed in a box for easy mobility: fried chicken, tater-rounds, hush puppies, cole-slaw, a roll and sweet tea, all for less than $6. A pleasant spot for a picnic is Latta Park a few blocks away.

1:45 p.m.

8. Time to Shop
If you're at Latta Park, you'll find youself in the heart of the pleasant Dilworth neighborhood, an early Charlotte suburb with a lot of porches and handsome wood-frame houses circa 1910. Get a feel for the area while making the short drive to Paper Skyscraper (330 East Boulevard; 704-333-7130), which is filled with chic paper goods, stationery and cutting-edge housewares, and a selection of art, architecture and design books that beats that at the Mint Museum.

8 p.m.

9. Le Cuisine Charlotte
It's located in a shopping center in the middle of suburbia, but Patou (2400 Park Road; 704-376-2233) offers first-rate French cuisine. Start with a hot crab cake set on a cool layer of minced tomatoes, avocado and capers ($9.95). Move on to the bourride de poisson ($17.95), the steamed mussels ($7.95) or the steak frites ($19.95). For dessert: the mousse au chocolat ($6.95).

Sunday

Noon

10. Birds of Prey
Thirteen miles northwest of Uptown, in Huntersville, is the Carolina Raptor Center (5225 Sample Road; 704-875-2312), one of the nation's largest refuges for injured owls, hawks, eagles, condors and other birds of prey. It takes in about 700 birds a year, almost half hurt by automobiles. The animals that can be reconditioned (they learn to fly again in large cages and get remedial training in mouse hunting) are returned to the wild. Others are used in the center's educational programs.

2 p.m.

11. Hot Food, Cool Mascot
For a bird of a different feather, head to the Penguin Drive-In (1921 Commonwealth Avenue; 704-375-6959), a 1950's drive-in that was given a face-lift a few years ago. It's popular with the trucker-cap crowd, and the beer includes labels like Schlitz and Pabst. The food runs to hot dogs ($1.95) and fried pickles ($2.95), along with a barbecue plate ($6.95) and Brunswick stew ($3.95). If you're not in the mood for beer, try Cheerwine, a regional cherry-flavored soda.

THE BASICS
Visiting Charlotte
Charlotte/Douglas International Airport is served by most major airlines and car-rental companies. 
When the Dunhill Hotel (237 North Tryon Street; 704-332-4141 or 800-354-4141) opened in 1929, it was the tallest building in town -- at 10 stories. It is now on the National Trust for Historic Preservation's list of historic American hotels. It has 60 rooms and looks out on the Uptown neighborhood. The weekend bed-and-breakfast rate starts at $139 a night.
On a smaller scale, the Homeplace (5901 Sardis Road; 704-365-1936), in South Charlotte, has just three rooms. It is in a Victorian-style house on two and a half acres in a residential neighborhood. Rooms are $115 to $125 a night, breakfast included.
