HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Less Space but More Rent? Court Says No

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
After one wall was shifted -- making the apartment next door larger -- a vacated rent-stabilized apartment at 302 East Third Street in Manhattan was rendered 86 square feet smaller. Yet the landlord charged the tenants who moved into the downsized unit a monthly rent of $1,950, nearly triple what the former tenant had paid.
 In a precedent-setting decision, an appeals court has said no. 
 Changing the size of an apartment -- to something either smaller or larger -- to get a higher rent "is done all the time," said Sherwin Belkin, a prominent landlord lawyer who was not involved in this recent case. 
So the 5-to-0 ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Sept. 16 -- the case was Devlin v. New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal and 302 East Third Street Associates -- "is absolutely precedent setting," Mr. Belkin said.
"It's undoing years of D.H.C.R. and judicial rulings," he added.
The case began in 1998 as an overcharge proceeding before the state housing division brought by the new tenants in Apartment 5D at the Third Street building, Keith Devlin and B. D. White. The new 5D, although 86 square feet smaller, remained a one-bedroom apartment. The previous tenant, when 5D was bigger, had paid $673 a month.
Normally, an owner of a vacated rent-stabilized apartment is entitled to a 20 percent rent increase when a two-year lease is given to a new tenant. In this case, the landlord sought to charge what is called a "first rent" because the smaller Apartment 5D, according to previous housing division rulings, constituted a "newly created unit." The landlord wanted to charge $1,950, but with a discount reducing the rent to $1,200 a month if the new tenant paid by the 15th of each month.
The state housing division ruled in favor of the owner, saying that an apartment that was 86 square feet smaller qualifies as a new unit. And, on appeal, the division's deputy commissioner, Paul Roldan, upheld the initial decision. The tenants then challenged the division's decision before Justice William A. Wetzel of State Supreme Court, who on March 6, 2002, also upheld the original ruling.
Then, this September in an opinion written by Justice Peter Tom, the Appellate Division unanimously reversed the lower court, saying that the reduction of the space did not result in the "obliteration of the prior apartment."
Justice Tom wrote that to hold otherwise "would encourage subterfuges as a means of improperly manipulating rent stabilization."
The ruling distinguished the situation at 302 East Third Street from one involving an owner who might have, for example, combined two studio apartments to create a large one-bedroom. 
In reversing the housing agency decision, the court said that the agency had "myopically" used to the letter of the law "to effectively undermine the very statutory regime that it was charged with administering."
Mr. White, one of the two tenants in 5D (Mr. Devlin has since moved out), said he expected the housing division to order the landlord to reduce his monthly rent to $810 -- "what the previous tenant paid plus a legal vacancy."
"I feel like I've won a victory not only for myself," said Mr. White, a theater production manager, "but for everyone who is subjected to these practices. I'm loving that."
Mr. Belkin, a partner in the firm of Belkin Burden Wenig & Goldman, pointed out that there had been many previous housing division and judicial decisions holding that a substantial increase or decrease in the square footage of an apartment creates a new unit, entitling an owner to a "first rent."
"I am certain that this decision comes as a shock to the real estate industry," Mr. Belkin said. "What the Appellate Division seems to have told owners who undertake substantial alterations of their apartments is: Make sure you not only increase or decrease the square footage, but also that you change the number of rooms in the apartment."
Through the newsletter that his firm sends each month to 2,600 clients, Mr. Belkin said, "I have advised them that if you are unsure if your proposed reconfiguration will create a new unit, you should consider obtaining an advisory opinion from D.H.C.R. before starting the construction."

GRAPHIC: Photo: B. D. White inside his apartment on East Third Street. An appeals court said the landlord, who had downsized the unit, could not triple the rent. (Photo by Marshall Mantel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL; 
For Knicks and Nets, A Rivalry of Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By LIZ ROBBINS; Lee Jenkins contributed to this report.

 BODY:
This year, the banner ceremony to celebrate the Nets' second straight Eastern Conference championship was deliberately understated. Lou Lamoriello, the Nets' chief executive, did not want to overplay the team's achievement, because they had again lost in the N.B.A. finals. 
 So hours before the tipoff on opening night at Continental Arena, Lamoriello changed the pregame ceremony; instead of raising the banner to the rafters, a spotlight was directed on a banner already hanging from the ceiling. Streamers fell, but so did the faces of some surprised Nets officials. 
 Chances are, that would never have happened in Madison Square Garden had the Knicks been able to make back-to-back appearances in the finals. In a place where hype and hoops co-exist, the Knicks would find a way to celebrate -- were there to be such an occasion. 
But there isn't likely to be one any time soon. Instead, as the teams prepare to meet tonight for the first time this season, the buzz is muted on both sides of the Hudson River, for different reasons. 
The Nets, with a 3-5 record, are struggling, but they remain one of the top teams in the Eastern Conference and have been retooled to return to the finals. But amid the increasingly distracting backdrop of a potential sale and move, they continue to have trouble drawing fans and currently have the second-lowest attendance in the National Basketball Association.
Nine miles away, the Knicks, at 2-5, are stumbling toward their third straight losing season, watching as empty seats dot the Garden, and hoping that the return of Antonio McDyess -- as early as next week -- can resurrect their season before it is too late. 
Just two years ago, Jason Kidd marched into New Jersey and proclaimed that the Nets were No. 2 in the New York metropolitan area, but would soon be No. 1. He was right, if only in the won-lost column. But even Kidd, with his uncanny vision, could not have foreseen the problems now confronting both teams. No one knows where the Nets are headed off the court; no one knows where the Knicks are headed on it.

On the Court
Nets Coach Byron Scott and Knicks Coach Don Chaney reacted to losses this week in the same way, saying their teams played scared.
Certain players -- Kurt Thomas of the Knicks and Kenyon Martin and Richard Jefferson of the Nets -- bristled at the suggestion. And both coaches had to hastily talk to their players the next day to explain themselves. 
Neither Scott nor Chaney said he was scared about his job status, although Scott entered the season on the last year of his contract, without the Nets showing any inclination of giving him an extension. "I think Byron is doing fine," Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, said. "You can't hold him accountable for the injuries and lack of depth."
James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden and the executive who oversees the Knicks, has twice extended Chaney's contract -- it now runs until 2006 -- even though Chaney has not had a winning record since taking over for Jeff Van Gundy in December 2001. 
"No, I'm not worried about my job," Chaney said. "And it's not because I have a guaranteed contract, either. I know -- and I've been in this place before -- that I'm doing the best I can do, preparing the team."
Chaney has, however, revealed the strain he is feeling these days. He ranted to reporters on Monday morning in Cleveland, reacting to criticism of how he had been using center Dikembe Mutombo, then ranted to his players on Monday night after they played without effort in losing to the Cavaliers. 
"I let myself go and I got upset," he said of his tirade to reporters. "That won't happen again." 
Chaney said that his job in preparing players only goes so far. "I can control them in the locker room, I can control them here," he said of the practice court. "I can't control what they do on the floor. They have to react as basketball players."
Tellingly, the Knicks are putting their faith in the return of McDyess, who scrimmaged twice with the team this week, but is not yet ready to return after a two-year layoff and three knee surgeries. 
In the meantime, the off-season acquisitions of Keith Van Horn and Mutombo have yielded inconsistent results and Mike Sweetney, the Knicks' first-round pick, is averaging just 4 minutes a game.
The plan, according to General Manager Scott Layden, was to get bigger and younger, which he accomplished by trading Latrell Sprewell for Van Horn. "We feel with this team we can win. We like the roster," he said. 
But the Knicks are slow and stuck with five power forwards. They have no depth at shooting guard and possess the highest payroll in the league. And they are still looking for a point guard, as Chaney unintentionally let slip in the preseason. 
The Nets, despite signing Kidd to a six-year, $103 million deal and Alonzo Mourning for an additional $23 million, have holes, too. Kerry Kittles, Richard Jefferson and Jason Collins have been consistent, and Kenyon Martin has been hurt, but Kidd has had to play too much; yesterday the Nets signed Robert Pack to be his veteran backup. 
Still, the Nets have made a remarkable transition in recent seasons, one the Knicks can only dream of.
"I think the Knicks are different when you judge them because they lock into a lot of players, so you can't turn the ship around real quick," said one Eastern Conference general manager. "New York's different," he added. "Nobody's looking for what you're trying to do to build the team -- you got to live in the present."

Off the Court
The Knicks' losing record the last two seasons has directly affected the team's ticket sales. Last November the Knicks' string of 433 consecutive sellouts was snapped; since then, they have had to aggressively market themselves, just as other teams in the league have done for years. And with season ticket-holders declining to renew because of apathy or economy, there is no longer a waiting list.
Steve Mills, the president of the Garden in charge of team operations, said that the decline in season tickets -- Sports Business Journal estimates the number of tickets at 12,600 -- was not significant. "It is down less than 10 percent from last year," he said.
In three games at the Garden this season, the Knicks' average attendance is 18,744, about 1,000 under capacity. The Knicks are soliciting groups like college alumni organizations and using e-mail messages for a ticket exchange program to reduce no-shows. Their last home game, last Friday night against Sacramento, brought in some A-list celebrities and the Knicks' electric victory over the Kings brought back reminders of the old days.
And then they lost two putrid games on the road. 
As for the Nets, they seem to almost prefer playing on the road these days, where they can be energized by electric crowds they do not see in Continental Arena. 
Last season, the Nets' average attendance improved by nearly 2,000 fans a game to 15,185, the seventh lowest in the league. Through four games this season, the Nets are next-to-last in attendance, averaging 13,530 fans. Perhaps it is not a coincidence that the Nets have lost their last three games at home, all played before a lot of empty seats.
The N.B.A.'s commissioner, David Stern, noted that the Nets' revenue from gate receipts has actually increased this season because the Nets are filling in the more expensive seats.
But underlying and perhaps fortifying the low attendance is the impending sale of the team. The Nets could end up in Brooklyn or Long Island, or Newark, and Continental Arena is already taking on something of a lame-duck status.
The players say they are not distracted by the impending sale or the empty seats. "I'm not worried about the support," Mourning said. "Our strength comes from right here, in this little unit here. We put on a better performance, more people might buy a ticket to come see us play."

Who's No. 1?
The Nets have won 9 of their last 10 games over the Knicks, overmatching them with athleticism. Yet, somehow, it doesn't fully resonate in the metropolitan area.
"The unfortunate thing about it, having been here in this market for a long time, I don't think the Nets will ever be No. 1," said Willis Reed, who starred for the Knicks, coached both teams, represented the Nets as an executive for 15 years and returned to the Knicks as a special adviser this summer. "You're fighting something that you can't win. You're fighting history."
Reed looks up at the championship banner of 1973 hanging in the Knicks' sparkling practice facility, pleased to be back with his old team, the one everybody always asked him about.
"It's hard to leave a good team. To be where a team is winning is always good," he acknowledged.
Sponsors and fans ask Reed when the Knicks will win again. "We have enough talent here to get back to the playoffs," he said. "That's going to be our major challenge."
For the Nets, the challenge is raising a championship banner, before a full house, wherever that may be.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
Twilight Zone For ZIP Code At Ground Zero

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
FROM the beginning, the collapse of the World Trade Center has been a tale told in numbers as well as words.
 We're still counting exactly how many people died. And parceling the compensation for victims' families. And measuring the damage to the city's economy. And deciding how tall new buildings at the site should be. Figures like 2,752, the latest tally of the dead, and 1,776 feet, the proposed height of the so-called Freedom Tower, are as much a part of the post-9/11 vocabulary as "footprints" and "ground zero." 
 One number gets little attention, but it should not be ignored in contemplating Lower Manhattan's future. It is 10048.
That was the trade center's ZIP code. When the towers came down, 10048 fell into a state of suspended animation -- seemingly dead, but not really.
An inevitable question is what does the United States Postal Service intend to do with this ZIP code. Preserve it for the new buildings that will eventually rise? Or retire it, much as a ball club does with a great player's number?
Nothing has been formally decided, the Postal Service says. Still, 10048 does not seem about to go the way of Babe Ruth's 3 or Lou Gehrig's 4 at Yankee Stadium.
"It is being held as an active number," with no plans to discontinue it, said Anthony Musso, a Postal Service spokesman in New York. When development begins, Mr. Musso said, "in all likelihood that number is going to be assigned to whatever buildings are on that site."
Obviously, the fate of a postal number is not the most pressing concern for city planners. But ZIP codes mean something. Communities, feeling that their very identities are at stake, sometimes fight over them. Where would the TV show about Beverly Hills kids have been without that 90210 in the title?
Certainly, 10048 meant something. It meant money. Many people who worked there earned lots of it. This was, after all, the World Trade Center, dedicated to commerce and to making a buck -- just as New York itself has been since its earliest days, when Dutch traders came ashore and struck, or so the story goes, their $24 deal.
Given this reality, those wanting to turn the entire 16-acre trade center site into a memorial are arguably untrue to the city's guiding spirit. Now, the advocates of rebuilding seem dominant. But it took them a while. In the first months after the terrorist attack, few people cared to think of the trade center as the money machine that it was.
"It was like you were speaking ill of the dead," said Andrew A. Beveridge, a sociologist and demographer at Queens College. But let's get real. The lawyers and financial types who filled the twin towers "were not working there for self-actualization," Professor Beveridge said. "They were there to make as much money as they could."
Analyzing census data from 2000, the trade center's last full year, Professor Beveridge found that 31,149 people worked in 10048, and were paid an average of $101,006, far more than the citywide average of $59,448. No other ZIP code in the city registered a higher income per worker.
(Intriguingly, the 2000 census recorded 55 people, including 11 small children, as living in the trade center complex. "The odds are we're dealing here with a homeless situation," said Joseph J. Salvo, director of the population division of the Department of City Planning.)
MAIL continues to arrive addressed to 10048, about 3,600 pieces a day, Mr. Musso said. That is a fraction of the volume before 9/11, but it is enough to make one wonder if some people out there never heard the news.
These letters and packages now go to the main post office on Eighth Avenue, opposite Pennsylvania Station. There, they either are picked up by businesses that have relocated or are marked "return to sender."
Before the terror attack, 10048 mail was sorted at 90 Church Street, but that building, another victim of Sept. 11, remains closed. Artifacts from the Church Street post office -- items like letter carriers' bags and sorting cases with pigeonholes for Windows on the World and Cantor Fitzgerald -- were sent to the National Postal Museum in Washington, part of the Smithsonian Institution.
The Church Street station may be reopened by mid-2004, Mr. Musso said. Presumably, at some point, 10048 will also return fully to life.
So it should, Professor Beveridge said. It would be a symbol of the site's rebirth. "They should rebuild it and get it going again, as opposed to pretending that we never can," he said.

HEADLINE: A Sketch of Arab-Americans; 
Survey Touches Off Disputes Over Who Should Study Whom

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
When researchers decided to survey attitudes, values and the impact of Sept. 11 among 1,000 Arab-Americans in the Detroit area, they saw their study as a groundbreaking attempt to accurately portray a community that felt stereotyped and under siege. 
 But perhaps inevitably the research team -- from the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research -- ran into criticism and concern. 
 First came questions about the study's confidentiality. The three-county region has one of the nation's largest, most concentrated communities of Arab-Americans, some 100,000 to 300,000 people, and there were fears about bias attacks and eroding civil liberties. Some Arab-American scholars were miffed that there was only one Arab-American among seven researchers. 
Then there were concerns about the survey's methods. Was "Arab-American" defined by region or language? For example, Chaldeans, primarily Christian Iraqis who speak Aramaic as well as Arabic, wanted to be part of the survey but didn't always identify themselves as Arab-American. 
Just how sensitive and informed were the researchers and interviewers about Arab-Americans? 
Preliminary findings of the $790,000 study are expected to be released in January, and ultimately many scholars predict that it will create a comprehensive view of Arab-Americans. But the cacophony surrounding it, reported in May in "The Chronicle of Higher Education," is emblematic of an old controversy among social scientists that is far from resolved: the gap between those who live in a community and those who study it. In other words, whose research is authentic? More than 40 years ago, the renowned sociologist Robert K. Merton wrote a classic paper on "insiders and outsiders" to talk about the nuances of social perspective. 
"It's in some ways a well-worn tale," said Lawrence D. Bobo, a professor of sociology and African and African-American studies at Harvard who has written widely about studies of race and ethnicity. "There will always be concerns when communities are studied that feel disenfranchised, lacking voice and influence when questions arise. The Arab-American community is just the latest community to experience this."
More often, blacks have been the minority in the insider-outsider debate. Mr. Bobo recalled a major controversy in the late 1980's when the National Academy of Sciences studied black American attitudes on a number of subjects. Some blacks were outraged that the leader of the study committee was white; others accused the committee of having an ideological bent that would skew the results.
"I'm not one who subscribes to the view that only one who is an insider can do work in minority communities," Mr. Bobo said. "At the same time, it's easy to misinterpret or miscontextualize something. It's important to have a dialogue with the community. This is a large and ongoing issue that is definitely not resolved."
Wayne E. Baker, one of the two principal investigators for the Detroit project, said he was baffled that anyone would doubt the researchers. They submitted the survey proposal before community groups, he said, fielded Internet queries and hired and trained 60 interviewers from the community who were fluent in Arabic and English. The team created a 30-member community advisory board and submitted the proposed survey to three academic specialists in Arab-American issues (all of whom are Arab-Americans).
The survey, which included the views of 500 non-Arab-Americans, also "oversampled" Arab-Americans -- or interviewed more than usual -- to get as accurate a snapshot as possible. Mr. Baker, a sociologist who isalso director of the Center for Society and Economy at Michigan, said he was the only one of the seven researchers without experience in researching Arab-Americans or the Middle East. 
David L. Featherman, director of the Institute for Social Research, said that the insider-outsider issues were familiar and expected. The institute is the world's largest academic survey and research organization and for 50 years has surveyed attitudes on everything from health and aging to child rearing.
"It was recognized that this was a tense geopolitical moment," Mr. Featherman said of the timing of the Detroit survey, which began a year ago and is mostly financed by the Russell Sage Foundation. But while it was important to make the process transparent to the community and to build a partnership, Mr. Featherman said, researchers did not need to completely mirror the communities they studied."You don't have to be poor to study poverty," he said.
Some Arab-American scholars argued, however, that ethnicity matters.
"Within the paradigm of ethnic studies -- African-American studies, Latino-American studies, Native American, you name it, it's always good to add as many academic voices from within that community as possible," said Kenneth K. Ayouby, an Arab-American who studies the community and who works in the Dearborn, Mich., public schools. 
Referring to the Arab-American researcher, Mr. Ayouby continued: "With all due respect to Amaney Jamal, her being simply one Arab-American of the seven members of the research team makes her a token. There are other scholars out there. Knowing the culture academically means knowing the issues academically and knowing how to do the research better."
Ms. Jamal, a professor of politics at Princeton, said that she understands cultural gatekeeping but that she resents being called a token. A research team of three or four Arab-Americans, she said, could just as well be seen as pawns of an institution or tokens. The only legitimate discrimination, she said, is against bad research. 
But some critics of the survey complain of the difficulty they have encountered getting answers about it. Gary C. David, an assistant professor of sociology at Bentley College in Massachusetts, who administers an Internet Arab-American discussion group, said he was especially interested in the definition of "Arab-American." The term has always been disputed by scholars, he said, and is not an official census category.
Because the survey has allowed respondents to identify themselves ethnically, Mr. David and others said, it will be problematic as a basis for developing policy, for getting an accurate count, for defining the community. 
"We're not new here," Mr. David said of Arab-Americans. He described himself as a fourth-generation Arab-American with a Christian Lebanese last name. "But studies create a sense of just arriving if you focus on an enclave of first- and second-generation people, of people with only identifiable Arab names. I'm not questioning their research ability or knowledge. I'm just asking, What's it a study of?" 
Hassan Jaber, the associate director of the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services, the oldest and largest Arab-American human services organization, said that community groups had peppered the Detroit team with all those questions. He believes that the university has done a good job of reaching out to a representative sample and listening to its concerns. 
Mr. Jaber became a member of the community advisory board, one of whose tasks was to assess potential survey questions. For example, he said, a question like "Do you send money back home?" was ripe for misinterpretation. It could be construed as either providing aid to a family back home or as transferring money to potential terrorists.
There are no definitive guidelines or litmus tests for authenticity, said Rodney Coates, a professor of sociology at Miami University in Ohio and the next chairman of the American Sociological Association's section on racial and ethnic minorities. Rather, as in Michigan, researchers typically select the community they want to study and subject their survey to review before, during and after the process.
Starting in the 1930's, Mr. Coates said, academic researchers began to be concerned about bias tainting studies of white ethnic males and by the 1950's they were training their lenses on women and minorities. 
For example, Mr. Coates said, until women started conducting psychiatric research in sizable numbers, "frigid women" were often said to be suffering from penis envy. Similarly, women's heart troubles were overlooked because of the way mostly male researchers asked the questions.
And before the black social psychologist Kenneth Clark did his famous study of children's racial preferences, cited in the 1954 Supreme Court decision ending segregated schools, Mr. Coates said, no one questioned that a black child would prefer a white doll to a black doll.
Groups like women, gays and African-Americans know that studies that purport to paint a group portrait can do as much harm as good, said Michael W. Suleiman, a professor of political science at Kansas State University and a survey consultant. 
He added that not only has the Arab presence in the United States not been accurately documented -- a project he has undertaken -- but that too many Arab-American scholars have not been able to get research funds to study Arab-Americans. 
Altogether, he said, it is estimated that there are about 3 million to 3.5 million Arab-Americans, with the Detroit area as the largest enclave. The community there is also the most diverse, including Syrians, Egyptians, Moroccans, Lebanese and Iraqis. Most Arab-Americans are Christian.
While Mr. Suleiman feels that the Michigan study is by and large sound and fair, he, too, said that he thought more Arab-American scholars could have been included. 
Others are looking ahead to the study as an important milestone. After all, even after it is completed, they point out, there will be plenty of opportunities to critique the findings.
"I think what they'll get out of it are good numbers for things we've only been able to hypothesize -- work, assimilation, how American do Arab-Americans feel," said Nabeel Abraham, who teaches anthropology at Henry Ford Community College in Detroit, who was also a project consultant. "Now we'll have numbers that stand up to top social science scrutiny."
As for all the charges that too many outsiders generated those numbers, he said that in fact many of the definitions are up for grabs. "An outsider's view has validity, it has worth, if it's sympathetic, if they're not coming at the group with an ax," Mr. Abraham said. "What does it mean to be an insider? What is a true representative of the community? There are people who've been here four generations, people who just got here, people who married out, people who married in, people whose grandparents gave them an Arab name."

Xerox Settles Dispute Over Pension Benefits
Xerox agreed to settle a lawsuit over the way it calculated pension benefits by paying an additional $239 million to thousands of employees who retired between 1990 and 1999.
 The proposed settlement calls for Xerox to make the payment out of its pension plan for salaried employees. Xerox said it would not have to contribute additional money to the plan until at least 2005. Page C2. 

Deal Reached on Energy Measure
Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the House-Senate committee forging a compromise on national energy legislation, said Congressional Republicans had agreed on wide-ranging national energy legislation that would provide billions of dollars in tax breaks for power producers and impose new standards intended to reduce the chances of blackouts like the one that hit the Northeast in August. He admitted that the bill, drafted almost entirely by Republicans, was bound to attract criticism. A1.

Exxon Mobil was ordered by an Alabama jury to pay the state $11.9 billion for depriving it of proper royalties on the natural gas the company gathers there -- one of the country's largest punitive awards ever. C3.

Lawyers for Martha Stewart filed a brief with the United States District Court in Manhattan contending that she should not be charged with securities fraud because the statements she is accused of making "were immaterial as a matter of law." Ms. Stewart is scheduled to go on trial Jan. 12. C4.

Wall Street sank as investors sifted through a series of downbeat economic reports. The Nasdaq composite index declined 37.09 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,930.26. General Motors will take a $1.2 billion pretax charge in the fourth quarter for costs related to its United Auto Workers contract. C5.

HEADLINE: As Counties Face Fiscal Squeeze, Taxes Soar and Spending Shrinks 

BYLINE:  By LYDIA POLGREEN

 BODY:
A study released this week found that New York State residents pay the highest local taxes in the nation by far. A look at county budgets introduced across the state this fall indicates that New York will keep that distinction -- with a vengeance.
 Squeezed by state mandates that have grown much faster than the rate of inflation, counties are raising property taxes by double-digit percentages, slashing money for programs like libraries and the arts, and laying off workers. 
 The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, unveiled a budget yesterday that would raise the sales tax by one percentage point, an increase he unsuccessfully sought a year ago, to avert a 25 percent rise in the county's share of the property tax. The county also plans to lay off 236 of its nearly 4,700 workers, mainly in the social service and health departments. 
County executives around the state are grappling with similarly grim arithmetic. "We are looking at a 17 percent tax increase this year, and that is on top of a 23 percent increase last year," said the Albany County executive, Michael Breslin, referring to property taxes. "The biggest challenge we face is expenses that are totally out of our control."
 The tax study, issued Monday by the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonpartisan group largely backed by businesses that seeks ways to contain government spending and taxes in New York, said that the combined local income, property and sales taxes New Yorkers pay were 72 percent higher than the national average. The second-highest tax burden, New Jersey's, was 20 percent higher than the national average. The study analyzed taxes from the 2000 fiscal year, before the state's current fiscal crisis. 
With county taxes rising to meet huge new expenses, local officials across the state expect the gap between New York and the rest of the nation to widen. County officials and many analysts of state politics lay the blame for the local budget crises squarely at Albany's feet. Politically popular decisions that expanded health care for the poor and fattened state worker pensions will continue to strain the state budget next year, as elected officials in Albany struggle with a fiscal crisis and comply with a federal court order requiring the state to spend millions on education to correct inequities among the state's districts.
 But the impact of Albany's spending is not felt just on state tax bills. Because of the unusual way the state pays for Medicaid, and changes to the state pension system, a good portion of the bill for Albany's largess is hidden away in local property and sales taxes. Counties pay one-quarter of the cost of health care for the poor under the federal Medicaid program, while the federal government pays half and the state chips in the other 25 percent, or for nursing-home care, 40 percent. When Albany expands popular programs to cover the working poor and not just the destitute, it usually pays only 25 cents of each dollar spent but gets all the bragging rights.
Gov. George E. Pataki has been criticized for appearing in state-financed television commercials to promote the state's expansive health care programs for working low-income families. They now qualify for Medicaid programs that the state expanded to include those who make 150 percent of the federal poverty guideline. 
 "The political benefits are reaped in Albany," said Edmund J. McMahon, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a research institution that advocates shrinking government and lowering taxes. "But the fiscal price is paid at the local government level." 
Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki's budget office, said the governor had fought hard to relieve the burden on local taxpayers and said the Democratic-controlled State Assembly had stymied his efforts.
"No one has done more than Governor Pataki to help relieve the burden on municipalities," Mr. Quinn said yesterday. "The governor has consistently pushed for local mandate relief, pension reform and Medicaid reform, all of which will dramatically help local governments." 
Relief is certainly needed in Chemung County, where the county executive, Thomas Santulli, has whittled a $9 million shortfall in his budget, which would have forced a 42 percent property-tax increase, down to a $2.8 million hole that would require a 14 percent tax increase. To get that far he had to do some ruthless cost cutting, trimming the county work force, eliminating money for the arts and closing two libraries. 
 For 11 years, he said, the county has not raised property taxes in an effort to attract new jobs to its struggling communities, which include Elmira. The effort seemed to be paying off: In the last three years a steel processor, a rail car manufacturer and a maker of high-tech medical devices have all located in Chemung, investing millions of dollars and bringing hundreds of jobs. 
 "I have always believed that property taxes are the biggest detriment to economic development," Mr. Santulli said. "But we have cut as much as we can cut and there is nowhere else to go."
 It is a lament repeated in county after county, from rural Chautauqua at the western end of the state, where County Executive Mark Thomas will ask an aging population to pay nearly 10 percent more in property taxes, to affluent Suffolk and Nassau in the east, where officials have held down taxes for the most part but paid a different price.
 The Rockland County executive, C. Scott Vanderhoef, announced last month that his budget would raise property taxes 9.5 percent to pay for growing state pension costs and higher Medicaid bills. In 2003 Rockland paid $8 million into the state pension system to cover its workers; next year it will pay $20 million. Similarly, Medicaid expenses grew by 14 percent.
But county officials, particularly those raising taxes by steep percentages, are quick to note that the increases often do not translate into a large dollar figure. In Rockland, for example, the property tax increase will add only about $45 a year to the average homeowner's bill, Mr. Vanderhoef told county legislators.
While county property taxes usually make up a smaller portion of a home or business owner's tax bill than school taxes, their contribution to the overall tax burden is significant. When sales taxes and school taxes are added in, the local tax burden quickly becomes onerous, county officials said. And some counties have already reached the limit of how much they can raise sales taxes.
The cumulative effect on a taxpayer, given that school taxes are likely to rise again this yearas the state deals with a Court of Appeals ruling that requires millions of dollars of new spending to bring equity to school financing, can be brutal. 
 "It all adds up and becomes a snowball," said Marcia J. Van Wagner, the chief economist for the Citizens Budget Commission.
 On Long Island, Nassau and Suffolk Counties face sharp rises in the costs of state-mandated Medicaid programs, contributions to the state-run pension fund and employee health insurance. County officials say they also worry that the state, because of its own fiscal troubles, might pull back on local aid.
 Suffolk projects a $131 million jump next year for Medicaid, pensions and health insurance. "That's a monumental increase," said Fred Pollert, the budget review director for the County Legislature, whose $2.3 billion budget for 2004 awaits action by the county executive.
In Nassau, the total for Medicaid, pensions and health insurance is budgeted at $460 million for 2004, an increase of $166 million, or more than 40 percent in three years. After raising the county property tax 19 percent this year, the County Legislature adopted a $2.3 billion budget for next year with no tax increase, partly because of savings from 1,100 retirements, shrinking the work force to its lowest level in 30 years.
 A statewide campaign to curb Medicaid costs is the goal of the president-elect of the State Association of County Executives, Thomas R. Suozzi of Nassau. "It's the biggest single threat to our budgets across the state," he said. The state requires the counties and New York City to pay one-fourth of the cost of most Medicaid programs.
 "The state pushes the costs down onto the property-tax payer," since localities have virtually no other new revenue to offset higher Medicaid bills, Mr. Suozzi said. It may be unrealistic to demand that New York State absorb the entire local share, he said, so his goal is to "at least stop the growth, to cap our contributions."
 But county officials do not have high hopes for Medicaid reform next year. The governor and the Legislature agree that the system needs to be changed, but no substantive alterations to the way it is financed have been made since the last county budget crisis, in the early 1980's, when the state assumed a greater portion of the cost of nursing-home care. The State Senate has held roving hearings on the issue, but with all 212 seats in the State Legislature up for re-election and a projected budget deficit of $6 billion, radical change seems unlikely. 
 Mr. McMahon, a veteran observer of Albany politics who has followed the battles between the state and local governments closely, said that while it is true that counties can blame the state for much of their fiscal woe, it is also true that counties, like the state, did not do enough during the booming years of the 1990's to plan for tough times that inevitably arrive. Now that the lean years are here, local governments must pay the price, he said. 
 "There is a tendency to scream, 'Take this monkey off my back,' " Mr. McMahon said, referring to Medicaid and other state mandates. "But that is a cover. They say, 'Our budget is overwhelmed by this' and don't pay attention to other costs and services."

HEADLINE: Indians Now Disdain a Farm Once Hailed for Giving Tribe Jobs 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN

DATELINE: ROSEBUD INDIAN RESERVATION, S. D., Nov. 8 

 BODY:
Seven miles west of the tiny town of White River, on a snow-covered rise surrounded by bluffs and valleys, 24 metal-roofed barns create an isolated barracks for tens of thousands of fattening hogs.
 When a pig production company called Sun Prairie built the barns on these tribal trust lands four years ago, the Lakota Sioux who live here on the nearby reservation said they believed the barns would bring good-paying jobs to a reservation where 7 of 10 people are unemployed. 
 The jobs did come. But now some tribal members who have worked at the farm say they wonder at what cost. They describe a company that discriminates against Indians, paying them less than white workers and at times demanding they work extra hours for no pay. They say dust and ammonia emitted from fetid pools of manure that sometimes accumulate inside the barns made them cough until their ribs hurt and made breathing a struggle, even months after leaving their jobs. 
Workers have also made videotapes of the conditions inside the barns showing animals so tightly packed in their pens that strong hogs begin to cannibalize the weak, eating off tails and ears. Other pigs are shown with soccer-ball-sized abscesses hanging from their bellies. During some weeks, hundreds of pigs die, some employees say, from mistreatment and disease.
"They are abusing the land, abusing the Indian people and paying them nothing for their work," said Alvin Covey, a tribal member who worked at the farm for six months this year until July. "All they really care about is getting their money."
Mr. Covey is one of dozens of current or former workers at the farm who have been interviewed in the last year by the Humane Farming Association, a nonprofit group based in San Francisco that has been fighting to stop the hog farm since 1998.
 On Friday, the group filed a petition with the state's attorney general describing how it says the company is abusing the hogs in defiance of state animal cruelty laws. The petition also says that the group plans to file a separate complaint contending that the company has mistreated employees and forced them to work in dangerous conditions. 
Greg Fontaine, chief executive of Bell Farms, a private company that manages the Sun Prairie farm, said the accusations are not true. Sun Prairie and Bell Farms are private partnerships partly owned by Rich Bell, whose business is based is Wahpeton, N.D.
The companies have never discriminated against its Indian workers, Mr. Fontaine said, nor forced them to work without pay. Mr. Fontaine said he was not aware of any systemic health problems among the farm's workers.
And the farm, he said, has never treated the hogs inappropriately. While many may have died on occasion, he said, similar death rates routinely happen "at any hog company" if disease breaks out.
Mr. Fontaine said the association had simply accumulated stories "to paint the picture they want to paint." The association had previously made accusations about environmental problems at the farm, he said, which have not been substantiated.
Mr. Fontaine also questioned whether the videotapes were actually taken inside the company's barns. "I can't respond to what I haven't seen," he said. "We believe we run our farms there with sound husbandry practices. There is no mistreatment of animals."
But Gail A. Eisnitz, chief investigator at the association, said workers who shot the videos signed affidavits confirming they were inside the Rosebud barns. The videos show dead hogs piled in front of a small metal structure that workers call "the dead box," which is visible from the highway running by the farm. 
Because of the prospect of new jobs, when the company built the first 24 barns in 1998, many tribal members welcomed the farm. The Sioux Rosebud reservation -- 1,442 square miles of rolling hills and pasturelands, dotted with small towns near Badlands National Park -- has the country's fifth-highest child poverty rate, according to census data.
Even the tribe's casino has done little to lift its members from poverty. Few gamblers are willing to travel to a place so remote.
Mr. Fontaine said Sun Prairie decided to build the hog farm on tribal lands because of the availability of workers and water, which the tribe had agreed to supply. The farm is actually two sites, Grassy Knoll and Cottonwood, a couple of miles from each other, each with 24 barns, with a combined capacity of 96,000 hogs.
Still, in 1998, the company would have found it hard to build elsewhere in South Dakota because of a state constitutional amendment then in place banning corporate farms. Most state laws do not apply to Indian land.
To win tribal support, the company promised the tribe 25 percent of the farm's profits. But while the company has sold hogs for slaughter worth millions of dollars, it has sent the tribe a check for a mere $11,000, said Michael Boltz, who recently retired from the tribal council. Disgusted with the sum, Mr. Boltz said, tribal officials tore up the check.
Mr. Fontaine said legal fees had consumed the farm's profits.
The tribal council voted in March to evict the farm, Mr. Boltz said, but continuing litigation between the tribe and the company has stopped any action.
Mr. Boltz said he believed that the conditions for the pigs and workers fell somewhere between the dueling descriptions offered by the association and the company. He said he had not learned of significant complaints from workers about health or safety, but had heard accusations about poor conditions for the hogs.
Ms. Eisnitz said the association recently had the air inside the barns tested for ammonia. At their peak, she said, the levels were more than double the federal government's average limit for workers during an eight-hour shift.
Many workers complained about breathing problems. Anthony Barrera said he was so short of breath after quitting as a maintenance worker at the farm last year that for months he could not finish a sentence. A doctor, he said, prescribed a medicine inhaler usually used by asthmatics and told him that breathing the barn air could cause lung problems like those suffered by coal miners. When employees gather in the farm's break room, he said, there is a continuous chorus of deep coughs.
Mr. Fontaine said the company periodically tested the barn air for ammonia and had not found an unsafe level.
One worker, Arthur Black Bear, said in a taped interview that was part of the association's investigation that his bosses ordered him back to work after he was jolted by electricity while using faulty equipment. He can no longer work, he said, because the shock left him with chest pain and muscle spasms. He also has difficulty concentrating, he said.
Mr. Fontaine questioned Mr. Black Bear's account, saying that records show he had suffered "a routine work injury." No manager, he said, had ordered Mr. Black Bear to work after he was hurt.
Mr. Barrera and some current workers said they had firsthand knowledge of the mistreatment and mishandling of the animals.
The employees say more than 50 piglets froze to death one night last winter after they were left on a truck overnight. Mr. Barrera said the barns do not have enough heat lamps to keep the babies warm, so they jump on top of each other in a pile under each light. Sometimes, he said, those on the bottom smother, while those on the top burn to death. 
Mr. Fontaine disagreed that such deaths were a problem. "We want as many animals to survive that can," he said.
But Marlene Covey, who worked several weeks at the farm this year caring for piglets, said employees were told to kill pigs they believed were too sick to live. "They picked them up by the hind legs and smacked their head on the floor," Mrs. Covey said.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Decline 0.3%; Industrial Output Rises 0.2% 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Total sales at retailers fell 0.3 percent in October, and industrial production increased 0.2 percent. Also, October's Producer Price Index rose 0.8 percent, more than forecast, and consumer confidence jumped this month -- all according to reports issued yesterday. 
 Total purchases at retailers fell 0.3 percent last month, to $318.5 billion, after a revised 0.4 percent decrease in September, the Commerce Department said. Excluding auto dealers, sales rose 0.2 percent, the same as September. 
 Economists had forecast total retail sales would fall 0.2 percent last month, according to a Bloomberg News survey.
Furniture sales rose 1 percent, the government said. Receipts at restaurants and bars gained 1.9 percent, and those at building materials stores climbed 1.6 percent. Falling gasoline prices contributed to a 1.6 percent decline in sales at service stations.
Industrial production, the Federal Reserve's measure of work done at factories, mines and utilities, rose 0.2 percent afterincreasing a revised 0.5 percent in September. The forecast was for an increase of 0.4 percent. Excluding automobiles, industrial production advanced 0.5 percent in October.
The share of industrial capacity in use increased to 75 percent from 74.8 percent, the Fed report said.
According to the Fed, the index was restrained by a "large decline" in output of autos and parts, which fell 3.8 percent from the previous month.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index rose to 93.5 this month, the highest since May 2002,
The 0.8 percent increase in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index was the biggest since March and more than the median forecast for a 0.2 percent rise. Excluding volatile food and energy prices, the so-called core index rose 0.5 percent, also the largest in seven months.
Raw material prices are rising as companies try to meet demand and replace inventories and as demand increases for raw materials in other parts of the world like China. Prices for crude goods used at the earliest stages of production rose 2.6 percent.
"The recovery, tenuous at first, has finally begun to gain momentum," said Anthony Santomero, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. He said the Fed had no need to raise its benchmark interest rate "in the near future" because there was little inflation and still too much factory capacity.
Company and consumer spending may help the economy expand at a 4 percent annual rate in the year's final three months after growth of 7.2 percent last quarter, which was the fastest in almost two decades. While slower, this quarter's pace would still exceed the average of 3.6 percent during the record 10-year expansion from 1991 to 2001.

HEADLINE: Modest Goals For Meeting On Free Trade 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
After the collapse of global trade talks in Cancun, Mexico, trade ministers gathering in Miami on Sunday to discuss creating a free trade area for the Americas have scaled back their ambitions, hoping to avoid another debacle.
 Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative and co-chairman of the Miami meeting, said on Friday that the goal now was to agree "on a framework for pragmatic moves in the months ahead." By the end of the week, he said, there is a good possibility that the 34 countries of North and South America will sign a common declaration. 
 This, however, is a far cry from hopes raised last month at lower-level negotiations in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad, that the countries could agree in Miami on substantive issues as well as a framework. 
But in this election season, the ministers' debates could be overshadowed by protesters hoping to turn the event into a referendum on free trade in the United States, nearly 10 years after the signing of the North America Free Trade Agreement.
This will be the first high-level trade meeting held in the United States since the 1999 meeting of the World Trade Organization in Seattle that dissolved into a melee, with protesters battling police, 500 people arrested and $3 million in property damage.
But neither the demonstrators nor the organizers expect wild violence in the streets or a breakdown of the talks this time. The tone is expected to be more sober and the issues much closer to home.
In Seattle, environmentalists dressed up as exotic sea turtles to protest the poor regulation of fishing fleets, but the demonstrators in Miami will be unemployed union members dressed as themselves, protesting the absence of basic labor standards in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Inside the negotiating chambers in Miami, the ministers are expected to avoid outright battles over the prickly issues that have divided the United States and Brazil, the other co-chairman. 
There will be no direct confrontation over Brazilian demands that the United States lower its agriculture subsidies, which the United States says can only be negotiated through the World Trade Organization. Developing nations led by Brazil, China, India and more than a dozen other nations created a new, muscular negotiating bloc at the recent Cancun talks dedicated to convincing rich nations to reduce or eliminate their agricultural subsidies.
Instead of negotiating American demands that the nations adopt new rules for intellectual property rights, foreign investment and government procurement, the negotiators will discuss how comprehensive an agreement they want, whether there will be special treatment for smaller countries and whether countries that refuse to adopt certain parts of an agreement should be penalized with less access to markets.
The Florida citrus and sugar industries want to block any discussion of lowering tariffs that now protect their products, saying agricultural tariffs as well as subsidies can be negotiated only at the W.T.O. Robert Coker, senior vice president for public affairs at the United States Sugar Corporation, said the "agricultural consensus could break down" if the tariffs were part of the agenda.
And since Miami is competing with Panama to become the headquarters of a future Free Trade Area of the Americas, the Miami police are taking extraordinary precautions to ensure an orderly event.
But the unhappy home front is expected to be represented by tens of thousands of protesters who have already begun arriving in Miami. They include union members, religious groups, farmers, students, environmentalists and some elected officials, nearly all Democrats, who say they believe that Nafta has broken its promise to lift the living standards for many American families.
Most of all they blame Nafta for a loss of jobs that will never come back.
"We really feel that the record is clear after 10 years that Nafta has failed American and Mexican workers," said John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., in an interview. "Even in the face of devastating job losses, the Bush administration is forging ahead with these negotiations."
The unions' demands that labor rights -- to organize and bargain collectively and to prohibit child labor and discrimination -- are absent so far from the trade agenda. But the unions will be part of informal discussions about the terms of trade with other activists and nongovernmental organizations.
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, said that he was upset by what he called the arrogance of the Bush administration for failing to listen to critics and warned that any new trade agreement would face a tough fight in Congress.
"They've got blinders on and cotton in their ears," he said. "If they don't face up to the critical labor issues, they are headed for a fall."
Through a spokesman, Mr. Zoellick said that in all trade agreements the United States did ask its trading partners to enforce all of the pivotal labor standards. 
The rest of the world is now taking a second look at the administration's trade record. After this week's ruling by the W.T.O. that United States steel tariffs are illegal, the Bush administration wants to reassert its credentials as a global leader in free trade.
In that pursuit, Mr. Zoellick joined forces with Celso Amorim, the Brazilian foreign minister and co-chairman of the meeting, and last week the two men agreed to disagree. 
But Mr. Zoellick said on Friday that he and Mr. Amorim were still at loggerheads over the idea of benefits commensurate with responsibilities.
This, for example, would allow a country like Brazil to decide against agreeing to new laws on intellectual property rights in the hemisphere, but would curtail the benefits Brazil would receive from the further opening of markets that did, like the United States.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Economic Reports Cause Leading Indexes to Move Lower

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wall Street sank yesterday as investors sifted through a series of downbeat economic reports, but drug makers, including Johnson & Johnson and Merck, got a lift as Congress neared an agreement on Medicare prescription legislation. 
 The economic reports included a drop in consumer spending, which followed a glum holiday season forecast from Wal-Mart Stores on Thursday, and an uptick in inflation at the wholesale level during October. 
 "Advance retail sales weren't so good," said Brian Williamson, an equity trader at the Boston Company Asset Management. "Retailers are a little worried about holiday shopping; they're worried about their profits; so, this number confirmed what we saw yesterday." 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 69.26 points, or 0.7 percent, to close at 9,768.68, losing 0.4 percent for the week.
The Nasdaq composite index declined 37.09 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,930.26, for a weekly loss of 2.1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 8.06 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,050.35, for a weekly decline of 0.3 percent.
This was the market's first down week in three. It registered moderate declines four days out of five amid concerns about the economy, but had a solid advance on Wednesday during a brief burst of optimism about high-technology sales.
A Commerce Department report yesterday showed that Americans cut their spending in October, depressing retail sales for a second consecutive month. The news added to investor concerns that arose Thursday when Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, said that it was cautious about the outlook for the fourth quarter.
Mr. Williamson said that investors were also concerned that interest rates could go up faster than expected after a government report suggested inflation was on the rise. The Labor Department said wholesale prices were up 0.8 percent in October, the largest increase in seven months. Economists forecast a rise of just 0.2 percent.
A turnaround in inflation could motivate the Federal Reserve to raise rates.
Also, the Fed reported that industrial production rose 0.2 percent in October, down from a 0.5 percent gain in September. October's increase was half what economists expected.
Some positive news came from a survey by the University of Michigan, which found that consumers were more optimistic about the economy. The university's consumer sentiment index increased to 93.5 for the first half of November, according to Dow Jones Newswires. Wall Street had expected a mid-November reading of 91.0.
Although stocks ended the day with declines, investors were not altogether discouraged. The major indexes managed gains for part of the session, and analysts were pleased that the drop was not more severe.
"We've had a good run, so seeing the market react this way is very positive," Bob Dickey, managing director of technical analysis at RBC Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis, said. "I think the big thing people are missing here is that earnings have been improving the last six quarters in a row, and that is what's driving this market. The overriding fact is optimism is growing."
Pharmaceutical stocks had gains as Congressional negotiations on a $400 billion Medicare drug plan appeared close to a conclusion. Johnson & Johnson ended the day up $2.02, at $52.12. Merck was up 78 cents, at $46.58.
Portal Software fell $6.86, to $8.40, after cutting its forecast for next year, to the disappointment of analysts. J.P. Morgan downgraded the company, a business software maker, to underweight from neutral.
Dell lost 40 cents, to $35.24, after reporting a 21 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, largely on growth in European and Asian markets. The results matched analyst expectations.
Liberty Media ended the day down 3 cents, at $10, after reporting an 86 percent rise in third-quarter net income, mostly because of new revenue from QVC Inc.
In the bond market, the 10-year Treasury note rose 8/32, to a price of 100 8/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 4.22 percent from 4.27 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 24/32, to 104 23/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.05 percent from 5.11 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: ACCORD REACHED BY REPUBLICANS FOR ENERGY BILL 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Congressional Republicans announced Friday that they had agreed on wide-ranging national energy legislation that would provide billions of dollars in tax breaks for power producers and impose new standards intended to reduce the chances of blackouts like the one that hit the Northeast and Midwest last summer.
 The proposal, which the Republican leadership will try to push through Congress next week, was stripped of a provision that would have opened the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration. But that victory for conservation groups did not quiet critics who consider the measure -- the first major energy bill in a decade -- too generous to the oil and gas industry and lacking in proposals to promote energy efficiency. 
 Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico and chairman of the conference committee resolving differences between the House and Senate bills, acknowledged that the measure, drafted almost exclusively by Republicans, was bound to attract criticism. But Mr. Domenici said it would help the nation increase and diversify its energy sources, ease a growing dependence on natural gas and improve the aging electrical transmission grid. 
"We did a total reform of the electricity laws in the country," Mr. Domenici said. "We are very hopeful that what we have done will, over time, minimize if not avoid blackouts like the one we had in New York."
The voluminous measure, the passage of which would be a victory for President Bush, was scheduled to be made public on Saturday. Lawmakers and senior aides said the electricity section would impose new mandatory reliability standards on large electricity providers. It would allow utilities to decide whether to join regional transmission organizations that some experts believe could help reduce the risk of widespread power failures. The federal government will also be given the authority to designate the routes of new high-voltage lines of "national significance" if states and local governments cannot settle land disputes. 
The measure does not go as far as the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission had proposed in its initiative to standardize the electrical grid nationwide, a plan that utilities in the South and Northwest lobbied hard to keep out of the measure. But industry and federal officials said the enactment of an energy law would spur investment in upgrading the transmission infrastructure. 
Authors of the bill agreed to double the use of corn-based ethanol as a gasoline additive, a provision viewed as essential to building political support among farm state legislators. As part of that deal, producers of the additive MTBE, which has been blamed for groundwater pollution in many parts of the country, would gain immunity from product liability lawsuits and the substance would be banned nationwide as of 2015. The MTBE provision was a priority of Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, and other lawmakers from Louisiana and Texas, where MTBE is produced. 
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has threatened to filibuster the energy measure over the MTBE provision, which he called the "worst break for polluters" he had seen in two decades in Congress. But it was unclear whether enough Democrats would object to the measure to prevent it moving forward. 
Energy legislation has been a chief goal of the Bush administration, and passage of the measure would be a victory for President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney, who headed an energy task force early in 2001 and came under criticism for conducting much of its business in secret. Mr. Cheney personally interceded in the Congressional talks when they became snagged on tax policy. Late Friday night, the White House issued a statement by President Bush in which he said that he applauded the conferees for reaching an agreement on the measure.
"A good energy bill is part of my six-point economic plan to create the conditions for job creation and a sustained recovery," the president said in his statement. "By making America less reliant on foreign sources of energy, we also will make our nation more secure."
But the outlook for the measure was uncertain, mainly in the Senate, where Democrats are angry that they were not allowed a role in the negotiations. Some Republicans were unhappy with the emerging bill as well. In a letter this week to Mr. Domenici, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, raised several concerns about the direction of the measure, and other Republicans from the Northeast have indicated they will oppose it.
Lobbyists and lawmakers said the key to passage might be the Democratic leader, Senator Tom Daschle, who has pushed the ethanol plan to benefit corn growers in his home state, South Dakota, and across the Midwest. If Mr. Daschle supports the measure, they say, the threat of a filibuster will fade.
"I'm not going to pop any Champagne corks until we finish our conference meeting next week, until the House votes and the Senate votes," said Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana and the chief House negotiator on the measure.
Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, the senior Democrat on the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, said he would be reviewing the measure over the weekend to figure out which way his colleagues should vote.
"I think we are being asked to take it or leave it," said Mr. Bingaman, who said the fact that Arctic drilling was not included was not enough to let the bill pass. "The old adage, 'It could have been worse,' is not an adequate judgment for people to vote for it."
Though Mr. Domenici and Mr. Tauzin said they would present the measure to a full House-Senate conference committee on Monday, Republican tax writers were still working out some final details Friday, and no price tag for the tax incentives was available. But the bill was expected to provide $18 billion or more in tax breaks to promote greater use of coal in power plants, to renew interest in nuclear power, to encourage oil companies to drill in deep waters in the Gulf of Mexico and to expand the generation of power through wind, among other things.
The measure apparently does not include a provision sought by Mr. Bingaman and others to require electricity producers to increase their use of renewable fuels, nor does it institute new auto mileage standards that advocates say could significantly lower petroleum consumption.
Knowing they will come under fire for the wide benefits the measure grants to the energy industry in the form of tax breaks, research projects, incentives for a new natural gas pipeline from Alaska and easing of regulatory requirements, Republican authorson Friday began promoting the capacity of the measure to create hundreds of thousands of jobs. "This is, in essence, a jobs bill," Mr. Tauzin said. 
Environmental organizations immediately attacked the measure as a special interest grab bag for the nation's energy companies. An official of the League of Conservation Voters called it "bad for the environment, bad for public health and bad for American taxpayers." Another group, Public Citizen, warned that the repeal of the almost 70-year-old Public Utility Holding Company Act, as proposed in the bill, would allow corporations and investment banks to acquire utilities and could lead to more "Enron-style scandals."
The proposal does not include a controversial plan to conduct an inventory of oil and gas reserves in coastal areas now off limits to drilling, though Mr. Tauzin said he would pursue that separately.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Pete V. Domenici and Representative Billy Tauzin getting ready for a news conference yesterday on energy legislation. Details of the bill, drafted almost exclusively by Republicans, are to be made public today. (Photo by Doug Mills/The New York Times) Chart: "AT ISSUE: The New Energy Bill"Some highlights of the agreement on energy legislation announced yesterday by House and Senate Republican negotiators: TAX INCENTIVES -- Provides more than $18 billion in tax incentives, most to boost development of oil, natural gas, coal and nuclear power. The bill's final language and details on many of its provisions have not yet been released. ELECTRICITY GRID -- Imposes reliability standards and penalties on the transmission system for the first time. The federal government will also be given the authority to designate the routes of those transmission lines that are of "national significance" if local governments and states cannot agree on their paths. ELECTRIC UTILITIES -- Repeals the Public Utility Holding Company Act, a 1935 law that strictly regulates the business dealings of multistate holding companies that operate electric utilities. GAS ADDITIVES -- Doubles the use of corn-based ethanol as a gasoline additive, a boon to farm states. As part of that deal, producers of the additive MTBE, which has been blamed for ground water pollution, would win immunity from product liability lawsuits, though MTBE would be banned nationwide as of 2015. NEW PIPELINE -- Includes tax subsidies to encourage the construction of a $20 billion natural gas pipeline from Alaska to Chicago. What's not in the bill President's proposal to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling. Plan to conduct an inventory of oil and gas reserves in coastal areas now off-limits to drilling. Requirements that electricity producers steadily increase their use of renewable fuels. New requirements to improve auto mileage standards. (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction 

BYLINE:  By Eric P. Nash 

 BODY:
 BEHIND THE GATES
Life, Security and the Pursuit
of Happiness in Fortress America.
By Setha Low.
Routledge, $26.
 The anthropologist Setha Low first became aware of exclusionary communities growing up in the Westwood Village section of Los Angeles in the 1950's, when a schoolmate's mother would not allow her into her house because she was Jewish. Low writes in "Behind the Gates" that the covenants, contracts and deed restrictions of private housing associations have replaced the social contract in American life. Homeowners' associations, condos and co-ops are metastasizing across the country. In 1970, only 1 percent of housing units were governed by such rules; today, half of all new metropolitan units are part of this "social revolution in governance," Low writes. Suburban gated communities are the most striking example: one-third of all new communities in Southern California are gated, and in Tampa, four of five new homes worth more than $300,000 are within gates. But what are these people trying to wall out? Their motives include "fear of crime and others," Low writes, as well as desire for security and "niceness," but the main anxiety is disappearing from the middle class altogether. "The gates are used symbolically," Low concludes, "to ward off many of life's unknowns, including unemployment, loss of loved ones, and downward mobility." The "symbolic arrival" of a house in the suburbs is no longer enough; class lines must now be fortified. Las Vegas, one of the nation's fastest-growing metropolitan regions, may be a portent of Fortress America: a ring of gated enclaves circling a dead city core. Eric P. Nash.
