HEADLINE: CHOICE TABLES; 
Tasting Korea in Los Angeles

BYLINE:  By MARK BITTMAN; MARK BITTMAN writes for the Dining section of The Times.

 BODY:
LOS ANGELES has one of the largest Korean-American populations in North America. Its Koreatown contains countless restaurants, most with strikingly similar menus. Sorting through them takes a combination of trial and error, word of mouth and luck. 
 Not exactly torture, since the flavors of Korean food are widely appealing; I like to think of it as Japanese food with guts. There is little subtlety here, because Koreans favor garlic, chilies, sesame oil and soy sauce, and use all of them liberally. 
 Furthermore, eating Korean barbecue -- table-grilled meat, fish and vegetables -- is an enjoyable process in which everyone can cook; all but one of the restaurants below are equipped with built-in tabletop grills. 
In Los Angeles, some attempt has been made to bring Korean food into the larger community. Woo Lae Oak, a small chain (with a branch in SoHo), has a gorgeous restaurant on La Cienega in Beverly Hills, a major street that also features a Tony Roma's, Lawry's and Benihana. Here you can listen to trip-hop, be served by hip young people speaking perfect English, look at a wine list and eat soulless Korean food. 
At the restaurants below, in contrast, the service is often brusque, the music terrible, the desserts practically nonexistent, and the beverages of choice soju, a kind of mild vodka flavored with either lemon or cucumber, or beer -- usually OB, the popular Korean brew. The food, however, is terrific. 

Chosun Galbee
Probably the best place in Los Angeles to initiate people into Korean cuisine, it is less showy than Woo Lae Oak, but it is good looking -- clean, modern and altogether pleasant. 
Yet from the parking lot it looks much like a fortress, giving no indication of the treasures within. There is an outside eating area, tree-lined, spacious and airy, with arched steel ribs supporting a roof of corrugated fiberglass to provide shade. The open sides allow a breeze, and, as a result, afternoon eating is comfortably temperate. 
The tables are made of granite, the floor of slate, and the overall impression is gallery-like. The more modest interior is also stripped down, with granite tables, white walls, and white tablecloths. 
Service is helpful though certain practices are disconcerting -- plates are almost never changed from one course to the next, service plates are rarely cleared from the table, napkins are scarce and made of paper. Nonetheless there is more contact between server and customer than in many Korean restaurants. 
The food is not unusual but it's very good. If the spices have been toned down a bit too much for my taste, the quality of the ingredients is stepped up. On a hot summer day, we started with a cold, bright red kimchi soup (kimchi, a spicy pickled cabbage, is a staple of Korean homes and restaurants). This was followed by the standard array of little plates known as panchan (think of them as a series of amuses-bouches), including cold broccoli with chili-bean paste, bean sprouts with sesame, sauteed fish cakes, pickled garlic with cold boiled beef, potato salad (yes, mayonnaise and all), and kimchi. 
The barbecue reflects the growing tendency to offer diners more than the usual selection of different cuts of beef that, until quite recently, was all that was grilled in Korean restaurants. Here, in addition to galbee (boneless short ribs) and other cuts of beef, there are chicken, shrimp and pork. All are handled the same way: you use tongs or chopsticks to turn the meat (if you appear helpless, a server will assist), and then fold the grilled meat into a large leaf of romaine lettuce, along with shredded scallions, soy sauce, bean sauce, a bit of rice and, if you like, garlic and jalapenos. This you eat with your hands. 
Dishes cooked in the kitchen excel. Bright red spicy noodles, served cold with raw skate, were just short of searingly hot, although served ice cold, mushy and crunchy; I couldn't get enough of these. Chop chae (glass noodles with meat and vegetables) was as good as any I've had. Dol sot bi bim bop, rice with a variety of meat, vegetables, and egg, is cooked in a stone pot until the bottom is browned, then combined with chili-bean paste to taste; it was perfect here. 

YongSuSan
 You could write what I know about the history of Korean food on the back of a postage stamp, so when YongSuSan's Web site reports that the restaurant "serves the Kaesong fare of the ancient Koryo Dynasty which was the golden era of Korean cuisine," I have to take their word for it. 
What I do know is that, as a nearly lifelong fan of Korean food, I was blown away when a friend sent me here five years ago, saying it was unlike any Korean food he'd ever eaten. 
He was right. Not only is YongSuSan unusual, it is sensational. It's a place I've delighted in introducing to other people, even though with its hokey color scheme and ultra-bright lighting, it isn't immediately appealing. 
The restaurant is broken up into a dozen or more small rooms, many private. If you show up without a reservation, or on your own, you're likely to be shepherded into the largest room, an unimpressive communal dining room. 
Many nights, however, most customers, whether couples or a large party, wind up in a private room, depriving you of the buzz of a busy restaurant but providing such pleasures as privacy and very personal service. Furthermore, there are real tablecloths, real napkins and reasonably attentive service.
You may order a la carte, but I've never seen anyone do so. There are several fixed-price menus, with escalating levels of luxury and cost, and I usually go for one in the middle of the pack. 
On my most recent visit I started off with a sweet, earthy, superthick butternut squash soup and a more-than-passable European-style salad. Then came a few paired and contrasting dishes: a sharp pile of shredded carrots and beansprouts with chilies and raw garlic, teamed with a mild, sweet mound of sesame-flavored mung bean noodles. Fatty steamed pork was served with kimchi and a vinegar dipping sauce; next to it was a plate of shredded cucumber with jellyfish, a 1,000-year egg (hard-cooked in soy sauce and spices), a little beef, and a lot of wasabi. 
The prized, intensely spicy whole-cabbage kimchi, essentially a globe of fire, was next, served with the taming influences of chop chae, at room temperature. Beautifully fried shrimp in egg batter with zucchini coins pressed into it followed, along with fried petrale sole, a West Coast variety. 
Continuing the pattern, all the dishes were fairly small, many without sauces and quite mild: tiny, hand-rolled, multicolored crepes with shredded vegetables and meat; a skewer of mushrooms, scallops, and broccoli; a small but lovely round of panchan, including black beans and dried sweet-and-spicy fish; and finally, perfectly cooked galbee, not done at the table, but in the kitchen. 

Seoul Garden
Known for its great shabu-shabu, Seoul Garden also offers a few very authentic dishes that alone make it worth the visit. This was my first (and to date, only) meal here, but I went with a small crowd and we ate through most of the menu. 
Seoul Garden is not inspiring looking: One of my companions called it "modern-traditional Home Depot special." Aside from a brilliantly backlit sign depicting how exactly to deal with shabu-shabu (not that you couldn't figure it out yourself), and the fact that 90 percent of the customers are Korean, you might think that you had stumbled into Pat's Kountry Kitchen in Smithtown, U.S.A. 
Never mind. The granite tables are well-equipped with powerful burners, and the $16.50 shabu-shabu special is quite a lot of fun. You are provided with a pot of simmering broth and a huge plate of thin-sliced beef, watercress, tofu and mushrooms, all of which you cook yourself; a sesame-lemon dipping sauce helps boost the flavor. Once you've finished that, the server cooks some noodles in the now gloriously scented broth. When those are done, the broth gets thickened with rice and egg. It's an experience, but it was not the gastronomic highlight of the evening. 
That honor belonged to other dishes. The cold spicy noodles, cut up with scissors, are superb. Grilled eel, Japanese style, is perfect, and served in the quantity you want (lots) but don't get in a sushi setting. Raw crab marinated in chili paste, perhaps the messiest dish in the world (you must use your fingers, and the sauce is plentiful and runny) is, for those energetic and adventurous enough to try it, quite rewarding and worth the work. Black cod in a dark, spicy sauce, which is served at most of the restaurants I visited, was very good here. 
The high point followed a dish of meat seared on a metal pan (another do-it-yourselfer), with onions and butter. The meat itself is unexciting but, when we finished, the server took the leftovers and combined them with a few vegetables, sesame oil, chili paste and cooked rice, making a flat cake on the pan. Sitting over fairly high heat, it waited while my party drank soju and beer and finished up the scraps of other dishes. After a while, we simply began scraping the now-crusty rice off the pan. Not exactly dessert, but a great meal-ender. 

Sa Rit Gol
This is the joint that the in-the-know people -- both Korean-Americans and local food hounds -- will send you to. Part of its charm is its lack of same; not to put too fine a point on it, the dark wood walls have a nice patina of greasy smoke, doorbells ring when diners want to summon waiters, the booths are not especially comfortable, and the service is rude and hasty. 
Having said all that, I've never regretted a visit here, and at each I have eaten memorably good food. The panchan -- which, to me, are the heart and soul of a good Korean restaurant-- are the best of any at the restaurants discussed here: there are pickled onions in sesame; boiled beef with jalapenos; tofu in chili; mustard greens; mook (a kind of starchy jelly made from a root vegetable, something everyone should sample at least once); and, on my recent visit, a kimchi prepared with scallion roots, as economical a dish as has ever been made. 
The tabletop cooking is also first-rate, especially the boneless short ribs, which are cut lengthwise here to make a long strip. Strips of beef breast, cooked on a steel skillet with oyster mushrooms and onions, are another winner.
But it is the kitchen-simmered dishes that really shine. A highly spiced beef and tofu stew with lentils would alone satisfy me on most occasions. I couldn't stop eating the rice cooked in a stone pot with kimchi, and the huge portion of black cod, with a boatload of root vegetables, would be considered haute cuisine in another setting. 

Bill of fare

HEADLINE: 13 Visiting Queen Mary 2 Die in Accident 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
What was planned as a day of celebration turned to tragedy on Saturday when a gangway with about 50 relatives and friends of workmen on the Queen Mary 2 collapsed, killing at least 13 people. 
 At least 32 people were injured, police and fire officials said. Early reports said several children were among the dead but officials said later that was not confirmed. 
 The accident occurred at dockside in the sprawling shipyards in St.-Nazaire, in western France, where workmen have been putting the finishing touches on the 1,132-foot Queen Mary 2, the largest and costliest vessel ever built. The deputy prefect of St.-Nazaire, Jean-Marc Falcone, said the gangway had been installed on Friday especially for the weekend visits. 
The liner is being constructed for $800 million by the French shipbuilder Alstom Marine for the Cunard Line, now a unit of the Carnival Corporation. In September, the ship underwent two trial runs in the North Atlantic, and returned Tuesday. The vast liner, which will carry up to 2,620 passengers on its first Atlantic crossing in January, from Southampton, England, to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was open this weekend for visits by family members of the workmen, from at least 800 companies, who have been installing cabins and swimming pools, a spa and a planetarium and restaurants. 
It remained unclear what caused the gangway to come loose at least 30 feet above the dockside. A shipyard official, Philippe Kasse, said about 50 people were on the gangway when it collapsed, most of them family members and children of the shipyard workers.
The accident is the latest blow for Alstom, which nearly collapsed earlier this year from a cash shortage before the French government bailed it out.
Alstom was awash in orders in the 1990's as the North American cruise market exploded, and cruise lines ordered dozens of vessels at European shipyards, which were seeking to overcome competition from low-cost shipbuilding yards in South Korea and Japan by specializing in high-value vessels like cruise liners.
But the luxury segment of the cruise industry weakened sharply as the souring of the global economy, the war in Iraq and fears of terrorist attacks and diseases like SARS took their toll on the travel industry.
After trips to Florida, the Caribbean and South America next winter, the QM2 will make its inaugural voyage to New York in April, where it will join the Queen Elizabeth 2, the Cunard liner it is intended to replace. 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 16 about a fatal gangway collapse on the Queen Mary 2 at St.-Nazaire in western France referred imprecisely to the ship's ranking. At 1,132 feet in length and a cost of $800 million, it is the largest and costliest of passenger vessels, but not of vessels over all.

HEADLINE: For Middle Class, Health Insurance Becomes a Luxury 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: DALLAS 

 BODY:
The last time Kevin Thornton had health insurance was three years ago, which was not much of a problem until he began having trouble swallowing.
 "I broke down earlier this year and went in and talked to a doctor about it," said Mr. Thornton, who lives in Sherman, about 60 miles north of Dallas. 
 A barium X-ray cost him $130, and the radiologist another $70, expenses he charged to his credit cards. The doctor ordered other tests that Mr. Thornton simply could not afford. 
"I was supposed to go back after the X-ray results came, but I decided just to live with it for a while," he said. "I may just be a walking time bomb."
Mr. Thornton, 41, left a stable job with good health coverage in 1998 for a higher salary at a dot-com company that went bust a few months later. Since then, he has worked on contract for various companies, including one that provided insurance until the project ended in 2000. "I failed to keep up the payments that would have been required to maintain my coverage," he said. "It was just too much money."
Mr. Thornton is one of more than 43million people in the United States who lack health insurance, and their numbers are rapidly increasing because of ever soaring cost and job losses. Many states, including Texas, are also cutting back on subsidies for health care, further increasing the number of people with no coverage.
The majority of the uninsured are neither poor by official standards nor unemployed. They are accountants like Mr. Thornton, employees of small businesses, civil servants, single working mothers and those working part time or on contract.
"Now it's hitting people who look like you and me, dress like you and me, drive nice cars and live in nice houses but can't afford $1,000 a month for health insurance for their families," said R. King Hillier, director of legislative relations for Harris County, which includes Houston.
Paying for health insurance is becoming a middle-class problem, and not just here. "After paying for health insurance, you take home less than minimum wage," says a poster in New York City subways sponsored by Working Today, a nonprofit agency that offers health insurance to freelancers, cabdrivers and other types of independent contractors in New York. "Welcome to middle-class poverty." In Southern California, 70,000 supermarket workers have been on strike for five weeks over plans to cut their health benefits.
The insurance crisis is especially visible in Texas, which has the highest proportion of uninsured in the country -- almost one in every four residents. The state has a large population of immigrants; its labor market is dominated by low-wage service sector jobs, and it has a higher than average number of small businesses, which are less likely to provide health benefits because they pay higher insurance costs than large companies.
State cuts to subsidies for health insurance to help close a $10 billion budget gap will cost the state $500 million in federal matching money and are expected to further spur the rise in uninsured. In September, for example, more than half a million children enrolled in a state- and federal-subsidized insurance program lost dental, vision and most mental care coverage, and some 169,000 children will lose all insurance by 2005. 
"These were tough economic times that the legislature was dealing with, and the governor believed in setting the tone for the legislative session that the government must operate the way Texas families do and Texas businesses do and live within its means," said Kathy Walt, spokeswoman for Gov. Rick Perry.
She noted that the legislature raised spending on health and human services by $1 billion this year, and that lawmakers passed two bills intended to make it easier for small businesses to provide health insurance for their employees.
Those measures, however, will not help Theresa Pardo or other Texas residents like her who have to make tough choices about medical care they need but cannot afford.
Ms. Pardo, a 29-year-old from Houston, said that having no insurance meant choosing between buying an inhaler for her 9-year-old asthmatic daughter or buying her a birthday present. The girl, Morgan, lost her state-subsidized insurance last month, and now her mother must pay $80 instead of $5 for the inhaler. Rent, car payments and insurance, day care and utilities cost Ms. Pardo more than $1,200 a month, leaving less than $200 for food, gas and other expenses. So even though her employer, the Harris County government, provides her with low-cost insurance, she cannot afford the additional $275 a month she would have to pay to add her daughter to her plan. 
When Morgan's dentist recently wanted to pull a tooth, Ms. Pardo hesitated. The tooth extraction proceeded, but: "I had to ask him, if you pull this tooth, will it cause other problems? Because if it does, I can't afford to deal with them."
Lorenda Stevenson said her choice was between buying medicine to treat patches of peeling, flaking skin on her hands, arms and face and making sure her son could continue his after-school tennis program. "There's no way I will cut that out unless we don't have money for food," she said.
Mrs. Stevenson's husband, Bill, lost his management job at WorldCom two years ago, when an accounting scandal forced the company into bankruptcy. They managed to pay $900 a month for Cobra, the government policy that allows workers to continue their coverage after they lose their jobs, but when the cost rose to $1,200, they could no longer afford it.
When their son, a ninth grader, needed a physical and shot to take tennis, Mrs. Stevenson turned to the Rockwall Area Health Clinic, a nonprofit clinic in Rockwall, a city of 13,000 northeast of Dallas. The clinic charged her $20 instead of the $400 she estimated she would have paid at the doctor's office.
"I sat filling out the paperwork and crying," she said, tears streaming down her face. "I was so embarrassed to bring him here."
A salve to treat her skin condition costs $27, and she pays roughly $50 a month for medications for high blood pressure and hormones. She does without medication she needs for acid reflux, treating the conditions sporadically with samples from the clinic. 
Carol Johnston cannot afford even doctor visits. A single mother living in Houston, she lost her job in health care administration in May and she said she was still unemployed despite filling out 500 to 600 applications and attending countless job fairs.
Cobra would have cost $214 a month, or more than one-fifth of the $1,028 in unemployment she gets a month. As it is, her monthly bills for rent, car, utilities and phone exceed her income.
She got a 12-month deferral on her student loans, and Ford pushed her car payments back by two months. The Johnstons rely on television for entertainment and almost never use air-conditioning, despite Houston's muggy, hot climate.
Now Ms. Johnston's 16-year-old son is losing the portion of his insurance that covered treatment for his learning and emotional disabilities because of state cutbacks. 
Ms. Johnston herself does not qualify for Medicaid, the government insurance program for the indigent, because her income is too high, the same reason she qualifies for only $10 a month in food stamps.
"I worry, I worry so much about making sure my son is safe," she said. 
As for her own health, Ms. Johnston has two cysts in one breast and three in another but has had only one aspirated because she cannot afford to check on the others. "Do I have to move to Iraq to get help?" she asked. "They have $87 billion for folks over there," she said, referring to money Congress allocated for military operations and rebuilding. 
Experts warn that allowing health problems to fester is only going to increase the costs of providing health care for the uninsured. "As Americans, when are we going to realize it's cheaper to save them on the front end than when they get cancer and show up in the emergency room?" said Sandra B. Thurman, executive director of PediPlace, a nonprofit health clinic in Lewisville, Tex.
Many hospitals and neighborhood clinics here say that the well-heeled are now joining the poor in seeking their care. Emergency rooms are particularly hard hit, since federal law requires them to treat anyone who walks through their doors for emergency treatment, regardless of whether they can pay. 
Public hospital emergency rooms are even harder hit, since private hospitals will move quickly to shift uninsured patients to them. And clinics for the poor are also seeing an increase in demand.
A clinic run by Central Dallas Ministries charges patients $5 for a doctor visit, $10 for medication and $15 if laboratory work is needed, but often settles for no payment from many of the 3,500 patients it treats each year.
"I'm not real optimistic it will get a lot better," said Larry Morris James, executive director of Central Dallas Ministries. "Demographic and economic trends tell you that it's probably going to get worse."
For Irma Arellano, the problem has already hit home. Mrs. Arellano is a secretary in the Royse school district northeast of Dallas, which provides her health insurance for $35 a month but offers no discounts for her three children or husband.
Two years ago, the Arellanos paid $269 a month to insure the family. The price jumped last year to $339 and this year to $780, more than their monthly mortgage payment.
Her husband works for a small landscaping company that does not offer insurance. So Mrs. Arellano is insured, but her husband, Jose, and their three children -- Jackie, 16; Joe, 15; and Anthony, 13 -- are going without insurance.
The Arellanos' income, which ranges from $2,800 to $3,200 a month, makes them ineligible for state-subsidized insurance. Their basic expenses run $2,000 a month or more.
"I'm one of those people in the middle," Mrs. Arellano said. "We don't make enough to pay for insurance ourselves, but we make too much to qualify for CHIP," the government-subsidized program for children.
So her children were recently at the Rockwall clinic for the physicals they need to participate in after-school sports, paying $25 instead of the $100 or more Mrs. Arellano would have paid at the doctor's office.
The family has catastrophic insurance, but Mrs. Arellano is uncertain how much longer she can afford it. Mr. Arellano's income typically drops in the winter, and his wife is hoping the children will then qualify for the state insurance program.
Even so, newly initiated regulations require families to reapply for the insurance every six months, rather than once a year, so they are not likely to qualify for long. 
"I'll take what I can get," Mrs. Arellano said.

HEADLINE: A Quick Swing Through Little Costa Rica 

BYLINE:  By Robert Stone 

 BODY:
The tourists appear to be blocking one lane of the coastal road outside Tarcoles, a busy thoroughfare that sees a lot of serious 18-wheelers coming and going from the Pacific port of Caldera. When the first burly local driver arrives with his rig and brakes, he appears a bit distressed. He looks thoughtfully at the bus and at the foreigners lined up along the highway. None of them, however, look at him. Their binoculars and cameras are fixed on the astonishing sight of six scarlet macaws in a nearby ceiba tree. Scarlet macaws in the wild are mind-bending, the total technicolor parrots, flaunting every color in the rainbow. To realize that we still share the ordinary world with the scarlet macaw, that it's not some kind of copyrighted entertainment phenomenon in Orlando, Fla., is to hope good things for the future.
 The truck driver puffs out his cheeks and shakes his head. The entranced bird-watchers, ogling and filming away, never glance away from the treetops. The driver carefully drives past the 20-passenger Toyota tourist bus. He isn't happy, but he doesn't take it out on the turistas. 
 Travelers in this hemisphere will know that this can only be Costa Rica, a land of great beauty with a commitment to democracy and reasonableness that has guided its history and its public life for 50 years and longer. This is not to say that, in Costa Rica, some hothead may not flatten you for bending his fender rounding some pothole on the Interamericana, or that ill will does not exist. But Costa Rica is a land of good intentions.
In Costa Rican society, the frictions of daily life are eased by humor and politeness. Relatively unused to foreigners before their ecotourist boom began in the 1990's, the egalitarian ticos still take visitors one on one, so to speak. 
In its history, Costa Rica shares much with its neighbors up the isthmus. It has at times been as impoverished as they, reduced to the mercy of foreign fruteros. With the spread of coffee cultivation in the mid-19th century, an overheated prosperity based on monoculture brought wealth to a handful of families whose descendants have traditionally served as a ruling class. It is the differences, however, that have distinguished Costa Rica in the region.
By now, Costa Rican exceptionalism is a near cliche, but it is based on some facts of life that one doesn't have to be a sociologist to recognize. This is the only country in Central America that abolished its army as a constitutional reform -- its fortified barracks overlooking San Jose are now the National Museum. It takes deep pride in a welfare state that labors to retain a nationwide social safety net in a country not unscathed by recent economic developments. 
Amazingly, this very small country, half the size of Kentucky, contains the greatest variety of plant species on earth as determined by the World Resources Institute, along with 615 separate species of bird and mammal. This abundance exceeds that of any country in Africa and proportionally rivals Brazil's. 
A few things seem worth saying about travel to this spectacularly beautiful place. One is that the national park system is the repository of its national treasure and that the best places to stay adjoin parks and adjoin them as inconspicuously and harmoniously as possible. The other, to the many people who normally do not consider traveling in groups with guides, is that easy access to national parks in Costa Rica is best afforded that way. Animals in the forest make a point of being hard to see. Guides are trained to see them and, unless one is a skilled spotter or bird-watcher, extremely helpful.
My wife, Janice, and I were part of a group of 11 Americans, all well traveled, touring under the auspices of Overseas Adventure Travel of Cambridge, Mass. Our 13-day itinerary took us generally north and west of the capital, San Jose, once descending to the edge of the Caribbean slope as far as the Sarapiqui River area and its Centro Neotropico.
The centro is an eco-tourism complex established by presidential decree in 1997 at the entrance to the Tirimbina Rainforest Preserve. It's a trip of a few hours from the capital over paved roads, almost 50 miles from the Caribbean itself but with the terrain that exemplifies the jungles on the east side of the Central American Great Divide.
At Sarapiqui there are gardens and one of the country's few anthropological sites. Maleko Indians left 70 burial sites here, along with some pottery and petroglyphs. There's a small, well-appointed anthropological museum near the site and a pleasant bar to reflect on it all while listening to howler monkeys and catching the rain-forest breezes. We were traveling in the late-summer rainy season, but our first few days were spared spectacular downpours.
The centro offers accommodation in large rooms within thatched buildings in the pre-Columbian village style. The Tirimbina preserve, 820 acres of rich tropical woodlands, is easily accessible across suspension bridges from the Sarapiqui complex. Trails lead through Tirimbina, and, for visitors who want a closer experience of the Sarapiqui River, guided white-water rafting. The rapids are fun, novice class, and along the river, creatures abound: iguanas, sloths and basilisks, along with enough exotic birds to provide regular new entries in a birder's logbook.
Our next destination was in the humid tropical forest of the Bosque de Chachagua, not far from the volcano at Arenal. We spent an hour in the town of Quesada, buying meat and vegetables to be cooked later at our hotel, a cluster of pleasant but basic cabins on a hillside. Maintaining the good will of a market stall merchant while attempting to purchase a food item you most imperfectly pronounce -- which in fact you have never tasted, which could be for all you know animal, vegetable or mineral, which in fact you would not recognize if a three-toed sloth hit you on the head with it -- is a reasonable test of a town's civility. For the patience and kindliness of the market people of Quesada -- may they long prosper in happiness.
From the hotel we made some novel expeditions -- novel at least for me. One such took us to the San Rafael de Chachagua elementary school, where Elizabeth, aged 11, made me dance the Zapateada, waving my checkered bandanna while she twirled prettily before me. Nor was I released until I had seen the sixth grade's garden, met its pets, listened to Elizabeth read "Mr. Gilligan's Pig" in resolute ingles. The children seemed delighted to entertain foreign visitors, and our group of Americans, mostly teachers, responded enthusiastically.
For lunch several of our band visited the home of one of the students. By this time we had discovered that food in Costa Rica is noticeably good, and the home-cooked meal (rice and beans, beef, hearts of palm, with coconut rice pudding for dessert) was even better. After lunch we spent part of the afternoon playing dominoes, in a fractured mixture of Spanish and English. If anyone had suggested a year before that I would spend a September afternoon playing dominoes in San Rafael de Chachagua -- I would have been, well, puzzled.
Also from Chachagua we traveled north to the great Cano Negro swamp, a vast expanse of wetlands that are known in Costa Rica as llanuras and are reminiscent of the Everglades. Much of this area is national park or wildlife reserve; it's scarcely inhabited and, being close against the Nicaraguan border, was further depopulated by the contra wars of the 1980's. The town of Los Chiles is a river port on the Rio Frio with a back-of-beyond feeling. Here boats arrive from Nicaragua with Nicaraguans applying for Costa Rican labor permits. (Several dozen were turned away by the border police the day we turned up.) At Los Chiles one can rent a boat, with a guide, to go farther into the area along the river. The shores are a mixture of private and public land; there are Brahman bulls placidly feeding in the Cano Negro, which happens to be one of the top spots in the country for reported jaguar and puma sightings. The river and its shores are teeming with life. The principal amphibian here is the innocently Pogo-esque caiman, which, sometimes achieving a snout-to-tail length of five feet, is too big to be funny. Birds migratory and specific are seen in great numbers; there are parrots and huge Amazonian kingfishers, hot blue and iridescent green mangrove swallows, white ibises and roseate spoonbills, wood storks -- a list would be pages long.
All four types of Costa Rican monkeys turn up here, the white-faced, the spider, the squirrel monkey and the ubiquitous howlers whose alpha males will soon be driven unhinged by mimicking tourists challenging their supremacy over the band. The Cano Negro is a dreamscape that leaves an imprint on the imagination: its waving grasses, punctuated by ceibas and the enormous conspiring sky, suggest infinity.
For a gently inclined, highly civilized country, Costa Rica yielded a disproportionate number of spectacular experiences, perhaps the most impressive of which was the eruption of Monte Arenal, one of the nine active volcanoes in the country. We arrived in the town of Fortuna to see the mountain that loomed in the range above us on the front page of the paper La Nacion. The night before, it had blown, spewing golden lava far down its northwestern slope, which was fortunately where it was expected, having been smoking and tossing molten rock down since 1968. The 5,357-foot Mount Arenal destroyed two villages and killed about 80 people during the 1968 eruption, and it continues to take a toll of the occasional rash tourist and guide who decide no visit there complete without going eye to Cyclopean eye with the great mountain. For two nights running, from the very comfortable, well-provisioned bar of the Volcano Lodge -- even from the terrace of our well-situated room -- we watched Arenal, when it was not covered with cloud, fume and glow with earth's fire, roaring like a fiend. The lodge, with air-conditioning, cable TV, pool and Jacuzzis from which to watch the volcano, was about the most upscale accommodation on our route.
The next day, we went over the Cordillera de Tilaran and Costa Rica's continental divide into the dry tropical forest of Guanacaste province, much of it actually open savannah that supports the culture of the sabanero. The classic sabanero is the tough mounted herdsman of these plains, known in the old cowboy way as independent, chivalrous and capable of iron endurance. Fancy saddles, good horses and skilled riding are admired and many towns in Guanacaste feature a rodeo, called a tope, where the main event is bull riding. We stayed at the Buena Vista Lodge and Adventure Center, an extensive former cattle ranch at the entrance to Rincon de la Vieja National Park, where accommodations in interconnected, motel-style buildings are basic but comfortable. Here in the drier forest the rainy season overtook us, but only intermittently.
Horses and thermal mud baths were available, but our favorite diversion was the canopy tour, an operation in which the tourist rides a wire on a kind of breeches buoy from elevated platform to elevated platform at a speed controlled by a hand brake, literally one's hand encased in a leather glove. High-minded and unexcitable persons are invited to inspect the scenery and the perspective on nature afforded by a view from the treetops. Most people, I think, succumb to the sheer kick of the thing, as we did, zooming through the branches at high speed. The monkeys we expected to hoot and jeer had apparently seen enough of human folly and failed to show themselves. But the landscape, from the high peaks of the Vieja volcano to the Pacific miles to the west, was breathtaking.
From the old port of Puntarenas, sleepy and louche in the rainy season, one may take a party boat across the Gulf of Nicoya to a point on the Nicoya Peninsula called Punta Coral, where a private reserve offers a beach with cabanas. Kayaks and snorkeling equipment were available, and an elderly gentleman, professionally know as Abuelo, played the marimba at lunch even for those whose beach toy was a hammock.
We finished near the Tarcoles River, staying again at the edge of a national park, in this case the Parque Nacional de Carara. The mangrove swamps of the world, it is now known, play an important role in the vitality of the world's oceans, and they give a home or shelter to an uncountable number of bird species. 
And, quite close up on the Tarcoles River, we watched a 13-foot crocodile challenged on the riverbank by a man armed with nothing more than a green towel. The crocodile went for it, and the sound of those jaws snapping shut is still with us.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE; 
Who's Co-Designing What for Co-Whom?

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE

 BODY:
THOUGH the ground zero matchup between David M. Childs and Daniel Libeskind is the highest-profile example, more than a few major collaborative architectural efforts are now under way in Manhattan. On West 53rd Street, Yoshio Taniguchi, the exacting Japanese modernist, is paired with the corporate workhorse firm Kohn Pedersen Fox on the expansion of the Museum of Modern Art. Nearing completion at Columbus Circle, the Time Warner Center by Mr. Childs contains Rafael Vinoly's performance spaces for Jazz at Lincoln Center, nestled inside like a marshmallow chick embedded within a chocolate egg. More recently, in a current competition for a new building at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Art and Science, Zaha Hadid, the London architect known for explosively fragmented forms, has matched up with Beyer Blinder Belle, a firm whose name has become synonymous with underachieving since its plans for ground zero were rejected by the public.
 As collaborations become so much a part of business as usual, architects are struggling to figure out terms of engagement that they can live with. At the Museum of Modern Art, the setup is fairly standard: famous out-of-town architect is attached to local stalwart who will see the job through. Mr. Taniguchi said by e-mail that he would have preferred being the sole architect. And Kohn Pedersen Fox does not normally see itself as second fiddle. 
 "For collaborations to work it is mandatory that one party work in support of the other and not compete," William Pedersen, a firm partner, said. "And so when we were asked to take on the assignment by MoMA, it raised questions in our mind. We are design architects, not production architects." They settled for "executive architect," a relatively new title that lends verbal dignity to a position somewhere between the starring role of design architect and the facilitators, known as the architects of record.
According to Robert Ivy, the editor in chief of Architectural Record, the title has come into currency recently and reflects a change in the way architects do business. "It is not just a euphemism," he said, adding that while "architect of record" implied a subservient role to the so-called design architect, "executive architect suggests an active, informed daily presence" that might include contributing to the design.
For The New York Times building on Eighth Avenue, Renzo Piano, based in Europe, is the design architect and Fox & Fowle of New York are calling themselves the co-architects, according to a spokesperson there. To confuse matters more, design publications usually refer to them as the executive architects, and sometimes name one, sometimes the other when referring to the architect of the building. The array of titles on the job, Mr. Ivy admitted, "is beginning to sound like a menu."
Not surprisingly, these partnerships are often awkward and fraught with tension. To Mr. Vinoly, the Manhattan architect, the prospect of having to collaborate on a single building with another ambitious architect would be, he said, akin to "asking two surgeons to share the scalpel when operating on a patient."
Mr. Vinoly, of course, was a member of the Think team, the group of architects -- ranging from Frederic Schwartz of Manhattan to Shigeru Ban of Tokyo -- whose design lost out to Mr. Libeskind's in the final stages of the ground zero competition. Even so, Mr. Vinoly said, he'd rather "go back to playing the piano" than share responsibility as executive architect.
Mr. Vinoly runs an office of 170 people. Size is part of his strategy to avoid undesirable collaborations, even on large-scale projects. While it no doubt takes many players to get anything built, Mr. Vinoly said that "working with other people is harder than anything else in the world and top-heavy collaborations are a recipe for disaster."
The real problem, he said, is that all too often developers opt for collaborations when they can't make up their minds about what they really want. He described the performance spaces for Jazz at Lincoln Center at Columbus Circle not as a collaboration but as a building nested within a building -- a situation that was forced on the project by Rudolph Giuliani, then mayor of New York, to provide the corporate behemoth with a public amenity.
Downtown, the 2001 collaboration of Prada's star architects -- Rem Koolhaas and Herzog & deMeuron -- on a boutique hotel for the impresario Ian Schrager in the East Village was an instant media sensation. But the design never went beyond the widely printed image of a tattooed obelisk. 
Jacques Herzog of the Swiss team Herzog & deMeuron said that his firm generally preferred joining forces with artists, rather than architects, so that "the client knows who is the boss." Still, he would welcome the chance to do it all over again with Mr. Koolhaas because he is on the "same level intellectually and artistically."
There is no architecture without collaboration, said Mr. Koolhaas, the Dutch architect who is a guru to an entire generation of intellectually aspiring architects, not to mention research assistants. Mr. Koolhaas, who is known to fly into imperious rages over artistic integrity, added that of course it works only if the partners involved are aesthetic equals as well. Mr. Koolhaas attributed the hotel collaboration's ultimate failure not to the economy, as was suggested at the time, nor to a rumored falling out with Mr. Schrager.
Instead, Mr. Koolhaas said, "Perhaps having the two of us together in one room was too overwhelming for the client."

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Pinchas Zukerman Conducts a Revival

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. OESTREICH

DATELINE: OTTAWA 

 BODY:
YOU wouldn't call him modest, exactly. Few star performers are, let alone conductors. A healthy ego is virtually part of the job description.
 But over lunch here at the National Arts Center late last month, Pinchas Zukerman, renowned violinist, violist and maestro, wanted to talk not about himself, for the most part, but about education and educational technology. To hear him tell it, he wants to educate everyone -- children, audiences, young performers and composers -- and those he can't teach in person, he wants to reach in interactive settings on the Internet. 
 "It's an educational tour as much as a concert tour," he said of his current North American trek with the National Arts Center Orchestra, which ends this afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall. It has included 10 concerts in 10 cities and 70 educational events: some combination of school visits, student matinees, lectures and master classes in each city visited, all mirroring the orchestra's extensive educational program in Ottawa and throughout Canada. 
On one level, Mr. Zukerman's reserve (almost Canadian, a brash American is tempted to say) was refreshing. Yet coming from a performer long known for a certain flamboyance and for recklessly unguarded comments in interviews, it was also something of a disappointment. Mr. Zukerman's five-year tenure as the orchestra's music director seems to have tamed him a bit. Or perhaps just made him more content.
"I was happy but not comfortable," the Israeli-born Mr. Zukerman, 55, said of life before Ottawa, which included highly publicized marriages and breakups with the flutist and television personality Eugenia Zukerman and the actress Tuesday Weld. He seems to have settled comfortably into life in this modest and charming national capital (if hardly an international musical one), largely out of the American public eye.
"It's a great city to live in," he said. He is planning his third marriage, to Amanda Forsyth, the orchestra's principal cellist. And the city as a whole seems to have taken him to its heart. He has, at any rate, played a major role in a revitalization of the arts center, spearheaded by Peter Herrndorf, who became its president in 1999.
Founded in 1969 as a national showcase for the performing arts, the National Arts Center had, by the 1990's, fallen into disarray. "We became less visionary, less creative, increasingly bureaucratic," the center admitted in a mission statement ("Restoring the Vision") published in 2001. "The N.A.C. had lost its sense of purpose and its sense of mission."
The plan that emerged was to improve the center's internal culture (encouraging greater creativity, initiative and professionalism) and expand its external reach (drawing younger and more diverse audiences and establishing a truly national identity).
The orchestra has always been the center's flagship, and change there was already in the wind before the report. Christopher Deacon, who became the orchestra's managing director in 1996, hired Mr. Zukerman to replace the English conductor Trevor Pinnock in 1998.
"He has transformed the orchestra," Mr. Deacon says now. "He is heavily invested in every detail of how the institution runs. He has recruited the best players in Canada."
Still, given Mr. Zukerman's continuing presence as a soloist and guest conductor on the international circuit, one might well question the depth of his commitment here. He conducts the orchestra for at least 14 weeks a year and in special events: more or less the same amount as music directors of other major North American orchestras. The difference, Mr. Deacon said, is that unless Mr. Zukerman is performing in Europe, he is around most of the time.
"He's always in his office," Mr. Deacon added, "and you almost forget that he's technically not here. We have a substantial meeting with him four days out of five."
Whatever the specific contributions of each of the current administrators, the National Arts Center Orchestra seems to be thriving, and this at a time when many Canadian orchestras are suffering much the same economic woes as their American counterparts. True, it operates on a relatively small scale. With 50 permanent members, it is about half the size of the largest North American orchestras. It takes on 10 additional string players on a regular basis, and it has expanded to as many as 76 players for a Bruckner Seventh Symphony. It is essentially a Beethoven orchestra that can expand to cope with most Romantic composers.
"We can't live without Brahms, Schumann and Dvorak," Mr. Deacon said, "but we can live without Bruckner and Mahler, so we build up. It is more cost-effective to add string players for a week than to maintain a big orchestra."
Mr. Zukerman, for his part, said: "I don't want to be in charge of 107 people. Sixty I already can't take. It's a pain in the butt."
The players' pay, with a base salary of $53,000 a year, is also around half that of the biggest American orchestras, though comparable to that of the Toronto Symphony and the Montreal Symphony. The orchestra's annual budget is $11 million; the center's, $46 million. Neither the orchestra nor Mr. Zukerman would discuss his salary, beyond noting that he gives back $19,000 a year for educational purposes. (All figures are in American dollars.)
Yet for a conductor not out to beat the world, the working conditions are more congenial here than at the majors.
"I would go crazy with an American orchestra," said Mr. Zukerman, who was the music director of the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra from 1980 to 1987. "The choice of contemporary music is more limited here, but we do two concerts a week instead of four or five, and it's nice to have the liberty to do five rehearsals in a week. It's a little more in the English style."
Certainly, having Mr. Zukerman as conductor lessens the orchestra's demand for costly guest soloists. Unlike many instrumentalists who have turned to conducting, Mr. Zukerman has continued his career as violinist and violist at full tilt.
"There are very few programs where I just conduct," Mr. Zukerman said. "If I see that I can play something, I do."
But in February, he is conducting another violinist, Nikolaj Znaider, in the Brahms Concerto for the first time. "I look forward to it," he said. "I want to see him suffer for a change. I know what it takes to do this stuff."
Ottawa, as much as it may love Mr. Zukerman, seems determined to do its part to keep him humble. When last encountered -- at the airport, minutes before the orchestra's plane was scheduled to depart for the first stop on the tour, Monterrey, Mexico -- Mr. Zukerman was being unceremoniously detained by security personnel for close inspection of his metal violin strings.
In his haste, he evidently missed my snide suggestion that he take a cue from the early-musickers (whom he has maligned in some of those outspoken interviews). Their gut strings, after all, whatever the benefits or drawbacks in music of the distant past, are surely better suited to 21st-century travel.
This, had he heard it, would undoubtedly have drawn one of those celebrated expletives.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Assisted Living, With Assist to Nature Preserve

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

DATELINE: LYNBROOK 

 BODY:
A BLIGHTED area in this Nassau County village is being revitalized through collaborative projects involving the county, an education center and Sterling Glen Communities, a New York City-based company with more than 250 assisted living residences in the state. 
 The Lynbrook projects include the $1.1 million restoration of the 14-acre county-owned Tanglewood Preserve, which has been untended for 10 years. It will have a connecting path to the adjacent 100-unit assisted living residence, Sterling Glen of Lynbrook, which is being constructed on the site of a private summer camp that has been vacant for 10 years. 
 According to Michael D. Daly, Sterling Glen's president, the company will provide assistance with some parts of the renovation of the nature preserve, including the creation of a parking lot. "We will see how else we can support it, maybe through plantings and new benches, and we will monitor and help maintain its brook," he said. 
In addition, the nonprofit Center for Science Teaching and Learning is planning to lease and renovate existing buildings within the preserve to run educational programs in which, they say, Sterling Glen residents can participate. 
Nassau County Legislator Roger H. Corbin, a Democrat from Westbury, who was instrumental in securing the county financing for the restoration, said: "This used to be a beautiful place, and it will be again. Sterling Glen is creating an ambience for the residence," which would mix well with the preserve and where the residents could volunteer services at the science center to mentor children. "It's a win-win situation for everyone," he added.
The Tanglewood Preserve is on the east side of Ocean Avenue, a north-south road that intersects with Lakeview Road on the north and Peninsula Boulevard on the south. Sandwiched between the preserve and Ocean Avenue on the south end is the Sterling Glen property, which includes six houses, three of which had been used for the camp and three as two-family rentals.
William Kreisner, the owner of Camp Tanglewood, which thrived for 40 years before it closed in 1993, said rising taxes forced him to close the camp, although he rented five of the houses until a few years ago.
Now 75 and living in Hampton Bays, Mr. Kreisner said, "It got to the point where the taxes were too high, and since we were operating only two months of the year, it was difficult to maintain." 
Eugene Scarpato, Lynbrook's mayor, said that since the camp closed, the property has become "an eyesore and source of trouble, and devalued houses around it." He added, "Kids were getting into the property and throwing stuff in the pond at the preserve." 
STERLING GLEN, which contracted to buy the 2.2-acre camp property in 1996, closed on it in September. Demolition of the buildings began in October, and the 100,000-square-foot residence for older people who need some assistance with personal and health care is expected to be completed in 2005. 
Meanwhile, the county has begun restoring the preserve. Brian J. Schneider, a hydrogeologist with Nassau's Department of Public Works, said that the project has three components.
The first will be the cleanup of Pine Brook, which runs the length of the preserve and through a culvert at its southwestern end to eventually discharge into Hewlett Bay. Because of the many roads in the area, the brook has become a drainage channel for runoff and is carpeted with debris, Mr. Schneider said. 
The second component involves restoring the one-acre Tanglewood Pond, which had been used and maintained by the camp. It will be dredged and restocked with fish, its shoreline stabilized with plantings, and a fishing pier added. A brick pathway will be constructed around the perimeter, where there are several worn benches.
Finally, a 1,000-foot-long, meandering wood-chip nature trail with bridges over some small streams will be created.
Just beyond the pond are three buildings that will be used by the science center. A 2,500-square-foot building that was once the Lakeview Public Library will house the administration offices and classrooms, said Ray Ann Havasy, the director. A one-room building will be used for programs and community meetings, and a small cottage will be used for maintenance equipment.
The center, which will make at least $150,000 worth of renovations, will not pay rent but will give the county a percentage of the fees earned from its programs for Nassau residents, which the county is unable to provide because of the cost, she said. 
The four-year-old center is dedicated to the improvement of science, mathematics and technology education. Its local programs include science camps and research projects. It currently has its offices in a rented building in Rockville Centre. At the Tanglewood Preserve, it plans to offer courses for teachers and students, as well as to allow the Sterling Glen residents to participate in mentoring students in science, gardening projects and research programs, she said. 
Dr. Havasy and Mr. Daly have written an application for a $140,000 state education grant for community learning, which would involve the county, the Malverne School District and Sterling Glen residents. 
The development of the adjacent camp property had been delayed for seven years because of a lawsuit against the developer and the village. Some local residents who were worried about traffic and the possible eventual commercialization of the site contended that "the board was not thorough in their review of the property," said Mr. Daly. In the decision, he said, "the judge ruled that the Village Board had been diligent in its review and was appropriately empowered to make the decision." 
As part of the permit approval, it was agreed that Tanglewood Road, which borders the preserve and is used as a shortcut to Lakeview Avenue, would be closed off at its southern end near the entrance to the preserve, where the road has been used as a dumping ground. Mr. Daly has agreed to create a 20-space public parking lot in that space with a sign for the preserve. 
The area's topography plays a major role in the development of the Sterling Glen property, he said. A short distance east of Ocean Avenue, the land naturally dips 15 feet to an open field abutting the preserve's border. A concrete retaining wall had been built against the steep grade for the camp, and the six buildings were on the street level.
The wall is being removed and the new five-level residence will be constructed across the center of the grade, Mr. Daly said. One level will be partially below grade and will include an 80-seat restaurant-style dining room, a living room and outdoor patios that will overlook the preserve. The remaining four levels will be above grade. "We are working with the lay of the land," he said. 
The $14 million assisted living residence, designed by Perkins Eastman Architects, based in Manhattan, will have pitched roofs, dormers and porches. It has a staggered facade and is designed to appear like a series of attached homes in order to fit into the residential neighborhood, Mr. Daly said.
There are to be four studios covering 500 square feet, 92 one-bedroom units of 550 to 640 square feet and four 750-square-foot one-bedroom units with dens. All are to have kitchenettes.
Monthly costs, which include three meals a day, housekeeping, laundry service and activities, are $3,400 to $4,500 for one person and $850 for a second occupant. Personal care services will range from $2 a day for a reminder to take medicine to $45 a day for an escort. 
THE mayor said he supported the assisted living residence, as it would be "pretty quiet and would help economically."
The 2.5-square-mile village, which has 20,000 residents and 7,500 homes, would gain $120,000 a year in taxes, and the Malverne School District would gain $250,000, Mr. Scarpato said.
Lynbrook's operating budget is $26 million, one-third of which is generated by taxes on commercial properties downtown.
Average taxes are $8,000 a year for a house, and the median family income is $70,000. 
Kim Misiano, office manager at Becker Real Estate in Lynbrook, said houses currently on the market in the village range from $329,000 for a three-bedroom colonial on the north side to $850,000 for a four-bedroom colonial or Tudor on the south side, where properties are larger.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Transit Center Is Planned as a Catalyst for a Revival

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn. 

 BODY:
RONALD D. ALIANO likes to cite the time during the Civil War when this city was known for its numerous millionaires. Norwich's deep-water port and the rail lines that ran along the Thames River provided transportation links that fed its commerce, mainly mills and merchant shipping, and generated great wealth.
 Mr. Aliano, president of the American Wharf Development Corporation and chairman of the Norwich Harbor Management Commission, said a new $14 million multimodal transportation center in the downtown could again make Norwich, a 27-square-mile city of 36,000 about 10 miles north of New London, a transportation hub for the region and bring back some of the commercial vitality of that earlier era. 
 Environmental work and detailed design have started for the proposed transportation center, which is to include a bus terminal, 250-car parking garage, water access and provision for an eventual rail station. It is to be on Hollyhock Island in the Yantic River, which joins with the Shetucket River to the south to form the Thames. Construction is expected to begin next year and be completed as early as 2005. 
"The intermodal transportation system is going to be critical to attract additional commerce to downtown Norwich," Mr. Aliano said. Other business officials also endorse the idea.
"I think Norwich has turned a corner, and this project will help a lot," said Cynthia G. Clegg, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Eastern Connecticut. "Interstate 395 is already a great corridor for growth, and anything we can do to improve the transportation system in the downtown can only help the commercial viability of the city." 
"Just having the transportation system opens up possibilities that we might not even consider at this point," Ms. Clegg said.
Some of the project's advocates envision a light rail system running between downtown Norwich and the two Indian casinos -- Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun -- both within a few miles of the city, and perhaps a water taxi on the Thames River between Mohegan Sun and Norwich.
The Norwich city planner, William R. Sweeney, said stronger transportation links would allow people to live in Norwich and work at the casinos and allow people who visit the casinos to go to Norwich for shopping or dining, ideally providing a steady stream of customers for new businesses.
"The issue with trying to get businesses downtown is to show them we have a market, and right now it's tough," Mr. Sweeney said. "The transportation center is one of those projects, along with some of the new housing we're getting downtown and the offices that are going up, that will combine to make it more attractive as a market for some of these businesses.
"At the very least, it's going to be a bus garage and bring some parking downtown, which are both positive developments for Norwich," Mr. Sweeney said. "But our hope is that eventually it will turn into a true multimodal facility. That's important for the long-term future of the downtown."
THE Norwich Community Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization that has developed the Norwich Business Park at the north end of the city, is developing the transportation center, with financing coming from four federal grants, a state grant and a city grant totaling more than $13 million. Another $719,000 will be needed before the project is completed, but the Development Corporation and Mr. MacDonald said they were confident that some form of state or city funds would become available.
As proposed, the transportation center would consist of a bus depot, a rail station and a two-story garage. It would stretch 288 feet between North Thames Street and Falls Avenue and straddling the west branch of the Yantic River, about 22 feet above the water.
The transportation center was originally planned for an area where there is a small bus terminal and parking area near a viaduct on the Thames River in Norwich. Michael A. MacDonald, a project executive for the Downes Group in New Britain, the construction manager, said it quickly became apparent it would not meet the requirements.
The viaduct site could accommodate no more than three buses at one time and was almost a mile from City Pier at the southern tip of Hollyhock Island, which is used in the summer by recreational boaters. It also has no rail access and limited access to Routes 2 and 12.
The city and its consultants quickly settled on a site on Hollyhock Island, which can accommodate eight buses, gives direct access to Routes 2, 12, 32 and 82, is within 720 feet of City Pier and has rail access as well.
Currently, the rail system is owned by Canadian National Railroad but operated by New England Central Railroad and used only for freight, Mr. MacDonald said. But the state Department of Transportation has identified the line, which runs between New London and Montreal, as one of the most likely to be used for passenger rail in the future.
"And when it happens, you have a rail station and platforms right on the line," Mr. MacDonald said.
The current bus terminal is just a parking lot, Mr. MacDonald said. The transportation center is to include a full-service bus depot, with an enclosed waiting area, bathrooms and concessions.
Richard E. DesRoches, general manager of Norwich Public Utilities and until recently the president of the Development Corporation, said an important aspect of the project is the 250-car parking garage, which will be a five minute walk from the downtown.
"Obviously, 250 parking spaces is not going to make or break any downtown, but as part of a transportation hub, it gives us the potential to bring a lot of people downtown," Mr. DesRoches said.
In addition, he said, the transportation center's water access could spur some other potential water-dependent uses, like a marina, on about three acres of land on Hollyhock Island that will remain developable after the transportation center is completed.
Robert S. Mulcahy, president of Landworks Collaborative Inc. of Worcester, Mass., a consultant hired to work on the city's waterfront plan, said he expected the transportation center's influence to extend much further.
"I see it as a catalyst for other land uses, particularly in terms of shared parking," Mr. Mulcahy said. While there has been considerable speculation about the transportation center's use by commuters, "this has the potential to be much more than 9-to-5, Monday to Friday. It can be an 18-to-24-hour seven-day-a-week community resource."
HE is considering uses for about three miles of waterfront property elsewhere in Norwich, primarily along the Thames River, with a total of about 80 acres of potentially developable land, and said the transportation center was likely to be central to most of it.
Mr. Aliano, who has developed an ambulance company, marina, miniature-golf course and restaurant in the harbor area, said that as a developer he agreed the transportation center could be critical to future development. He is considering developing a banquet hall on property he owns just a short walk from the planned parking garage.
But he said the city must take a long-term approach as it moves forward with the project.
"None of this can be implemented unless everyone is on the same page in terms of the zoning, redevelopment and economic development objectives," Mr. Aliano said. "We've been 47 different pistons in this community, working in 47 different engines. Everyone is off doing their own thing, and every once in a while something happens, but it's more by accident than by design. If we're going to be competitive in this new millennium, we've got to have a strategy."
