HEADLINE: As Rents Rise, So Does Deregulation 

BYLINE:  By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
AS the New York City housing market flourished in much of the period between 1999 and 2002, the pace of apartment deregulation quickened in the most desirable neighborhoods of Manhattan and market rents rose sharply in much of the city, especially in Brooklyn and Queens, where median rents exceed $1,000 for the first time in some neighborhoods.
 These are some of the highlights of a portrait of the rental market, drawn from an analysis of the New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey carried out in the spring of 2002 and recently released for independent analysis. 
 Rent regulation has been a major force in the New York City real estate market for more than half a century, with rents of more than a million apartments still set by government regulations. That stock of rent-regulated housing is gradually eroding, however, with a loss of a minimum of 32,000 units, 3 percent, from 1999 to 2002, according to an analysis of the data.
Moreover, in the most sought-after parts of Manhattan, below 96th Streeton the East Side and 110th Street on the West Side, rents were sufficiently high at the time of the survey that nearly one in six units could be removed from regulation upon vacancy, while more than half could escape regulation after a moderate renovation by the owner. State law provides for the deregulation of any vacant apartment with a legal asking rent of $2,000 or more. 
Outside Manhattan, rent stabilization's ability to protect tenants from the vagaries of the market is also showing signs of weakening. The legal regulated rents have been rising and are often at or above the market rents for the same apartment, even though they remain significantly below the $2,000 threshold. 
In Brooklyn and Queens median market rents rose faster than regulated ones in the three years covered by the survey. But in the Bronx, regulated rents rose faster than market rents, leading to a situation in which many owners now say they can no longer collect the stabilized rent increases to which they are entitled because their tenants cannot afford to pay them.
Though many New Yorkers continue to pay a large share of their income on rent, incomes rose even faster than rents in 1999 to 2002, softening the impact of the increases. 
The survey was established to determine the apartment vacancy rate under a law that would end rent stabilization if the vacancy rate exceeded 5 percent. At the time of the survey it was 2.94 percent over all. The survey is performed by Census Bureau every three years under contract to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and is the only large survey that tries to meticulously track housing patterns that include units' rent regulation status. The results were analyzed for The New York Times by Andrew A. Beveridge, a demographics expert and sociology professor at Queens College.
The survey portrays changes in the many different housing markets in neighborhoods across the city. In the last decade the Lower East Side and Chinatown showed the largest increases in market rents in the city, cheering landlords and causing tenant advocates to raise concerns about the affordability of housing. The survey showed that median market rents in the neighborhood have more than tripled from $600 a month to $2,000 since 1993, and the median stabilized rent rose 85 percent since 1993, to $850 a month.
Outside Manhattan, median market-rate rents were highest, at $1,100, in Bayside and Little Neck, Queens, and were at $1,044 in Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. Median market rents of $1,000 were found in Brooklyn Heights and Fort Green, in Brooklyn; Forest Hills and Rego Park, Flushing and Whitestone, Hillcrest and Fresh Meadows, Sunnyside and Woodside, and Astoria in Queens. Bay Ridge was next with a median rent of $975.
Of course, rents vary by location and apartment size. In Manhattan, the median three-bedroom market rate apartment had a rent of $3,400, compared with $900 for three-bedrooms in the Bronx and $1,000 in Queens. When computed across entire boroughs, market rate apartments with the same number of bedrooms had very similar rents outside Manhattan. A median two-bedroom was $800 in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Staten Island and $900 in Queens.
But the sharpest distinctions emerge not at the neighborhood level or from borough to borough but between market rate apartments and stabilized apartments within Manhattan, and especially in the most expensive and sought after parts of the borough. The Manhattan market is central to the debate over rent regulation because of the large gaps -- owners call them subsidies, tenants call them benefits -- between market rate and stabilized apartments.
"Rent regulation will end unless the laws are changed, and soon," said Michael McKee, the associate director of New York State Tenants and Neighbors, a tenant advocacy group. In Manhattan, he said, "Nine times out of 10, a vacant apartment is going to come back on the market unregulated."
But Jack Freund, the executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a group representing owners, said he was concerned about a "bifurcated system" in which owners in Manhattan have "long-term occupied stabilized units that are well below market" while outside Manhattan, owners receive the right to increase rents that they cannot collect.

Manhattan Trends
An Elevation Of Rent Levels
Within the prime Manhattan market, the survey clearly documents the rapid run-up in unregulated rents in the waning days of the city's economic boom, a surge that has made a bargain apartment almost impossible to find. 
By 2002, three-quarters of all unregulated apartments in this market were rented or listed for more than $2,000, up from 57 percent only three years earlier. Only 1 in 10 rented for less than $1,200 a month. 
Median market rents increased from $2,034 a month to $2,400, a rise of 18 percent, and up to $2,500 in leases signed in the 15 months before the survey. Since then, asking rents for new leases in Manhattan have declined about 10 percent or more from the peak, brokers and building owners say, but is not clear whether this has led to a decline in rents for the average long-term tenant.
Based on standard real estate benchmarks, a renter of a $2,500 apartment would require an income of $100,000 a year, and, indeed, the median income of new renters of unregulated apartments was $110,000, according to the survey.
As market rents accelerated, the gaps between market and stabilized rents in these parts of Manhattan increased. The median rent on a one-bedroom market-rate apartment was $2,450 compared with $1,100 for a stabilized one, a difference of $1,350, or 55 percent. In the rest of the city the difference is far smaller, a $700 median for a market rate one-bedroom versus $661 for a stabilized apartment of the same size, a difference of $39, or 6 percent; the difference rises to $147 for a two-bedroom and $220 for a three-bedroom apartment.

Stabilized Apartments
Many Units Are Gone, But How Many?
The weakening of rent regulation, through laws signed by both Democratic and Republican governors and adopted by the City Council to raise rents on vacant apartments and deregulate those with rents above $2,000, can be seen in a number of measures. 
The first is the count of stabilized apartments. An analysis of the housing survey estimates that a minimum of 32,000 rent stabilized units were removed from regulation between the previous survey in the spring of 1999 and the current one. This figure includes all occupied rent-stabilized apartments and vacant apartments available for rent. The 59,000 apartments still covered by rent control, an older regulatory system that now protects tenants in buildings put up before 1947 who have lived in their apartments since 1971, were not included.
It has been all but impossible to come up with a method to estimate the effects of rent regulation and deregulation that owners and tenants can agree upon. Earlier this year the New York City Rent Guidelines Board put the minimum net loss of apartments through the high rent deregulation laws at 14,736 in the three years that ended in 2002. New York State Tenants and Neighbors estimated that 47,000 units were lost during roughly the same period.
The Rent Guidelines Board found that during this period the number of apartments removed from rent regulation for other reasons were largely offset by apartments added to rent stabilization through government programs. The board tabulated apartments as lost to high-rent deregulation only if they were listed in records of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which administers the rent-stabilization program.
But the Rent Guidelines Board said that its figures were a floor -- the lowest possible number -- since many building owners may not have reported the deregulation of apartments to the state, and that the true number could be higher. 
The estimate of 32,000, although much higher, is also a conservative one, because between the 1999 and 2002 surveys, the Census Bureau changed the way it counted apartments: it used a sample from the homes canvassed in the 2000 census, which added more than 100,000 addresses that were not included in the 1990 census. 
This had the effect of increasing the count of all housing units in 2002, compared with earlier reports. As a result the actual number of apartments removed from regulation is probably larger than the estimate.
The reduction in rent stabilized apartments is likely to continue as the relatively large rent increases authorized by the rent guidelines board -- 7.5 percent for a two-year lease and 4.5 percent for a one-year lease beginning last month -- work their way through the system. 
Under the current rules, vacant apartments are entitled to at least a 20 percent vacancy increase on a two-year lease (and more for low-rent apartments and those that have not turned over in at least eight years). This means that any apartment with a current rent of at least $1,667 could immediately be deregulated upon vacancy. This threshold could drop as landlords renovate apartments and pass the cost along to new tenants. An additional $32,000 in renovations would trigger the deregulation of a vacant apartment with a current rent of $1,000.
As of 2002, the survey showed that almost 31,000 apartments -- nearly one in six of the 206,000 occupied, rent-paying stabilized apartments in the prime Manhattan market -- could be immediately deregulated upon vacancy and an additional 84,000 were renting for $1,000 or more and were within easy reach of deregulation. That would leave only 90,000 stabilized apartments, less than 40 percent of the 245,000 stabilized units in Manhattan in 1993.
In the rest of the city, nearly 4,000 apartments were renting for $1,667 or more, according to the survey, and could be deregulated when the apartments next become vacant. An additional 70,000 were renting for $1,000 or more and were in striking range of deregulation, although owners are unlikely to invest money in improving an apartment if the market rents are too low to recoup their investment.
The duration of tenancy in Manhattan apartments is longer than elsewhere in the city, as tenants are unwilling to give up their protected apartments. Tenures in stabilized apartments have begun to resemble those in the older rent control program, decades after that program started to be phased out. 
In Manhattan, 45 percent of stabilized tenants have lived in their apartments since 1993, compared with 38 percent in the rest of the city.
In addition, median rents in stabilized two- and three-bedroom apartments in Manhattan are rising more slowly than in one-bedroom apartments, and are actually lower, as the bigger apartments turn over more slowly and owners are unable to collect vacancy increases. Median rents were $900 on a one-bedroom, $800 on a two-bedroom and $700 on a three-bedroom.

Outside Manhattan
Stabilized Rents Near Market Prices
Outside Manhattan, rents were up significantly between 1999 and 2002 in some neighborhoods, including some middle-class communities. Median rents in Bay Ridge were up the most, by 44 percent, to $975, followed by Astoria, up 33 percent, to $1,000. Similar trends are seen in some improving neighborhoods. In Bedford-Stuyvesant, for instance, the median rent was up 30 percent, to $650, and in North Crown Heights and Prospect Heights, up 29 percent, to $775.
But stabilized rents outside Manhattan are, on average, not far from market rents. In Queens the median stabilized rent is 89 percent of the median market rent. In Brooklyn, it is 84 percent, and in the Bronx, 83 percent. In Staten Island, according to the survey, median market rents and stabilized rents are about the same. 
In the Bronx, stabilized rents actually rose slightly faster than market rents between 1999 and 2002. David Waxenberg, a senior vice president at Norwax Associates, which owns 30 buildings and manages several hundred more, primarily in the Bronx, said that the high rents in Manhattan have brought new investment to other parts of the city, but he said renters from Manhattan have not yet crossed the river to the Bronx in search of lower rents.
The State's Division of Housing and Community Renewal reported that in 2002, owners filed registration forms showing that about 81,000 regulated apartments in the city, an increase of 15 percent from the year before, were renting for less than the maximum legal allowed rent. But owners say these counts may far understate the issue. 
Arnold Goldstein, chairman of Samson Management, which owns thousands of apartments in Manhattan and surrounding boroughs, said that in the Bronx, where, for example, a three and a half room apartment on Pelham Parkway goes for $950, about 20 percent of his tenants pay rents below the maximum allowed under rent regulation.
When he installs a new room or waterproofs a building exterior, the cost of these improvements are passed along to the stabilized tenants with rents below market, but "those at market don't get charged." On the other hand, he said, in Manhattan, market conditions dictated that he reduce one tenant's rent from $4,000 to $3,000 in a large Park Avenue South apartment after the market turned.
Tenant advocates say the problem outside Manhattan is that stabilized rents have risen too high, through the 20 percent vacancy increases allowed by the state for a two-year lease. They fear that the rising stabilized rents will serve in the long run to undermine public support for rent stabilization.
Janet Henne, president of the tenants association at the Marseille and the Brussels, two large apartment buildings on 67th Avenue in Rego Park, said her association believes that many three-bedroom apartments in the complex have reached the legal $2,000 threshold and are no longer protected, while other apartments that had once been occupied by a single tenant for years, are now turning over frequently, increasing the legal rents. 
But Edward Cortese, senior vice president for marketing at the Lefrak Organization, which owns the buildings, said the company has at most two or three apartments renting for more than $2,000 in Brooklyn and Queens. Despite the tenant fears, he said, "The deregulation issue seems to be focused more in Manhattan than the outer boroughs."
The survey also documents a scarcity of low-rent stabilized apartments. The number of apartments with rents below $700 -- which would, in theory, be affordable to a household with an income of $28,000 -- fell by about 25 percent from 1999 to 2002; for the first time they make up less than half of the stabilized apartment stock. They are about a third of all apartments in Manhattan, Queens and Staten Island, half in Brooklyn and two-thirds in the Bronx.
During this period, the rising rents -- at least for stabilized tenants -- were cushioned by rising incomes. The percentage of stabilized tenants paying more than half their incomes -- a standard measure of distressingly high housing costs -- declined, from 29 percent to 27 percent, while the percentage of market tenants paying more than half their income increased slightly.
In the prime Manhattan market, 20 percent of stabilized tenants paid more than half their income for rent, compared with 23 percent in Queens and 28 percent in Brooklyn. In the Bronx, where rents are lowest, 34 percent pay at least half their income in rent.
Michael H. Schill, a law professor at New York University and the director of the Furman Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy, said that in the city's booming economy in the late 1990's incomes were rising faster than rents, especially among low-income people who were able to find jobs. 
Even so, Mr. Schill, who is using the survey to prepare a report on housing in New York, said the high proportion of people, especially low income people outside Manhattan, paying 50 percent of their income for rent was a serious cause of concern. That may have only worsened as the economy slumped since the survey data was collected.
"I would predict that the economic decline will make affordability problems more severe, because affordability improved with the booming economy," he said.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
The 32 Steps

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS; E-mail: amh@nytimes.com

 BODY:
SEVEN years ago, Ernie Fellenbaum noticed a town house for sale on West 103rd Street, down the street from the apartment where he lived with his wife and stepdaughter. The building was dilapidated and selling for the princely sum of $565,000. "It seemed like an awful lot of money," Mr. Fellenbaum recalled the other day, and he and his wife decided to pass.
 Mr. Fellenbaum is still in the market for a town house, and although his wealth hasn't increased appreciably, $565,000 strikes him as peanuts. The 103rd Street building eventually sold for more than the asking price, leaving Mr. Fellenbaum feeling as if he had just lost a hand of poker, and determined to do better the next time. 
 Three years ago, opportunity knocked again. Through Dexter Guerrieri, an Upper West Side town house broker, Mr. Fellenbaum toured a brownstone at 106th Street and Manhattan Avenue, in a neighborhood recovering from decades of neglect. The asking price was under $1 million. But to call it a dwelling was something of an exaggeration. "I looked up four floors, I saw the sky, and watched the pigeons almost literally fly into the place," he said. He passed. He lived to regret that one too.
 And so last Wednesday Mr. Fellenbaum was at Dexter Guerrieri's stylishly appointed suite at 68th Street and Broadway, where his firm, Vandenberg Inc., has its office, for an event billed as a "Town House Buyer's Seminar." Scanning the listings, Mr. Fellenbaum winced behind his tortoise-shell glasses as he noticed that a similar Manhattan Avenue building (renovated) was on sale for $1.8 million.
 Mr. Fellenbaum does not consider himself a rich man; pushing 50, he is considering a town house as a retirement investment. He designs ads for U.S. News and World Report, including those pesky blow-in cards that urge readers to renew their subscriptions. The other dozen people who attended the seminar, enticed by the promise of mastering "the 32 steps" needed to buy a town house, didn't look rich either.
 Nor were they there for the free snacks; the bottled water and fat strawberries remained politely untouched until the audience left, upon which the real estate agents wolfed them down. Rather, they were earnest, serious, plodding. A man in a gray suit wanted to know whether 11 times the rent roll was a rule of thumb for purchase price. The woman in the antique-lace blouse agonized: "I'm just trying to figure out how much we can afford on a house. I don't understand all the cash-flow implications."
 These people were living proof of the topsy-turvy economics of New York City, where a person can be looking at houses selling for $1.5 million to $4 million and, with some justification, think he is not rich.
 The truly rich, Mr. Fellenbaum demurred, are people like David Martinez, the London financier who paid $45 million for a duplex in the AOL Time Warner building.
 After years of searching for the perfect house, Mr. Fellenbaum could have written the headline last month that jeered: "What Can a Million Buy in Manhattan? Something Average." Or, as Mr. Fellenbaum put it, "The people who are super-affluent-wealthy, they don't need this meeting." Most prospective buyers were hoping to leverage the price of a town house with rental income. They sat up as Mr. Guerrieri discussed buildings that had been painlessly -- or so he said -- emptied of low-paying renters.
 Patience Sundaresan, looking cuddly in a flowered blouse and carnation pink lipstick, wondered whether she could stomach evictions. Ms. Sundaresan, a painter and lawyer now living on West 74th Street, is looking for a house and studio to share with her husband, a surgeon; their daughter; her mother; and a tenant or two. "I think there are moral issues as far as people who are professional building-emptiers," she said. "I think maybe it's a little different for someone who truly wants to make it a home for their family."
 Scarcity drives up prices, and desire. There are only 1,500 town houses on the West Side between 59th and 110th Streets, Mr. Guerrieri said. Had anyone considered Harlem or the Bronx? Or the suburbs? "I will never live in the suburbs," Ms. Sundaresan replied flatly. Her comfort zone was a four-block radius of her present apartment.
 She knew she was obsessed when she realized that she regarded "Rosemary's Baby," with its lovely Dakota settings, as a movie about real estate rather than about the occult.
 A little black magic might have been nice at the seminar. "You advertised 32 steps," one man whined. "But you only gave 18." Well, Mr. Guerrieri replied sheepishly, he had condensed things. Mr. Fellenbaum also felt let down. "The 32 steps is what kind of drew me there," he said. But he was not defeated. "There's one property that's been boarded up for years," he said brightly. "I'm not going to tell you where it is. The fantasy, or the hope, is that something like that will come along and we'll jump on it."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE; 
Madison Ave. Finds Itself in Elegance Deficit As the Bentleys Purr Smoothly Away

BYLINE:  By JAKE MOONEY

 BODY:
Luis Cepeda, a clerk at Dino Baldini at 49th Street and Madison Avenue, sells $3,000 sport jackets and $850 shoes. So when the Bentley dealership across the street moved out, it didn't exactly put a dent in his business. Still, Mr. Cepeda feels that something has been missing lately, if only a touch of spectacle. 
 "An upscale car dealership always attracts people," Mr. Cepeda said the other day, looking across the street at the empty white showroom that was home to Bentley Manhattan. 
 Manhattan Motorcars, which owns the dealership, vacated the space in September, moving the cars into its other showroom, on 11th Avenue. When the $300,000 sedans moved on, Mr. Cepeda said, so did the tourists and gawkers who used to point and dream.
 Still, merchants nearby say they never got much of a sales boost from having such an upscale neighbor. And Mahmoud Elsamahi, who operates a coffee cart on the other side of 49th Street, wondered about the economics of the high-end business. 
 "Thefunny thing that I noticed during two years here is, I didn't see people buying," he mused. "I just saw people with camcorders, or taking a snapshot and leaving."
 Steven Schneir, a Bentley salesman who now works at the 11th Avenue dealership, explained the move by saying the location just wasn't a good fit. "We were the only car dealer ever in the history of Madison Avenue," Mr. Schneir said. "There were never any before us, and I wouldn't think there will be any after."
 The business is doubling its space on the West Side, he added, where neighbors include a warehouse and a Con Edison facility, and four lanes of traffic whiz by the front door. 
 Back on Madison, the old showroom's owner is still seeking a new tenant, and the walls -- white in the main room and racing green in the back -- are bare. But even some people outside the Bentley price range are mourning the old place.
 "I miss it," said Alvin Dunston during a lunch break from his job servicing coffee machines in an office building above the former showroom. "Because you come by, you look at the cars, they're like fantasy cars. You think, 'Ooh, if I had money, I could get one."' 
 "You don't see them every day," he added. "It was fun for me. I'm not around 11th or 12th too often." JAKE MOONEY

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Access Fees for Doctors? Some Test the Waters

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
YOU probably already pay a monthly fee for access to cable TV and cellphone service. Someday soon, you may also have to come up with $20 to $30 a month for access to your doctor's services, on top of any co-payments, premiums and deductibles you're already paying for health insurance.
 It may sound far-fetched, but it has already happened in at least three states -- Washington, Ohio and Illinois -- and health experts say it's probably starting in other places as well. And it's not the health plans or employers that are responsible. It's the doctors themselves. 
 Jim Simpkins said he received a letter in January from his doctor at the Polyclinic in Seattle, a multiple-specialty practice with 97 physicians, notifying him that he would have to start paying a $25 monthly retainer fee if he wanted to continue as a patient. The extra money, the letter said, would permit his doctor, Bradley Harris, to limit the size of his practice, allowing for same-day (and longer) appointments. In addition, the letter promised health seminars, a newsletter and eventual e-mail access to the doctor. 
 Mr. Simpkins, 47, who retired from Microsoft several years ago as a group program manager, said he was already paying $313 a month for coverage under an individual preferred provider organization plan from Blue Cross. He said that he was "not thrilled" about the extra charge and that he didn't think the new services would amount to much. But he decided to pay it anyway because he really liked his doctor and didn't want to lose him. 
 In August, he said he received another letter from Dr. Harris, this one informing him that the office of the Washington State insurance commissioner was investigating the legality of the access fees. The letter asked him to contact the commissioner's office and register his support for the "new model" of more personalized care. 
 The commissioner's office confirmed that after consumer complaints, it was in talks with the Polyclinic and other clinics in the area about how the fees were structured. And the office is in discussions with insurers over whether mandatory fees for access to covered care are allowed under various contracts that physicians have with insurers, or under state law. The Illinois Department of Insurance, meanwhile, is responding to complaints by discussing contractual issues with insurers. 
 But Mr. Simpkins decided that he'd had enough. "The letter was talking about how wonderful all these creative arrangements were," Mr. Simpkins said. "I didn't think it was so wonderful. I think it's perfectly appropriate that they're investigating this." He said he left Dr. Harris's practice that month. Dr. Harris did not respond to repeated requests for comment.
 There is no question that doctors are feeling squeezed financially. The cost of running a multiple-specialty practice grew by 7.5 percent in 2002, while total medical revenue increased just 5.7 percent, according to a report in October by the Medical Group Management Association, a professional group based in Englewood, Colo., for medical practice managers. The cost of medical malpractice liability insurance continues to skyrocket, in some states more than doubling in 2003, according to a survey this year by Medical Liability Monitor, an independent reporting service in Chicago that tracks medical liability trends. And last month, the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services announced that the physician reimbursement fee schedule would drop 4.5 percent in 2004. 
 But many health care experts say it's wrong to charge managed-care patients extra for access to their doctors. 
 Doctors who join health insurers' networks sign contracts agreeing to provide certain medical services for a fixed fee. In general, patients' financial responsibility for covered medical services is limited to the co-payment and deductible, the amounts of which are spelled out in the contract, said Dr. William F. Jessee, chief executive of the Medical Group Management Association.
 Doctors who accept Medicare patients follow similar rules. "The whole idea is that the insurer contracts with the physician in order to ensure that the patient won't be charged over and above what the insurer's agreed to," Dr. Jessee said.
 Scott Forslund, a spokesman for Premera Blue Cross, one of the insurers that contracts with doctors at the Polyclinic, said, "Physicians in our network have every right to offer value-added services so long as they're optional." 
LLOYD A. DAVID, the chief executive of the Polyclinic, says the four primary-care doctors who are charging the access fee limit the size of their practice so they can provide more personalized service. 
 "Your availability is enhanced, your ability to return a phone call yourself instead of having a nurse answer it," he said. He also noted that there were extra benefits like a newsletter, health seminars and e-mail access to doctors. 
 Arthur L. Caplan, chairman of the Department of Medical Ethics at the University of Pennsylvania, questioned access fees in general. "Paying a monthly fee for what ought to be part of what your regular bill covers is morally dubious," he said. "It looks like extortion." 
 Eric Salathe, 38, a research scientist at the University of Washington, said he had been a patient of Dr. Jon P. Younger at the Polyclinic for about three years when he received a letter in 2002 informing him of a $20 monthly charge to continue as his patient. Mr. Salathe said he didn't think a newsletter and extra time with Dr. Younger justified the added expense, so he switched doctors. "It wasn't going to be $240 worth of value," he said, adding that his new physician "is just as good and doesn't charge me extra." 
 Dr. Younger said 300 of the 850 patients who were notified of the fee had left his practice. "Most of them were sort of marginally my patients anyway, young people who would see me once every two or three years," he said.
 Some patients say that paying the extra money is worth it. "Most doctors, it's one-two-three, they want to get rid of you," said Bernard Kessler, another of Dr. Younger's patients. Mr. Kessler, 86, had just finished a half-hour physical with the doctor. "This doctor gives you as much time as you need." 
 Dr. Michael O. Fleming, a family physician in Shreveport, La., who is president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, said he sympathized with his fellow doctors who are feeling squeezed. But he said patients shouldn't have to pay extra for personal attention or help in managing their illnesses. 
 "These are the things that should be covered within the relationship we already have with our patients," Dr. Fleming said. 
 The practice of medicine has changed drastically in recent years, and medical advances have led to more complicated treatments. Managing the care of patients who may be on several medications at once, for example, often eats up more clinical and administrative time, too much of it not reimbursed under managed-care contracts. 
 "The reimbursement system is starting to crumble," said Dr. John Goodson, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School who has written extensively about care management issues. "The reimbursement structure needs to be rethought." 
 One way would be to increase the amount that physicians are reimbursed for work that doesn't involve direct patient contact. 
 Mike Kreidler, the Washington State insurance commissioner, says he believes that there are ways in which the added fees could be structured so that they would not conflict with provider contracts. They could be voluntary, for example, or the doctors who charge them could remove themselves from the networks, he said.
 Still, Mr. Kreidler said, "We're concerned that if a significant number of physicians start charging these fees, what happens to those individuals who can't afford to pay more?"

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: S. Basu Mullick; 
Neuberger Berman Partners Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
INDUSTRY slowdowns, a weak economy or even bad weather can easily push down the share prices of solid companies, said S. Basu Mullick, manager of the $1.6 billion Neuberger Berman Partners fund. The important question for an investor, he said, is whether those price declines are likely to last long.
 "These are quality companies that have dropped in price," he said. "We want to figure out which ones are tennis balls and which ones are eggs." 
 The fund lost 0.7 percent of its value, annualized, for the three years through Thursday, ranking among the top 6 percent of large blend funds, which own a mix of growth and value stocks. That category lost 6.6 percent, on average, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.4 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.
 The fund gained 31.6 percent in the last 12 months, compared with 20.9 percent for its group and 22.1 percent for the S.&P. 500.
 Mr. Mullick, 45, is a vice president of Neuberger Berman Management, the fund's adviser. The adviser is a unit of Neuberger Berman Inc., which was acquired by Lehman Brothers on Oct. 31.
 Mr. Mullick finds the fund's 70 to 80 stocks among American companies with market capitalizations of at least $3 billion. He looks for growing businesses that sell for what he calls a "value price" -- a bargain based on the company's price-to-earnings ratio relative to that of the S.&P. 500. Over all, the portfolio companies trade for 15 times projected earnings for 2004, versus 17.8 for the S.&P. He also screens for companies with high profit margins and low debt.
 Mr. Mullick closely reviews the 100 to 200 companies found by his screens. Through talking with company management, investment analysts, consultants, lawyers and regulators, he aims to figure out the source of a company's share price decline and when it might reverse.
 In August, Mr. Mullick bought shares of Countrywide Financial, based in Calabasas, Calif. He paid $74.03, on average, for the position; the shares are now at $100.00. 
 Countrywide, a mortgage finance company, has had annual earnings growth averaging 22 percent during the last 20 years, Mr. Mullick said. Despite that, he said, the company's shares sell for just six times projected consensus earnings estimates of $17.50 a share for 2004,because the company has been viewed as cyclical, and its business is widely expected to be hurt if interest rates rise.
 The company has growing businesses in securities trading, banking and property and casualty insurance. "Investors have not yet appreciated the company's strong gain in market share and their diversification strategy," he said, "which should result in a far more resilient earnings picture in 2004 versus the expectation of an earnings collapse precipitated by sharp declines in mortgage banking."
 MR. MULLICK recently added shares of Viacom, the entertainment giant whose holdings include CBS and MTV. He started the position in March 2001, paying $42.06, on average. The shares now trade at $37.88. 
 The performance has lagged this year, he said, because of lackluster growth in local advertising as well as rising expenses. As a result, he said, shares trade for just 11.5 times 2004 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a low level by historical standards. But Viacom should profit next year, he said, from advertising related to the elections and from an overall increase in television viewing related to the Olympics, even though the events themselves will be on NBC, which is owned by General Electric. "This time around," he added, "Viacom has set modest revenue and cash-flow goals, and I suspect they will beat them." 
 Another holding is AmeriSource-Bergen, a large pharmaceutical distributor in Chesterbrook, Pa. Mr. Mullick expects the company to benefit from increases in mail-order prescription drugs and the savings created by consolidating its drug distribution centers. The company's generic drug business is expanding, he added. 
 Shares trade at 12 times estimated 2003 earnings, versus a 10-year median multiple of 18, he said, and "the business is still growing, perhaps slowly, but it is still a good value at this price."
 The fund began buying shares in September, paying $54.62, on average. They now trade at $64.19.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Sugar And Spice, And Sour Dads

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
CHILD rearing, divorce and sexism are each, on their own, topics that can fill a long day's worth of conversation. Throw them together, and you have fodder for weeks of debate.
 Last month in this section, I described a new study that found higher divorce rates among families with girls than those with boys. Looking at United States Census data, the study's authors -- Gordon B. Dahl, an economist at the University of Rochester, and Enrico Moretti, an economist at the University of California at Los Angeles -- found that the gap had existed since at least the 1940's and probably for much longer. 
 The differences are not enormous. About 20 percent of mothers with an only child who is a girl are divorced, for example, compared with 19 percent of those with a single boy. But the gap is broad enough, found in every region and among every family size, racial group and education level, that it seems undeniable. It means that girls are bearing an undue share of the economic and psychological costs of divorce.
 The article about the study elicited a torrent of responses, and some excellent questions. So let's return to the topic:
 Where's the proof that the divorce gap is a result of discrimination against girls?
 There isn't any in Mr. Dahl and Mr. Moretti's paper, a fact that they acknowledge. Thinking that boys would suffer greatly from the absence of a father, some parents might work harder to rescue a marriage when a boy is in the home. Or perhaps girls just give their parents more grief than boys, as one anonymous father announced on my voice mail.
 But it turns out that the Gallup Poll offers something resembling a smoking gun. When asked whether they would prefer a boy or a girl if they could have only one child, 38 percent of Americans chose a boy, and 28 percent picked a girl, according to a poll done this summer. Thirty-four percent had no preference or no opinion. 
 Since Gallup first asked a similar question in 1941, the numbers have hardly budged.
 Blame the Mini-Me phenomenon. Women show a slight preference for girls (36 percent versus 32 percent), but men overwhelmingly favor smaller versions of themselves (45 percent versus 19 percent). It isn't hard to imagine how the disappointment of some fathers over having girls could cause them to be less involved with their families, lowering the chances that the family stays together. 
 What about families with both a boy and a girl?
 Fertility records show that most parents with more than one child want at least one of each sex. Until they succeed, many continue to have children.
 That finding seems to suggest that parents with both a boy and a girl may be happier and less likely to split up. But that is not the case. Mr. Dahl and Mr. Moretti report that families with children of both sexes divorce less often than those with only girls -- but more often than those with only boys. Put simply, the more girls a family has, the more likely a divorce will occur.
 So what causes this bias toward boys?
 There are not clear answers, but there are some plausible ones. 
 Some of it is probably circular. Sexism makes life harder for girls and women in all kinds of ways, be it the horror of domestic violence or the quiet discrimination of lower wages for the same work. Parents trying to help their daughters cope with these obstacles almost certainly face a harder task than those raising members of the favored sex.
 BUT big societal forces should get only part of the blame. 
 The inability of some fathers -- though not all, of course -- to get as excited about a baby girl as they do about a baby boy almost certainly plays a role in creating the divorce gap. 
 "There's been a lot of attention paid to increasing fathers' involvement in families," said Shelly J. Lundberg, an economics professor at the University of Washington at Seattle who studies families. "Perhaps it would be useful to insert some understanding that fathers' involvement with daughters deserves a bit of focus."
 The professor has a point. But here's a simpler way to think about it: Do we dads really need a bunch of economic studies to point out that we should not discriminate against our own children?

HEADLINE: Falling Wages and Lost Jobs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Beneath the Smile, a Churning Anxiety" (Economic View, Nov. 2) described the drop in pay experienced by millions of laid-off Americans who eventually find new jobs. 
The column made the case that not even education protects these workers from falling wages. 
 The pattern is seen in the flight of American jobs to countries with low labor costs. Manufacturing workers are already losing high-paying jobs this way and end up taking positions that pay less.
 If the pattern continues, the results may be an enormous decline in wages for manufacturing and white-collar workers alike. 
 Chances are that chief executives, however, will retain their high pay: the cheaper labor here and abroad will increase profits and, in the recent past, higher profits have usually not translated into higher wages for workers. 
 Yes, education once raised workers' wages. Even education, however, can't fight globalization.

Diane Forve
Los Angeles, Nov. 2

HEADLINE: The Nation: Prescriptions Filled; 
If Americans Want to Pay Less for Drugs, They Will

BYLINE:  By GARDINER HARRIS

 BODY:
AMERICANS, who pay the highest drug prices in the world, are clamoring for access to cheap imports of prescription drugs. 
 The governors of Illinois, Minnesota, Iowa and Wisconsin -- Democrats and Republicans alike -- want their constituents to be able to buy drugs from Canada. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg says he would like the same option for New York City employees and hospitals. Municipal workers in Springfield, Mass., already have that right, though federal regulators threaten to stop them. 
Though American drug companies have spent millions to discourage Congress from legalizing the import of cheap prescription drugs -- and succeeded last week in keeping the ban on imports in a proposed bill -- even some industry executives privately acknowledge that they are fighting an uphill battle. With public pressure growing, drugs, the only legal products specifically prohibited from being imported, will ultimately join automobiles, software and all the other products that trade across borders. 
"Eventually we're going to get rolled on this," said a top industry executive on condition of anonymity. 
A House provision allowing the eventual import of prescription drugs was included in a bill creating a Medicare drug benefit. But last week in the Senate-House negotiations on the final legislation, the proposal was not included. 
Supporters of the idea say the battle is far from over. Some polls show that Americans are even more enthusiastic about measures to reduce the cost of prescription drugs than they are about a Medicare drug benefit, according to Robert Leitman, a pollster at Harris Interactive. Even the elderly -- who would gain most from a Medicare drug benefit -- prefer drug price controls to the Medicare benefit, by 52 percent to 35 percent, Mr. Leitman said.
American drug companies say that domestic prices are higher to cover the high cost of developing new drugs, a process that can take years. Cutting prices, they say, will reduce research, producing fewer new drug breakthroughs. 
The demand for cheaper prescription drugs has grown for many reasons. The spread of Internet sites advertising the lower prices has allowed Americans to see just how much more they are paying than their neighbors -- though it is illegal to import medicine. At the same time, drug prices in the United States continue to climb, and consumers pay an increasing share of these costs out of their pockets. 
Drug prices in Europe and Canada are far lower because they have national health care, and the governments negotiate deep discounts. The American manufacturers submit to these discounts because pills are cheap to make, so even sales at significantly reduced prices are profitable. Drug company scientists routinely introduce medicines similar to drugs already being marketed. European bureaucrats tell drug company executives that if they don't cut their prices, the government will go to a competitor. 
The companies say that even if they still make a profit, the discounts squeeze the amount of money available for research. That is what American consumers are supporting when they pay the higher costs. 
In America, they pay high prices because nobody is negotiating on their behalf on a national scale, and patients might not know that the drug their doctor prescribed could be replaced by an equivalent, often cheaper, medicine in some cases. 
Tight-fisted payers say there are few good medical reasons to buy all drugs within a class at list price, so they drive hard bargains. When governments are doing the bargaining, it is called price controls. 
The drug industry deplores price controls and says doctors should be able to prescribe whatever drug they deem appropriate because patients can react differently even to similar drugs. 
But consumer advocates say that doctors can be as susceptible to expensive marketing efforts by pharmaceutical companies as consumers are, raising costs for the entire medical system. 
GlaxoSmithKline, for example, recently introduced a new version of its big-selling antidepressant, Paxil, that the company calls Paxil CR. Doctors now regularly prescribe Paxil CR, and GlaxoSmithKline says it is "better tolerated" than Paxil. In fact, say researchers who make generic drugs, there is little difference between Paxil and Paxil CR. Generic versions of Paxil have recently been introduced, but the success of Paxil CR has meant that thousands of patients haven't taken advantage of the savings. They may not even be aware of the cheaper alternatives.
This is also the case with Nexium, a heartburn drug that replaced Prilosec. Thomas A. Scully, the administrator of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, told doctors at a medical conference earlier this year that you "should be embarrassed if you prescribe Nexium" because it increases costs without any medical benefit. Thousands of doctors prescribe it nonetheless. 
A variety of drugs introduced by major pharmaceutical companies in recent years are like Nexium and Paxil CR. Drug imports could drastically cut the prices of these expensive drugs and the incentives for making them. 
At the same time, the imports will have no effect on the prices of many biotechnology drugs developed by companies that have discovered life-saving cures for hard-to-treat illnesses. The prices for these breakthrough medications are as high or higher in Europe as they are in the United States because there are no ready alternatives. Gleevec, a miracle cure developed by Novartis for some types of leukemia, is one such drug. 
If cheap imports reduce industry profits and mean less money for research, it could be that some Gleevecs of the future won't emerge as rapidly, though that won't be known for years because research takes so long to bear fruit. 
"Drug import legislation is politically perfect," said Rebecca Henderson, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who studies corporate research and who often consults for drug makers, pointing out the tendency of politicians to consider short-term gain rather than long-term consequences. "You get the benefit now, but the pain doesn't come for a long time."
Already the industry is beginning to raise prices in Canada in advance of the day when drug imports will be legalized. And some executives are threatening to withhold products from Europe unless prices are raised. But no one is predicting that short of imports being legalized, drug prices abroad will ever be as expensive as those in the United States.

HEADLINE: German City Tries to Persuade Pentagon to Keep Bases Open 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: MAINZ, Germany, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
The birthplace of Johann Gutenberg and the center of the German wine-growing industry, this is a gracious city, proud of its Roman roots and splendid medieval cathedral.
 While it advertises its wine festivals and thriving media industry -- a fitting legacy for Gutenberg's town -- Mainz says less about its other big local business: the American military. 
 Now, though, the United States is rethinking how to deploy its troops overseas, a process that could replace many of the fixed bases in Germany with more mobile installations in eastern Europe. Officials here are scrambling to avert what they fear could be an economic body blow to the region. 
Nearly 63,000 soldiers and their families live in Rhineland-Palatinate, the German state of which Mainz is the capital. The bases, scattered in the dense forests and rolling hills southwest of here, plow an estimated $1.4 billion a year into the state's economy, generating 27,000 civilian jobs.
With talk of base closings in the air -- some of it fueled by the rift between Germany and the United States over Iraq -- a delegation from Mainz traveled to the Pentagon recently to make a pitch for the troops to stay.
"We know we won't have any influence on the geopolitical strategy of the U.S.," said Karl Peter Bruch, the state secretary of Rhineland-Palatinate, who led the delegation. "But we wanted to explain to them why we believe this is the best place in the world for the U.S. military."
Armed with a slick presentation, Mr. Bruch tried to change some minds. He noted that Germany contributes $1 billion a year for the upkeep of American bases here. The Ramstein Air Base, he said, is the logistical hub for the campaign in Iraq -- the first stop for wounded soldiers, as well as the main supplier of ammunition, equipment -- even bread, which is baked at a local bakery.
While most Germans opposed the war, Mr. Bruch said Ramstein and other bases were left largely undisturbed by protesters. That level of security, he said, would be hard to match in Poland, Romania or other Eastern European countries, where the military has considered locating the bases.
To sweeten his pitch, Mr. Bruch proposed recruiting German investors to help the military build new living quarters for the American soldiers here. Much of the military housing dates from the 1950's and is decrepit. He said he could line up $130 million in financing to build 500 new houses.
"When the soldiers see how well people live outside the bases, they say, 'Why should I live in this crummy housing block?' " Mr. Bruch said. "We can offer them more attractive row houses."
Such appeals are likely to carry little weight with Pentagon officials, who have been instructed by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld to break out of cold war-era thinking about how to deploy troops.
The watchword these days for the American military is agility. New bases would be modeled on Camp Bondsteel, which was constructed during the Kosovo conflict and features makeshift barracks and wooden helicopter hangars. They would be situated closer to the Middle East and other hot spots. 
Troops would be sent out on rotation, without their families, which would avoid the cost of building and running schools, churches or shopping centers. Ramstein alone costs $1 billion a year to operate.
"We're moving, not because we can get a better deal from another country, but because we need to be in another country," said Lt. Col. Mark Riccio, who is helping draft a plan for the Pentagon on how to realign its European bases. "It's about being in the right place strategically."
Gen. James L. Jones, the commander of United States forces in Europe, denies having a list of bases that would be closed. But the only one he consistently cites as having "enduring value" is Ramstein.
For Rhineland-Palatinate, that is a relief. But it still leaves vulnerable major Army installations in the city of Kaiserslautern, as well as the air base at Spangdahlem. With 34,000 American residents, Kaiserslautern has the largest American population outside the United States.
"We have never had a problem living with the soldiers," said Cornelia Weis, a state official who grew up in Landstuhl, where the Army has a hospital. "They are a part of our community."
For now, at least, Germany may get a reprieve. With the campaign in Iraq eating up so many resources, military analysts said Mr. Rumsfeld was unlikely to hasten the plan to close German bases.
"At the White House, they told us they would do nothing against the interests of the soldiers," Mr. Bruch said.

HEADLINE: Cattle Rushed to Market As the Price of Beef Soars 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: WEATHERFORD, Okla., Nov. 15 

 BODY:
About 30 of Tom Tippens's Black Angus cows wade halfway up to their knees in a field of winter wheat so thick and green they barely have to budge for a meal. Cattle ranchers, too, have never seen it so good, better even than the cattle, which in the genteel argot of meat production are subject to "harvesting."
 They are being harvested younger and faster than ever. 
 "The last two or three years, I lost a lot of money running cattle," said Mr. Tippens, 51, parking his Lexus S.U.V. to watch his ranch hand chase newly weaned calves from a pen, up a chute and into a trailer to be taken to pasture. "Now we've got the perfect storm. Prices are exploding. They're far beyond anything we have seen in history." 
Many things, like droughts in the Midwest and Great Plains, mad cow disease in Canada, and shifts in foreign trade and popular preferences, affect the price of beef. 
"But the unique thing about 2003," said Gregg Doud, chief economist for the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, "is that all these factors are pulling in the same direction, pulling prices higher. That never happens." 
Cattle ranchers have just one complaint now: signs of more midnight rustlers running off with their calves. Ranchers, and the thieves, too, have been getting 90 cents to $1.15 a pound for cattle, often more than $1,000 a head. That is well above the 85-cent peak a decade ago and 30 and 40 cents more than a year ago. Many ranchers are betting that these prices will not last, so they are slaughtering cattle sooner and depleting their herds of the heifers they would otherwise use to build new herds. 
"This year's calf crop is expected to be 38 million head," the Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service wrote in a report last month, "the smallest calf crop since 1951." Another result of the early slaughtering is a scarcity of the tastier choice- and prime-grade cuts, like ribeye and tenderloin, that can make up 80 percent of the meat of the well-fattened steer and just 60 percent of a lighter steer. 
Soon, Mr. Tippens said, "the final, tug-of-war stage" begins in the retail market. Because of a tight supply of cattle, the Economic Research Service said in the report, "retail prices are likely to continue on a record-setting path as the higher prices are passed on to consumers." 
So far consumers have seen an average rise of about 10 percent in restaurant and supermarket prices, the department reported. Rather than raise prices, many restaurants and supermarkets are selling lower grade, select beef instead of choice, or promoting chicken and pork.
"We've had to raise prices on beef at least 50 cents a pound depending on the cut," Jeff Lowrance, spokesman for the Food Lion supermarket chain, said. "We sell choice. What we're finding is cattle being rushed to market with less meat that will grade out at choice." 
The Agriculture Department predicts that the high prices at auctions and feedlots, though slipping below $1, are likely to stick for two more years, and retailers can hold out for only so long with 50-cent increases like Food Lion's. Today's $35 Porterhouse at white-tablecloth steak houses could be heading past $50. 
Robert Noland, an owner of Davis & Main restaurant in Richmond, said he was paying about $6 a pound for certified Angus beef ribeye steaks in August. "About three weeks ago they jumped all the way to $10.20," he said. "So I've switched from certified Angus to just regular."
Jim Cannon, a vice president of the Ruth's Chris Steak House chain, based in New Orleans, said, "We're going to hold prices as much as possible." With prime cuts becoming costly and scarce, Mr. Cannon said some Ruth's Chris outlets were diverting customers with a $28.95 special of garlic-encrusted halibut. 
Beef prices cycle up and down just as they do for most things, like lumber, lobster or gasoline. But every cycle has its own characteristics. 
Demand for beef has surged with the industry's development of juicier cuts and the new popularity of the Atkins diet, which promotes high protein meals. Americans are eating 67 pounds of beef a year per capita now, 3 more pounds than a decade ago. 
As demand has climbed, droughts have been scorching the leading cattle-producing states, leaving thinning pastures, underweight cattle and depleted herds. Ranchers have cut their herds still more to eke out some revenue. By the start of this year, the supply was down to 96 million head from 104 million in 1993.
Then on May 20 this year, the corpse of an 8-year-old cow in Alberta was found with mad cow disease. Importation of Canadian beef, which accounts for 8 to 10 percent of American consumption, was stopped. With the supply already tight, prices rocketed.
Pressure on prices should ease because the Bush administration is planning to lift most of the embargo early next year, but since supplies were already tight before the embargo, economists doubt that renewed Canadian imports will push prices much lower for a couple of years. 
Ranchers, too, could be reinforcing high prices. Looking at the current, unheard-of prices, Leland Southard, an economist at the Economic Research Service, said ranchers are saying, "These are probably higher prices than I'll see next year." 
So, he said, a rancher asks, "Do I sell at this price, which is very high?" Or does he build his herd and risk having to sell when prices might be lower? Many have opted to sell now. Like cattle, Mr. Tippens said, "ranchers have a herd mentality." They could be setting themselves up for a couple of years when prices are still strong but they have little to sell. 
Mr. Tippens has developed a strategy to navigate this market and keep himself afloat. He owns only 200 cattle -- all breeding cows. "We've got a factory, which is a cattle herd," he said. "I have a synchronized calving operation so I can wean them at the same weight and the same age." 
In one field he has a herd of cows that have just become pregnant, so they will deliver in the late spring. In a pasture across from them, he has another herd that recently delivered.
Mr. Tippens also manages 3,000 cattle for other producers, in what is called a backgrounding operation. Other ranchers contract with him to take their newly weaned calves 30 or 40 days to rid them of disease and fatten them up for pasture. By backgrounding, Mr. Tippens avoids the risk of owning cattle that in another turn of the markets could be worth half what they sell for today or nothing at all if rustlers should strike. 
No one keeps national statistics on stolen cattle, so it is unclear whether reports, lately about one a week, mean a resurgence. Cattlemen say rustling does not appear to have risen in pace with the prices. 
"It's fairly constant," said Joe Rector, a field inspector and Oklahoma area supervisor for the 14,000-member Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association, in Fort Worth. "This year, we'll recover in excess of $5 million in stolen property, and 70 to 75 percent of that is cattle," Mr. Rector said.
There may, however, be a surge in Iowa. "It seems like there's more now than ever," said Ronald Jordan, owner of a livestock auction business in Sioux Center that sells about 90,000 cattle a year and loses some to thieves. "They're getting really brave," Mr. Jordan said. "Ten head of cattle can bring $10,000 to $14,000."
"Two weeks ago a farmer in George, Iowa, lost 15 head," he said. No one knows where they went. A guy can take them and hold onto them for a year and then go sell them in Florida."

HEADLINE: A P.R. Challenge: Marketing Croquet to the Malletless Masses in America 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH

DATELINE: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 

 BODY:
Robert Fulford, the reigning world champion of croquet, settled into a cushioned wicker chair and surveyed a corner of his realm -- an emerald lawn dotted with wire wickets, a shady veranda set up for luncheon, white-shorted spectators murmuring and nibbling, waiters gliding about bearing jars of Grey Poupon.
 All was unruffled calm, yet all was not well. This was, after all, the world series of croquet -- the sport's grandest tournament, taking place in North America for the first time, and at the largest croquet grounds in the world. So why were there so many empty chairs? Where, alas, were the cameras and the sponsorship banners? Where was everybody? 
 "Certainly we could do more in terms of growth," Mr. Fulford, 34, a Londoner, said, tactfully cloaking his disappointment as he scanned the well-heeled enthusiasts who had come to the National Croquet Center to watch expert players from Britain, Australia, New Zealand and, in lesser numbers, the United States. "We'd like everyone everywhere to have access to croquet." 
Hold on to your teacups. Mr. Fulford and other croquet tragics, as die-hard fans are known in Britain, say they want everyone on this side of the Atlantic to embrace the game as a new national pastime, taking up wooden mallets and painted balls and pounding wickets into lawns from coast to coast.
Such populist ambitions are perhaps an odd fit for a tradition-steeped game played behind privet hedges, in Edith Wharton novels, in Merchant Ivory films and at the farthest reaches of the British Commonwealth. This is a game that even partisans admit is snooty, and too boring to be televised. And in an age of smackdown wrestling and smash-mouth football, the croquet world's favorite slogan -- "It's the ultimate social calisthenic" -- does not exactly roll off the teleprompter.
None of this has stopped officials at the $6 million croquet center, which opened last year, from embarking on a vigorous marketing campaign that highlights not just the familiar backyard version of the game but also newfangled forms meant to draw in high school students, young singles, middle-aged couples, grade-school gym classes. How else to justify the existence of the center, which bills itself as America's 21st-century Wimbledon?
Such misty optimism about croquet's potential is perhaps least far-fetched in Palm Beach County, which has one of the nation's highest per capita incomes and, according to the center, its highest concentration of croquet lawns. Polo is big here, as are garden parties, debutante balls and other pastimes of the very wealthy, to whom croquet was marketed almost exclusively in the past.
Center officials admit that Palm Beach may not be the best place from which to recruit a more racially and economically diverse fan base. Bob Alman, the director of marketing and community relations, said "there was tremendous concern" about the inconsistency of trying to broaden croquet's appeal from this place, a few miles south of the Millionaires' Row of mansions that has kept Palm Beach on the international socialite map for a century. 
"But what are you going to do?" Mr. Alman said. "There's no way of getting rid of that image, anyway, unless maybe Miller Lite comes and gives us a $1 million endorsement."
To the exasperation of Mr. Alman, 63, who helped organize the nation's first nonprofit croquet club in San Francisco in the 1980's, even companies that cater to the wealthy will not sponsor croquet events.
"Do you see the Jaguar money around here, do you see the Rolex?" Mr. Alman asked, perching on the veranda of the white-and-green clubhouse as the daily matches wound down around 2 p.m. "No, because we can't get television. TV would only work with golf croquet."
Ah, golf croquet. The way of the future, if Mr. Alman's plans work out. That version, he said, played on an undulating lawn that resembles a challenging golf course, is quicker, more exciting. The center has dedicated its Harpo Marx Lawn (Harpo having been one of this country's more prominent croquet tragics) to golf croquet, and is marketing it to middle-class couples, high school students and corporate groups.
Mr. Alman has other variations. He helped invent malletball, which uses soccer balls and outsize wickets, and which he says is perfect for the beach. In toequet, players kick soccer balls through the wickets.
Mr. Alman, just back from peddling malletball to members of a local chamber of commerce, predicted that revisionist croquet would take off. The Palm Beach County sheriff's Olympics this weekend features malletball, Mr. Alman said, and he will soon pitch the game to the county's gym teachers and supervisors of after-school programs.
Mr. Alman is also lobbying luxury and resort hotels. He expressed especially high hopes for South Beach, which he said had plenty of energetic fun-seekers but no croquet courts.
Until now, most croquet tragics have encountered the sport accidentally, said Jeff Soo, the manager of the tournament here, called the MacRobertson Shield after the trophy that is awarded. Mr. Soo, 39, first played croquet while on a beach vacation 10 years ago. When he got home to Chapel Hill, N.C., he discovered a small croquet club, where he has played ever since. Mr. Soo, who is of Chinese descent and was the only nonwhite person at Wednesday's matches, compared croquet to rock-climbing "in that it's a sequential thing" and to chess because of the strategizing it requires.
Playing organized croquet is also relatively inexpensive, Mr. Soo said, pointing to the growing number of clubs in California, Florida, Massachusetts, North Carolina and Illinois whose membership fees are generally far less than golf and country clubs'. The National Croquet Center's 300 members pay $100 a year, for students, to $1,500 a year, for a premium couple's membership.
The number of public croquet lawns is also growing, Mr. Alman said: New York City has one, in Central Park, as do Chicago, Denver, Hartford, Atlanta, Tulsa, Houston and Baton Rouge.
In New Zealand and Australia, croquet has much broader appeal, with clubs in every other town and people of all ages and classes taking up mallets. Carmel Statham, who traveled from Canberra, Australia, to watch the championship here, said the members of her local club ranged in age from 11 to 89. Furthermore, she said, Australian croquet players do not insist on wearing all white, preferring jeans and bare feet. (Ms. Statham, 55, in a green polka-dot blouse, and a reporter, in red and black, stood out in the sea of white attire like parrots among swans.)
The Americans were foundering during this championship, as usual -- the country has sent a team to the MacRobertson Shield only since 1993, and has never won. Americans are at a disadvantage, Ms. Statham said, because they do not normally play by the international rules that the British, Australians and New Zealanders know cold.
Robert Derham of Fort Lauderdale, who stopped by the championship after reading about it in a local paper, said he was intrigued by croquet because an extended family could play. Mr. Derham, 81, said that the official rules bewildered him but that he planned to buy a book about building croquet lawns nonetheless.
"You can't have 10-year-olds out playing tennis with grandma, but this is a different story," he said. "You can play this until you drop dead."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jerry Stark, captain of the United States croquet team, lining up a shot.; Stephen Mulliner, a Briton, played at the world croquet championship this month at the National Croquet Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. (Photographs by Barbara P. Hernandez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Politicians Join Criticism Of Finances In New York 

BYLINE:  By MIKE McINTIRE

DATELINE: PALISADES, N.Y., Nov. 14 

 BODY:
At conferences like the one that ended here on Friday titled "Fixing New York State's Fiscal Practices," it is not uncommon to hear gloom-and-doom assessments from those seeking change in government. Elected officials, if they show up at all, can be counted on to defend the status quo.
 But in a striking turnabout, this time it was the politicians who were seething over New York'sbudget problems and openly doubting the likelihood of reform. Indeed, in the view of some of them, the sky was not only falling -- it had already fallen. 
 There was H. Carl McCall, the former state comptroller and Democratic candidate for governor, lamenting that he "was really depressed" over New York's finances and "very pessimistic" about the prospects for solutions proposed by the Citizens Budget Commission, which sponsored the conference.
"It seems to me that we've found a new way to do business in New York," Mr. McCall said, "and it is called utter failure."
There was William A. Johnson Jr., the mayor of Rochester, declaring that New York "used to be known as the Empire State -- and we still act like we are."
But, Mr. Johnson said, "we are a dying state, and I don't know what it will take to get us to give up the inside games. If we keep playing them, we're heading down the road to oblivion."
And there was Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau County executive, who drew applause for his no-holds-barred description of the budget process in Albany. "It's a horrible, rotten, terrible, broken system," he said.
For all the harsh talk, participants at the annual gathering, held this year at an I.B.M. conference center here, did offer suggestions for improvement.
They said that New York State should plan better, by adopting multiyear budgets with quarterly modifications; establish an independent, nonpartisan office to watch over fiscal deliberations; require the Legislature to adopt a budget on time; and add to the "rainy day" fund so that more money is available during economic downturns.
"The system is so broken and people are so pessimistic that something has to change," said Diana Fortuna, president of the commission, a nonpartisan group supported by businesses, which seeks ways to contain government spending and taxes in New York.
"We're hopeful that this will get people thinking about ways to make it better," she said.
The despairing tone of the two-day conference was set early by Gerald Benjamin, the dean of liberal arts and sciences at the State University of New York at New Paltz. Mr. Benjamin opened the conference on Thursday night by summing up the state's problems, including the downgrading of its bonds, the one-shot infusions of cash and heavy borrowing to balance the budget, and a lack of oversight over public authorities that control billions of dollars.
"The reputation of the state has declined," Mr. Benjamin said. "New York once prided itself as being a leader in governance among the states. Now mediocrity is the norm."
Much of the criticism was leveled not only by academics and representatives of research organizations, but by current and former elected officials from the local level. Those officials said they had chafed under unfair burdens imposed by an aloof and inept state government.
Time and again, the local leaders complained that they have had to raise taxes to cover the cost of mandated services like Medicaid, which they said would be better paid for at the state level.
Mr. Suozzi spoke bitterly about unresponsive lawmakers in Albany. He suggested that they had grown too comfortable in their jobs because incumbents in the Legislature enjoy "a re-election rate higher than the Politburo in the old Soviet Union."
Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, picked up the theme of poor governance and unaccountable leadership, likening New York's use of public authorities to Enron's use of off-the-books partnerships to hide huge financial losses. Mr. Spitzer, like Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, another conference participant, attacked the authorities as spendthrift agencies and dumping grounds for those hired by patronage.
One state official who did attend was John Cape, the deputy director of the State Division of the Budget. Mr. Cape agreed with much of the commission's assessment of the state's fiscal problems, but ridiculed the notion that adopting the proposed changes would make New York "a model state."
"We already have that state -- it's called California," Mr. Cape said. "California has all these things and it is a poster child for fiscal irresponsibility."
