HEADLINE: Bridgeport Mayor Knows He's the Focus 

BYLINE:  By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
JOHN M. FABRIZI had less than 20 hours to celebrate his victory in the Bridgeport mayoral race on Nov. 4 before critics started biting. Ken (Citizen) Smith, the afternoon talk-radio host on WICC, had called Mr. Fabrizi's press office and asked for an interview, but had been denied. So, as radio talk-show hosts often do, he went on an indignant rant.
 "I guess that's a signal," he said. "That's a sign. I'm taking that as a sign. When they fail to come on a day after the election it's a sign to me." 
 Mr. Smith, a Democrat who constantly attacks President Bush, was holding nothing back with the newly elected Democratic mayor. 
"It tells me that they want business as usual in Bridgeport. The day after the election he owes it to the citizens of Bridgeport to be on the radio."
Suddenly, the mayor kicked the door of the studio open.
"No one's blowing you off. Come on, Ken," Mr. Fabrizi said. He sounded exhausted. "It's been a long seven months."
"All right," Mr. Smith acknowledged. "I got a little paranoid."
Can the mayor get a break? Apparently not.
Mr. Fabrizi is treading lightly these days as he begins his four-year term. The city's previous mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, is serving nine years in federal prison for taking bribes, and Bridgeport is mired in an economic slump. Mr. Fabrizi, who stepped in when Mr. Ganim resigned last April, knows residents are on edge and are expecting the mayor to move them forward.
"I believe there's an extra focus because of previous issues," he said in an interview last week in his downtown office. "However, I welcome the focus. I don't mind people holding my feet to the fire, breathing down my back. It's all part of the job and I understand that."
It's not just talk-show hosts who are watching. Local business leaders have decided to present the mayor with a periodic report card, grading his efforts on everything from economic development to public safety. Honesty and public openness are also major concerns.
"We certainly had our bubble burst with the performance of the last mayor, so we want a gauge for future mayors so we can forestall future inappropriate behavior," said Paul S. Timpanelli, president and chief executive of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council, a nonprofit group representing the local business community and chambers of commerce.
The report card will not have letter grades, but will determine whether the mayor is "meeting expectations" or "failing to meet expectations."
The regional business council, which has about 1,000 members, will set up a committee to oversee the report card, Mr. Timpanelli said.
Mr. Fabrizi said he doesn't mind the scrutiny.
"If that gives the business community a comfort level, so be it," he said. 
It will take months, if not years, to find out whether Mr. Fabrizi is the honor student he claims to be. So far, at least, he has embraced symbols of openness and honesty. On his desk, next to a half-empty bottle of antacid tablets, Mr. Fabrizi has replaced the traditional nameplate with a placard stating "You don't have to pay to play in Bridgeport."
He has opened the bidding process on contracts and added members to the ethics commission. During Mr. Ganim's administration, there often weren't enough members of the commission to meet participation requirements. Mr. Fabrizi has sold the lavish oriental rugs and luxury cars of his predecessor. And, fittingly enough, one of the first vacant buildings to be restored is the old "City Trust" building across the street from the City Hall annex. That building will be converted by a developer into more than 130 market-rate apartments, as well as retail and commercial space. Next door an indoor mall was being renovated. Across the street from the Trust building, the old Read's department store will be converted into lofts for artists. Those projects will be under way within months, Mr. Fabrizi said.
With state and federal help, Bridgeport officials are hoping the city will begin operating a barge system that would transport shipping containers across Long Island Sound from New York and New Jersey, pulling trucks off the highway. It would also create jobs associated with warehousing and shipping.
State Representative Jacqueline Cocco, who represents the northwest corner of the city, said she is working on the barge plan. This is just the beginning of a strong partnership between the city and the state, she said.
"We need to know what important things are happening in the city and what we can do to bring them to fruition," she said.
Mr. Fabrizi also said he wanted to increase contact with Connecticut's representatives in Washington. Last week, he was scheduled to travel to the nation's capital to meet with a handful of senators and representatives, he said.
But he has also got bad news. Local taxes, which both Mr. Fabrizi and his challenger, Rick Torres, noted were exorbitantly high during the election campaign, will probably be going up again. Despite recent reductions in the mill rate, an upcoming property tax revaluation will likely result in higher taxes for many residents and businesses. Mr. Fabrizi hoped further mill rate reductions can keep taxes down.
His Republican opponent in the mayor's race, Mr. Torres, said he was upset when he heard taxes might go up again.
"I said I would cut them," he said. "He claimed he would help cut them. Now it looks like he's going to raise them."
Mr. Torres, who ran against great odds -- registered Democrats outnumber Republicans in Bridgeport 6-to-1 -- lost by more than 3,500 votes. He wasn't sure whether he will continue to be involved in politics or run for another office, but his anger and disappointment were still very much at the surface.
Mr. Fabrizi had indicated that he wants to move on from the bitter feelings generated by the race. Some of the most heated words came not from Mr. Torres, but from fellow Democrats who wanted the party to go in a new direction. Will those feelings simmer? Mr. Fabrizi doesn't think so. Turmoil in the party, he said, was cast into stark relief because of the difficult circumstances of this election.
"It was a unique time in Bridgeport, due to the scandal with the former mayor," he said.
That may be wishful thinking, given the fervor with which fellow Democrats, like State Representative Chris Caruso, have attacked Mr. Fabrizi.
As the mayor walked and waved in a Veteran's Day parade earlier this week, the handful of residents who lined the streets said they would give him time to settle into the office.
"He just got elected," said Timothy Horan, owner of the Downtown News & Mini-Mart. "Give him a chance."
And a week after his outburst, Citizen Smith came back on the air to announce that he would soften his approach. As the Carpenters's "We've Only Just Begun" played in the background, Mr. Smith announced he would lay off criticizing the mayor for 90 days, as a sort of "honeymoon."
"We'll give him a little breathing time," he said. "In the meantime, we'll let the wounds heal in Bridgeport."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor John M. Fabrizi of Bridgeport, with his wife, Mary, and son, Mike, behind him, greeting people at the city's Veterans Day parade last week. (Photo by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

PERSON: GEORGE W BUSH (54%) John (Mayor) Fabrizi; Joseph Ganim; Avi Salzman

HEADLINE: Dog Bed to Custom Cage: Tailoring the House to Fit the Pet 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE NADEL

 BODY:
SATURDAY sounds in suburban neighborhoods tend toward a generic mix of leaf blowers, car engines, children and babies. Maybe an occasional seagull or sparrow in the background. But in Wantagh, the familiar soundtrack is frequently overpowered by an unlikely sound: the high-pitched screams of a hyacinth macaw named Bentley.
 "When Bentley screams, you can hear him across the street," said Linda LaFleur, who owns the macaw plus two quieter birds and a 15-year-old Pomeranian. 
 Perhaps not surprisingly, when Mrs. LaFleur, 36, and her husband Artie, 37, brought Bentley home three years ago, a neighbor filed a complaint under a section of the Hempstead town code that prohibits "owning, possessing or harboring any animal or bird which howls, barks, meows, squawks or makes any other sounds which creates a noise disturbance across a residential real property boundary."
Ms. LaFleur said that the police came to the house three times in response to theneighbor's complaint. "The cops would play with the birds, but they never gave us a ticket," she said. "We shut every window in the house and never opened them again."
And then they did what countless American pet owners are doing -- they redesigned their house around their pets. 
"This is one of the country's fastest-growing industries," said Julia Szabo, the author of "Animal House Style: Designing a Home to Share With Your Pets" (Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown, 2001). "In a rocky economy, people will only spend money on their kids and pets, which are like children."
Last year, Americans pampered their pets to the tune of $29.5 billion. Animal-oriented designs accounted for $100 million, a 10 percent increase over 2001, according to the American Pet Products Manufacturing Association.
Mr. and Ms. LaFleur have built a soundproof room for Bentley and their other two birds, a 6-year-old blue and gold macaw named Ally and a 5-year-old peach-face lovebird named Nick. The 10-foot-by-12-foot room has an insulated second wall and slabs of six-inch-thick industrial foam rubber stuffed into the window frames. 
Mr. LaFleur, an electrician, built the room himself for about $600. Two steel cages, 4 feet long, 2 1/2 feet wide and 6 feet high, take up most of the space. Ally's cage cost $700, but because Bentley is able to bend steel with his beak, he has a titanium cage, which cost $2,200. Nick occupies a smaller cage nearby.
Pointing to her wedding ring, Ms. LaFleur said that it was her third. "I had to get an airplane-grade titanium wedding ring made," she said. "It was the only ring that Bentley couldn't bend." 
Outside the bird room, the LaFleurs' house is decorated with ceramic wall hangings that read "Don't Ruffle My Feathers -- I Get Ugly" and "Pets Are Welcome. Children Must Be on a Leash." 
Since Ally, Bentley and Nick are free to fly through the house, the LaFleurs have installed tile and linoleum to make cleaning easier. 
Titanium cages are nothing compared with the pet furniture available in stores on the Island. Designs range from a $19 tartan dog bed at Costco in Westbury to wrought-iron four-poster dog beds for $450 in Pet Supplies Plus in Manhasset and Happy Tails in Great Neck.
"For every outrageous item I carry, there's a pet owner out there who'll buy it if he can find my store," said Norio Okui, a co-owner of Happy Tails. 
Where pets are concerned, elegance and functional design do not have to be expensive. James Blauvelt created a discreet screen of bushy spathiphyllum plants in a corner of the dining room at his weekend house in East Hampton to camouflage his cat's litter box. 
Mr. Blauvelt, 50, the executive director of catering at the Waldorf-Astoria, called his design "a moving day accident that became permanent." 
"You would never think of putting a litter box in a dining room," he added, "but it works."
Luke, a golden retriever puppy, has few restrictions in the restored chicken coop in Water Mill where he lives with his owner, Paul Donaher, during the summer.
"I wanted to make the house user-friendly to the new puppy, so I removed two carpets and rolled one up," said Mr. Donaher, 47, whose main residence is an apartment in Manhattan, where he is the president of the Mrs. John L. Strong Company, a stationery concern. Luke was given his own lamb's-wool bed and assigned a shelf in an antique armoire, where Mr. Donaher stores dog treats, toys and other supplies. 
The house is decorated with vintage black-and-white photographs, sepia prints, paintings and 19th-century ceramic heads of dogs, which are hung over doorways. "The dog motif is more about me than about the dogs," Mr. Donaher said.
Finding the right design is a continual process of analyzing what works and what doesn't. "My dogs are my interior designers." Ms. Szabo, the author, said. "They vote with their feet." 
Marie Birnbaum, 49, who has 4 adopted cats in her Lido Beach home and 10 strays living in a her backyard, said, "You have to constantly be changing your toys and your furniture." 
To keep her cats from getting bored, she bought a carpeted "kitty condo" for $125. It had three carpeted curved shelves attached to a scratching post. The cats would climb the post and curl up to sleep on the shelves. . 
But after six months, the cats stopped using the condo, so last January, Ms. Birnbaum gave it to Adele Santoro, 47. a hairdresser in Island Park. She also gave Ms. Santoro a kitten. Ms. Santoro loved the cat, but the condo did not fare as well. 
"My cat hates that thing," she said, so she ended up throwing it out.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Linda LaFleur with her macaws, Bentley, left, and Ally. Marie Birnbaum, left, plays with her cat Ice Cream, who is chasing a feather attached to a wand. Ice Cream wallows in catnip, right. "Kitty condos," top, at Pet Supplies Plus in Manhasset. (Photographs by Kirk Condyles for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Going for the Glitter 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM

 BODY:
MONICA ANDERSON always liked to doodle on notebooks, napkins and scraps of paper.
 At the age of 40, she has parlayed that talent, plus a business degree, into a fast-growing, high-end greeting card company called Remanents and based in Haddon Township. In 2000, its first year in business, the company sold about 10,000 cards. This year, she says, it has already sold more than 250,000 to retail stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue, which started carrying them this fall. 
 The cards are petite and glittery and oh so girly. One card with earrings on the front says "every girl needs a good stud." The "low-fat Italian dressing" card has a picture of a slinky, glittery dress. And one of many shoe cards has a picture of a jazzy shoe called "Palm Slings." 
 "We think they are quite cute, and they are affordable and the quotes are great," said Cassandra Van Cott, stationery and gift buyer for Saks. "They are not only great to write notes on, but they are gifts and quite frameable."
 The cards, which sell for $2.95 to $6, have also been featured on Oprah Winfrey's television program.
 Ms. Anderson grew up in Los Angeles and went to college in the San Francisco Bay area, majoring in economics and business. She always appreciated art, she said, but "I never thought I had enough talent." 
 After she and her husband, John, moved to Haddonfield six years ago, she began making cards and stationery and doing special-order invitations or announcements for friends. In May 2000, she accompanied a neighbor, Lora Carr, who owned a small stationery company, to the National Stationery Show in New York.
 After checking out the competition, Ms. Anderson decided to start Remanents, which makes "designer greeting cards for those with a passion for fashion," she says in her marketing material. Ms. Carr sold her business and joined forces with Ms. Anderson.
 They made their first sale to The Papery in Marlton and have continued to expand to other shops in New Jersey, Philadelphia and throughout the county, including the 60 Papyrus stores. They now have two employees and at busy times hire other people to apply glitter to each hand-sparkled card.
 Even though Ms. Anderson is the head of the company and Ms. Carr is in charge of marketing, everyone helps to fill orders.
 "We all do it all," Ms. Anderson said. "I glitter on the weekends just to get caught up."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 23, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Remaments, a greeting card company based in Haddon Township, referred incorrectly to Oprah Winfrey's reaction to the cards. The company's founder, Monica Anderson, said Ms. Winfrey's staff reported that she liked the cards. They were not featured on Ms. Winfrey's television program.

HEADLINE: Product of New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By MARGE PERRY

 BODY:
FOR every cousin who forgetsthat this is the Garden State, for every New York City relative who believes there is no good food beyond the little island of Manhattan and for all those unfortunate souls who have not discovered the pleasures of New Jersey, it's time to pay attention.
 New Jersey has entrepreneurs aplenty who take good ingredients and make them even better. The following is a sampling of some of their products, timed for the holidays -- as gifts or for making shorter work of party preparations. All this, and they contribute to the state's economy, too. 

This (Not So) Little Piggy . . .
 Though ostensibly named for the French city from which it originally hails, Bayonne ham made by the Newark-based specialty food company D'Artagnan comes by its American name fair and square. Ariane Daguin, the French-born co-founder of the company, said she first produced this delicacy in a building with "one wall in Bayonne" -- Bayonne, N.J., that is. 
 Bayonne ham bears some resemblance to prosciutto, and is in fact made by a similar method. But Bayonne ham is earthier and meatier tasting than its Italian cousin, with less discernible salt. The ham, made from large pigs, is dried for a minimum of 12 months with the bone in, which helps enhance the meat flavor. The bone is removed before the ham is sold -- either sliced in 4-ounce packages for $7.30 or as a whole 10-to-12-pound ham ($173.25). 
 D'Artagnan also sells exquisite and almost haunting truffle butter (3 ounces for $8.90 or a 6-ounce log for $14.40). The two work in tandem: a slice of bread topped with a pat of the butter and draped with a slice of the ham puts a plane ticket to Gascony on top of everyone's holiday wish list. 
 Orders can be placed by calling (800)327-8246 or going to www.dartagnan.com.

Berries and Bees
 It makes perfect sense that New Jersey produces a knock-out blueberry honey. The state insect -- yes, the state has one is the honey bee. And New Jersey is the largest producer of blueberries after Michigan.
 But blueberry honey is not a purplish mixture of fruit and honey. Rather it is a woodsy, lightly floral, dark amber result of the necessary pollination of the blueberry highbush. It doesn't contain even a milligram of the actual fruit.
 In a win-win situation, blueberry growers hire beekeepers to release their bees unto the bushes to enable the plants to bear fruit. In return, the beekeepers collect the resulting sweet nectar. 
 Fruitwood Orchards Honey Farm of Monroeville has just such an arrangement in nearby Hammonton. The blueberry honey that Fruitwood Orchards produces is pure -- meaning that it is not blended with honeys from plants other than the blueberry bush. The Wright family, owners of Fruitwood Orchards, has been producing honey for more than half a century, and the experience shows. Enjoy the blueberry honey drizzled on buttered toast, scones or pancakes; use it to glaze meats and poultry; or, when no one is looking, lick it right out of the spoon.
 Orders can be placed at www.fruitwoodorchardshoney.com or (856)881-7748. A 12-ounce blueberry honey bear is $2.50, a 1-pound bottle is $3 and a 2-pound bottle, $5.50.

The Nose Knows
 Stroll down Ocean City's boardwalk and it inevitably happens: the aroma of warm caramel corn lures you into submission. No matter that you just ate -- one whiff and you move, zombie-like, toward the large copper kettle where the popcorn is transformed into a sweet and slightly salty treat.
 While nothing beats fresh-out-of-the-kettle caramel corn, Johnson's 28-ounce plastic tubs come close.
 In my family, none has ever survived a drive home from the shore fully intact. But in the rare event that a little bit is left a few weeks later, it's still irresistible. Bill Lombard, a co-owner of the company, says the caramel coating seals in the freshness of the air-popped corn. How and why is a secret; even summer employees sign confidentiality agreements.
 Johnson's sells one-, two- and three-gallon tins, now decorated with holiday themes ($25.95, $38.95 and $49.95, including delivery), and 28-ounce plastic tubs ( $21.95, delivered). Or, follow your nose to the shop at 1360 Boardwalk in Ocean City and watch them make a batch (it is open through January, then closes except for weekends, and then reopens after Easter). The caramel corn and Johnson's peanut crunch are available in a choice of 15 holiday tins or in plastic tubs at www.johnsonspopcorn.com or (800)842-2676.

Tomato Sauce, Purely
 Just how did Ed Simpson, the owner of Muirhead of Ringoes, manage to get that old-time flavor into every 16-ounce jar of Ed's Tomato Sauce? For anyone who grew up knowing tomato sauce as "gravy," this sauce may bring memories of Grandma with a wooden spoon permanently affixed to her arm. For all others, the sauce may just be a revelation.
 Tiny bits of tomato and onion are suspended in a tomato puree that is just thick enough, seasoned with oregano, basil, fennel seed and a hint of hot pepper. Is it perfect balance of seasoning that makes the sauce so good? Or does Ed's Tomato Sauce have the same secret ingredient as Grandma's? Mr. Simpson says it's the simple pure ingredients. 
 "The things I put on the market don't have all the additives of processed products," he said. "I make everything in small batches. It gets out there and it's gone."
 Muirhead is a family company of just five employees, including Mr. Simpson, 77; his wife, Doris; and their daughter, Barbara. In the last decade they have produced two finalists for outstanding new product at the Fancy Food Show in New York: Pecan Pumpkin Butter ($5.90 for 13.5 ounces) and Green Tomato Mincemeat ($5.90 for 14 ounces). 
 Ed's Tomato Sauce is sold in 16-ounce bottles for $4 plus shipping and can be ordered by calling (800)782-7803 or going to the Web site www.muirheadfoods.com.

Jersey Jam and Jelly
 While most customers who order from Spring Creek Farm go for the blueberry jam -- made, of course, from nearby Hammonton blueberries -- the farm's owner, Diana Johnson, especially likes her bluebarb jam. 
 For good reason. Adding the tart rhubarb to the intense flavor of blueberry somehow mellows it, making the jam smoother, more complex and less in-your-face sweet. This is a jam for marmalade lovers, for grown-ups who like a little balance in their bite. Serve it on scones with cream cheese, or give the pretty octagonal jar as a gift. Either way, you're helping keep the Garden State green: all Spring Creek Farm berries are locally grown.
 The farm, on 17 acres in Upper Deerfield Township, makes 28 flavors of jams and jellies, produced from both their own berries and those from nearby farms.
 A 5.75-ounce jar is $3.35; a 12-ounce jar, $5.25. Phone: (856)455-6462 .

GRAPHIC: Photos: Native products of the Garden State include Johnson's caramel popcorn, Muirhead tomato sauce and Fruitwood Orchards blueberry honey, as well as Bayonne ham and truffle butter, left, from D'Artagnan. (Photographs by Jim Simpson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Manufactured Here 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

 BODY:
LEA & PERRINS' Worcestershire Sauce is made in Worchester, England, and just one other place: New Jersey.
 North America's largest producer of cigarette paper is not in Virginia or North Carolina. It is in New Jersey. 
 Calvin Klein's Obsession is also made in the state. The chocolates placed on the pillows at the Regency on Park Avenue in Manhattan? You guessed it -- made in New Jersey. 
 "People are often shocked when we tell them that right in their own backyard is where many of the world's most beautiful fragrances are made," said Cosimo Policastro, executive vice president of the Givaudan Fragrances Corporation, in Mount Olive, which makes Obsession and fragrance oils used in many other products, including Hugo by Hugo Boss. "Too many people think of New Jersey as what they see off the New Jersey Turnpike."
 In fact, the state is home to 12,500 manufacturers that make specialized niche products, with fewer than 500 employees each. Many of these companies are family-owned; others are divisions of multinational corporations or key suppliers to them.
 Businesses of this size are the future of manufacturing, said Robert Loderstedt, chief executive of the New Jersey Manufacturing Extension Program Inc. in Newark. "That's where the real innovation and creativity emanates from," he said, adding that New Jersey's location, in the heart of the vast consumer markets of the Northeast and near ocean ports and rail and road networks, gives manufacturers an advantage despite the state's relatively high costs of labor, land and utilities.
 Italian immigrants brought Brioschi, the bubbly antacid, to New York City in the 1880's. In 1953 the company's United States division moved to Fair Lawn in Bergen County and settled into one of the nation's earliest suburban industrial parks.
 "We moved to New Jersey to escape all the taxes and confusion that was in Lower Manhattan," said Marco Brizzolara, 81, president and owner of Brioschi's United States operations. His father bought the United States rights to the product in 1925.
 Today, 14 employees make up to 9,000 pounds of Brioschi a day, when the company is in production. The main ingredient, sodium bicarbonate, is blended with the effervescent pH-balancing ingredient tartaric acid, a byproduct of grapes imported from Spain and Italy, Mr. Brizzolara said.
 In the same industrial park, 75 New Jersey employees for Lea & Perrins' make the spicy brown sauce from the same secret recipe used in Britain, where it is a condiment and a cultural mainstay. Anchovies, tamarind and garlic are among the key ingredients.
 Differences do exist between Lea & Perrins' customers in the United States and Britain. In Britain the sauce is used on eggs at breakfast and on grilled cheese sandwiches. In the United States it is sold for use with steak and as a "burger booster." The recent popularity of the Atkins Diet has not hurt business, and Bloody Mary demand remains steady, said Ralph Abrams, president of the company's American division.
 "We're in every restaurant and grocery store in America," Mr. Abrams said. "It's one of the few brands that can make it for 185 years."
 The Spotswood Mill in Middlesex County is North America's largest manufacturer of cigarette paper. The mill's 350 workers produce enough paper in a year to make 450 billion cigarettes. Yet the mill is nowhere near its raw materials in Manitoba or the plants in Virginia and North Carolina where Spotswood paper is rolled around Marlboros and Camels.
 The 62-year-old mill is still in business here because of investment decisions made by Schweitzer-Mauduit International Inc., based in Atlanta, which spun off from Kimberly-Clark in 1995.
 The owners have recently spent $60 million to upgrade the mill's machinery, said Bill Foust, vice president for administration, to make fire-retardant paper, which is mandated for use in cigarettes sold in New York beginning in mid-2004. "In a continuing effort to improve operations over the last 12 years we have spent over $100 million in the plant's facility and equipment," he said.
 Varda Shambon was a concert pianist when she began making truffles in her Manhattan kitchen 16 years ago. Now, her specialty chocolate company, Varda Chocolatier, occupies 20,000 square feet in Elizabeth, where it molds Belgian chocolate into more than 1,000 products, including palm trees, cactus, camels, saddle shoes and a hot air balloon. 
 Ms. Shambon chose Elizabeth because it is convenient to her base of clients in the New York hospitality and travel industries. The state of New Jersey provided real estate incentives with financing and tax credits. Still, Ms. Shambon is disappointed in one way with New Jersey and the United States: chocolate consumption per person here is only about eight or nine pounds a year, half that of the world leader, Holland.
 "There's still big potential," she said.
 One of the world's largest makers of ear-piercing kits, the Inverness Corporation, is based in Fair Lawn. The 30-year-old business makes encapsulated ear-piercing equipment for customers like Wal-Mart, Piercing Pagoda and Claire's, as well as 2,000 jewelers and 2,400 salons and day spas.
 "It's a rite of passage," said Peter Indiveri, president of Inverness. "It's a special event that has to be treated with the utmost safety but also fun." Inverness has 190 styles of ear-piercing studs and has just introduced a product, Klixx, which allows the newly pierced to change the look of their earrings without changing the post during the healing process. 
 "When you're dealing with teenagers, there is a patience factor," Mr. Indiveri said.
 Inverness needs to stay fresh because it has only a limited time to reach consumers before their piercing days are over.
 "At age 25 it's time to get serious about life," he said. "Whatever the statement is, it's got to go."
 Advanced Cerametrics, in Lambertville, makes ceramic fibers that are used in tennis rackets to control vibration. The technology grew out of work the company did for the Pentagon to muffle the sound of helicopter rotors. The leap from helicopters to tennis rackets came after a conversation about the fibers that the owner of Advanced Cerametrics, Richard Cass, had after a game of tennis with a friend who worked for Prince, the racket manufacturer. In the end Prince was not interested, but Head was. Andre Agassi now uses a Head racket with Advanced Cerametric fibers.
 The ceramic fibers cancel vibrations in the racket, making it tighter and generating 15 percent more energy when the ball is hit, Mr. Cass said. "The net effect is, the sweet spot is as big as the whole racket when normally it's just six inches," he said.
 The company is also using its product in skis and is working with manufacturers of baseball bats, hockey sticks and archery bows. Mr. Cass said there might be applications for golf clubs, but he doubts the tradition-bound sport would accept the change.
 Originally, Mr. Cass said, the 55-year-old business was a manufacturer of textile machinery parts, but that business steadily moved south and offshore.
 "By the end of the 1980's we said, 'If we are going to stay in business we need to adapt new technology and devote significant resources,"' Mr. Cass said. "Fortunately, it paid off."
 Mr. Cass said the company, which has $2 million in annual sales, used federal government financing to help develop the product.
 In the long term, he said, his company's true potential is not in tennis rackets and skis, but in helicopters and aircraft. The company is also working on using its fibers to improve the sound of guitars, generate heat in hiking boots and charge batteries.
 Many of New Jersey's niche manufacturers are a part of larger United States and European multinationals. Lysol, AirWick, Easy-Off oven cleaner and Mop & Glo are made in Belle Meade by their British owner, Reckitt Benckiser.
 Others are castoffs from big companies that changed their business strategy. Mr. Loderstedt of New Jersey's manufacturing program said that when a big company sheds a plant or a division, new owners often make a success of the remains because they are more entrepreneurial and innovative. "There's less bureaucracy and less overhead," he said. "They're focused. Many of them live day to day. That's the nature of the beast. But when you have something personally invested, you work a lot harder."
 The Integra LifeSciences Corporation, which makes artificial skin, was spun out of Marion Merrell Dow, previously a part of Dow Chemical, which had been unsuccessful in getting Food and Drug Administration approval for the same product.
 Jack Henneman, Integra's executive vice president for administration, said the new company bought the rights to Marion Merrell Dow's clinical trial data and manufacturing processes in the early 1990's and went back to the F.D.A. It won approval for the product, known as Integra dermal regeneration template, in 1996.
 "It involved mostly a lot of hard work," Mr. Henneman said. "My guess is, if Marion had been willing to invest more money and more time they would have been able to get it approved."
 Integra has 860 workers worldwide, with 250 at its collagen plant and headquarters in Plainsboro. Last year the company had $118 million in sales. It went public in 1996, pulling in investors who believed its artificial skin would be a hit.
 "The product did turn out to be stupendous from the standpoint of the patient," Mr. Henneman said. "But the commercial success did not meet the expectations of the initial investors."
However, it formed the backbone of a series of other products that remodel tissue. Integra's leading product is DuraGen, which repairs the sac around the brain and the spinal cord after surgery. It also makes NeuraGen, which stimulates nerve regeneration, and products that help bone growth and oral surgery.
 "The original technology," Mr. Henneman said, "has been central to each of these."
 Sometimes when conglomerates fail, families prevail.
 "If you go back 20 years, New Jersey was the plastics capital of the world," Mr. Loderstedt said. Many of those companies have folded under intense pressure from low-cost producers around the world.
 FPI Thermoplastic Technologies in Morristown is a survivor, making half of all the brown plastic trays McDonald's uses in its restaurants. That's two million trays a year. The company, which has 120 employees, also makes smoke detectors, heat sensors, retail cosmetic display cases and toilet and hand towel dispensers for commercial restrooms.
 Brian Murray, a senior executive at a large plastics company, bought the business in 1978 from Air Products and Chemicals, a Pennsylvania multinational. His sons joined the company right after college, Sebastian in 1981 and Samuel in 1987. The sons are now running the company, following the death of their father in 2000.
 Sebastian Murray, chief executive of FPI, has just one word to describe how his plastics business has survived in New Jersey: robots. Each of the company's 28 plastics injection-molding machines is operated by a robot or can be controlled automatically. Mr. Murray said he had been to factories in China where it took 700 workers to turn out the same volume of products FPI can make in the same amount of time.
 "We have invested significantly in automation and robotics to bring our costs down and allow us to compete with the Far East," he said. In one sense, though, he has something in common with China. "I would love to pass this business on to my kids and create some kind of a dynasty," he said. "That was my dad's vision."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Products made in New Jersey, in full or in part, range from artificial skin to cigarette paper, antacids, fragrances, chocolates and household cleaning aids. The state is home to 12,500 manufacturers that make specialized niche products, with fewer than 500 employees each. And businesses of this size are said to be the future of manufacturing. HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Focus PZEV; 
A Stealthy Operative In the War on Pollution

BYLINE:  By JIM MOTAVALLI

 BODY:
AT first glance, the Ford Focus PZEV, which combines gasoline-engine practicality with ultraclean tailpipe emissions, seems to be the gift that no one asked for. Car owners who care about their vehicles' evaporative emissions performance, or the rate at which catalytic converters heat up, seem few and far between.
 But there is growing evidence that consumers will seek out environmentally responsible vehicles if they do not have to make a tradeoff in terms of lower performance or a higher price. Few people paid attention to fuel economy in 1987, when a survey by J.D. Power & Associates found that only 3 percent of consumers considered it the most important factor in buying a new car. But a survey this year by the same company indicated that gas mileage is now the top consideration of 15 percent of car shoppers, and the fifth-highest priority. 
 Thus, the Focus PZEV -- the label stands for partial zero-emission vehicle, one of many mind-numbing categories established by clean-air regulators -- has arrived at an opportune time. Although its mileage is not appreciably different from that of a regular Focus, its emissions are remarkably lower. 
The Focus PZEV, with a special 2.3-liter 4-cylinder Duratec engine, produces just one-tenth of the smog-causing emissions that come from a Focus with the conventional 2-liter Zetec engine; the PZEV puts out just 1 pound of these emissions over 15,000 miles, using the low-sulfur gasoline sold in California, compared with 10.7 pounds for the regular Focus. (The difference with the expiring federal pollution standard, known as Tier 1, is more stark: that rule permitted 30.1 pounds over the same distance.)
One might expect such clean-air gains to be accompanied by fireworks and confetti, but the clean Focus, like about a dozen other PZEV models, has slipped into the market as quietly as a secret agent on a cold war rendezvous. While Ford has made its Focus available for test drives, the publicity departments at some other companies seem barely aware that they offer such cars. 
Even environmental groups, focused on hydrogen fuel-cell and hybrid gas-electric technologies, seem only vaguely familiar with PZEV's. "What are they exactly?" asked the Washington-based press secretary for a group focused on clean energy.
This new Focus, like PZEV's from 11 other automakers, is designed to meet the strict new environmental rules in a handful of states, and they do so with mostly mundane, relatively low-cost modificiations to existing gas-engine technologies -- like revised catalytic converters that heat up very quickly to cut the pollution produced by cold engines. 
California regulators, trying to clean up some of the nation's worst air, have changed their rules under a compromise with the industry. Originally, the California Air Resources Board had ordered carmakers to produce zero-emission battery cars under a complex system of credits that is part of the state's low-emission program. Tough revisions to those rules were adopted in 1999 to cover the 2004-10 model years. As a result both of automaker lawsuits and the failure in the marketplace of plug-in battery vehicles like General Motors' EV-1, the California board allowed automakers to gain credits from low-emission gasoline cars.
Because four Northeast states follow California's rules, PZEV's are also sold in New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine (with some spillover to nearby states).
Starting with 2003 1/2 models, the PZEV powertrain became standard on all Focus cars sold in California and the four Northeast states, except for the high-performance Focus SVT, and the package is available nationally on 2004 models as a $115 option. Jim Cain, a Ford spokesman, said: "In California, we do market the environmental benefits very clearly. But Focus customers will get a PZEV no matter where the environment is on their concern list." 
The potential benefits of PZEV's may be far more sweeping, at least in the short term, than the gains from hybrid cars. Tens of thousands of PZEV's are already on the road, at little or no cost premium beyond conventional gasoline versions of the same cars. New models are coming, and sales are expected to grow steadily. In contrast, only 100,000 hybrid cars have been sold in the United States since 1999, when the Honda Insight became first on the market.
Ford has sold 36,000 PZEV's and projects 100,000 sales through the 2004 model year. By contrast, United States sales of the Toyota Prius hybrid have totaled only 56,255 over three years, through Oct. 31. And despite the publicity given to fuel-cell cars, practical versions remain a dream, given the challenges of creating a hydrogen infrastructure.
Focus PZEV's start at a reasonable $13,915, including delivery charge. I tested a five-door ZX5 Premium,with a base price of $16,785 and a sticker total of $19,445. With a five-speed manual transmission, it had an economy rating of 25 m.p.g. in town and 33 on the highway, roughly the same as the standard ZX5. The Prius hybrid, with more high-tech features and a combined mileage rating of 55 m.p.g., lists for $19,995, making it tough competition, although there are long waiting lists for the 2004 model.
If you are looking for a car that makes a public statement, the Focus PZEV is not for you. Unlike battery cars festooned with decals or the oddly futuristic-looking Insight, the compact Ford blends into the background. There is no clue, not even a discreet emblem, that the car is far greener than the average Focus.
Still, it is more fun to drive than the average econobox, especially with the five-speed manual transmission. The car requires no sacrifices. Its small but energetic engine produces 144 horsepower, compared with 130 in the basic Focus sold in 45 states. The PZEV is a tight, zippy car, the kind you'll enjoy throwing into curves a little faster than might seem prudent.
Weighing just 2,600 pounds and aerodynamically styled, the five-door hatchback is handsome in a modern way, but also practical: there is room for four, plus luggage, and great visibility all around. My 6-foot-7 cousin even managed to fit (albeit snugly) behind the wheel.
I seldom have the opportunity to put test cars to serious braking and handling tests, but I had my chance on the Merritt Parkway in Connecticut when a Ford Taurus flew across the divider and landed right in front of me. I sawed the wheel, stood on the brakes, and made it safely to the shoulder.
After seven days of regular use, I felt rather virtuous, having used only a half-tank of fuel. And compared with the average 2003 automobile, the Focus PZEV produces 97 percent less hydrocarbon and nitrogen oxide emissions, and 76 percent less carbon monoxide. But not all environmentalists are convinced. "PZEV's certainly help improve air quality," said Bill Moore, editor of EV World, an online magazine about electric cars. "But they do zip for fuel efficiency or reducing oil imports." 
Nor do PZEV's reduce another type of emissions, the carbon dioxide produced by burning gasoline that is the primary greenhouse gas contributing to global warming.
Even if environmentalists are skeptical, and even though many consumers haven't a clue what PZEV stands for, the technology will soon be on cars across the nation, and it should have a profound and positive effect on air pollution. California rules say that 6 percent of carmakers' production should be PZEV's, and at the rate these cars are moving off dealer lots, that goal could be achieved. "PZEV's are a fantastic outcome of the zero-emissions vehicle program," said David Friedman, research director of the Union of Concerned Scientists.

INSIDE TRACK: Green without pain.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
For Job Seekers, More Hoops and Hurdles

BYLINE:  By Betsy Cummings

 BODY:
Rob McIntosh feels like he's been jilted -- 10 times in a row. Over the past year, Mr. McIntosh, a graphic designer and creative director, has come close to snagging a job that many times, only to be told "no thanks" in the 11th hour. One company promised him a job that later vanished. Another asked him to complete hundreds of dollars of freelance work as a "tryout," then balked at payment. Still another invited him to interviews on four occasions for a position that he is now convinced never existed. 
 Mr. McIntosh, who had never waited more than three weeks for a job offer, couldn't conceive that employment was so elusive -- or employers so demanding. But his recent experiences have made it painfully obvious how maddening a job search can be in this economy. 
 Mr. McIntosh, 37, who was laid off last year from his position as a designer at Scient, an information technology services company in New York, might find comfort in the fact that he's not alone. Recent statistics from the United States Department of Labor indicate that the national economy has grown at 8 percent in the past quarter, while unemployment claims have dropped by more than 50,000. But in the New York metropolitan area, the jobless rate is 8.6 percent, compared with 6 percent nationwide.
It doesn't help that some employers are using the current market to their advantage. A glut of job seekers means companies wade through more resumes, but have the luxury of a larger talent pool. "Employers in poorer markets can afford to be fussier and look for the perfect applicant," said James Brown, a labor market analyst with New York State's Department of Labor, who said 300,000 people statewide are looking for work, up from 200,000 two years ago. 
For job seekers that can mean being left in a lurch. Every hiring process Mr. McIntosh has gone through since losing his job at Scient has lasted at least two months and frequently longer.
That wait has meant a loss of opportunity. This September, Mr. McIntosh felt he was on the verge of landing the position of creative director of branded environments at one New York company. After his initial interview, Mr. McIntosh was told he was at the top of the list of seven applicants.
"The H.R. person said, 'We're ready for the next step,"' Mr. McIntosh said. The next step would be an offer, he assumed, since the firm had checked his references. But instead, the company called him to say they had chosen someone with more experience. In the interim, Mr. McIntosh had turned down a $14,000 freelance project for fear he couldn't juggle a new job and outside work simultaneously.
Overall, he has declined more than $50,000 in freelance work this year, after being told he was the top contender for various jobs. "I could go bankrupt looking for a job," he said.
"In a boom economy employers are reluctant to put up hoops," said Matt Ferguson, president of CareerBuilder.com. "But now they're saying there's eight things an employee has to do to be considered."
Such demands forced Mr. McIntosh to look beyond the city, but with even more alarming results. This summer, he was told before flying to a national retailer's Minneapolis headquarters that, besides three days of interviews, he would take a psychology test. "I assumed it would be a half-hour commitment," he said. Instead, he spent four hours taking an SAT-style exam that included a personal essay, reading, math and a 400-question section that asked about his family structure and political leanings. Mr. McIntosh scored low; the company asked him to retake the test, but he declined. 
Part of the problem may be that employers fear the cost of bad hiring decisions, said Erik Rambusch, director of outplacement services at Partners in Human Resources International, a job placement firm in New York. Still, he said, some firms are taking advantage of the situation.
Mr. McIntosh can't decide if opening a full-time studio would be smarter than chasing an elusive job. The idea has some appeal -- and not just to him. "It pulls your friends and family down too," he said. "You tell them a job seems imminent and they get their expectations up. Then all of a sudden they're as disappointed as you are."

HEADLINE: Vote for Sewage Study Breaks Logjam 

BYLINE:  By ALICE KENNY

 BODY:
AFTER years of wrangling, county legislators last week broke through the logjam that had blocked efforts to keep untreated human waste out of reservoirs supplying drinking water to nearly one million New York City and Westchester residents. 
 The breakthrough came on a relatively mundane vote, to commission a study of ways to protect the watershed. 
 Aging wastewater treatment plants and septic fields in Yorktown and New Castle spew nearly two million gallons of treated and sometimes untreated human waste into the watershed daily. Still more dirty water leaches in from compromised septic fields and cesspools in Bedford Hills and Katonah. 
The county began debating how to clean the reservoirs in 1997 after cutting a deal with New York City, promising to protect the watershed in return for $38 million from the New York City (now, with interest, grown to $51 million) to cover expenses.
At the urgingof the 12 Westchester communities lying within the watershed, the county initially considered diverting waste water out of the watershed and into underground pipes going to county treatment plants in Peekskill and Yonkers, which discharge into the Hudson River. 
In October 2002, County Executive Andrew J. Spano endorsed the proposal and sent it to the County Board of Legislators, requesting its approval to use $1.4 million of New York City funds to assess the plan's environmental impact. Before scheduling the vote, legislators held a series of local informational meetings.
But Peekskill and Yonkers residents packed the meetings, accusing the county of environmental racism for planning to send foul-smelling waste water into cities with high populations of low-income or minority residents. 
Responding to this opposition, legislators instead agreed this week to commission the study, a $500,000 analysis that would evaluate alternative methods to protect the watershed. They also created a citizens advisory committee of residents from affected areas who, along with the legislators, will oversee the study. 
Under the committee's direction, the analysis will compare the diversion plan with the possibility of instead adding state-of-the-art measures to upgrade existing Yorktown and New Castle wastewater treatment plants and septic systems. It will evaluate the alternatives' environmental and engineering effectiveness and consider their impacts on the economy, public health and quality of life.
"After near-certainty that diversion would go through -- it was the only way studied for six years -- they're now obliged to look at alternatives," said Marion Rose as she celebrated the legislators' vote with fellow environmentalists who said they worried that diversion would remove limits on development in the watershed, causing increased runoff and further damage to the reservoir. 
Ms. Rose heads the Croton Watershed Clean Water Coalition, a watchdog environmental organization formed to ensure the purity of New York City's reservoirs.
The vote also marked the first time residents of potentially affected communities agreed to abandon turf battles and work together to find a regional solution. 
"The initial process was not inclusive," said Andrea Stewart-Cousins, a Democratic legislator representing Yonkers. "Now we're beginning with all the impacted parties at the table talking about all the issues at hand. It doesn't mean we'll all be singing 'Kumbaya,' but I certainly support this and look forward to the study's conclusions."
John Raymond, the Westchester County chairman of Inter-Local Organizing Committees, a community group that grew out of the Million Man March on Washington, said he hopes to serve on the advisory committee. "The original move toward diversion would have been a serious injustice toward the minority community," he said. "With the upcoming discussion we can correct those injustices."
While the original debate was a geographic one, the vote divided instead along party lines, with 10 Democrats voting for the alternative analysis and 5 Republicans voting against it. Two legislators were absent.
"How can I not support something that looks as benign and gentle as a comparative analysis?" asked George Oros, a Republican legislator who represents Cortlandt and Peekskill. "Because it considers diversion, something a majority of the legislators do not want."
While leaving open the possibility of diverting Yorktown's waste to Peekskill, the comparative analysis also introduced the option of diverting New Castle's waste to the state-operated sewage treatment plants at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility. 
Because this diversion would use up the plant's excess capacity, it would undercut efforts of Ursula G. LaMotte, a Republican legislator who spent the last year and a half negotiating with the state to lay sewer lines that would link the treatment plant to homes and businesses in her district that have failing septic systems.
Ms. Cousins and Legislator Michael B. Kaplowitz of Yorktown, both Democrats, drafted the compromise legislation approved this week. According to the timeline, an engineering company will be chosen in the next four months to conduct the study.When the study -- slated to take six months -- is completed, it will be presented to the legislators for another vote. If New York City approves the legislators' plans to protect the reservoirs; it will release funds to pay for the work.
"Although we continue to believe that the proposed diversion project is the best option for dealing with certain water quality problems in Yorktown and New Castle," Mark Hoffer , New York City Department of Environmental Protection general counsel, wrote to Mr. Kaplowitz, "we are willing to support a feasibility study."
"Naturally, we would hope that the feasibility study will yield recommendations that the City can support."
Meanwhile, the clock is ticking, and fines are beginning to mount in Westchester. Last year, Yorktown entered into consent orders with Riverkeeper, the Garrison-based environmental organization, and with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, agreeing to install new equipment in its antiquated wastewater treatment plant to prevent storm water from seeping into aging pipes and to keep ammonia from flowing into the reservoir. So far, according to Yorktown engineer Sharon Robinson, the town has spent more than $100,000 upgrading the plant, but hoped to learn whether the plant would be closed and its sewage diverted before undertaking the remainder of the work, estimated to cost over $4 million and scheduled to begin by next September.

HEADLINE: An Especially Taxing Burden 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN

 BODY:
IT is a matter of near-universal agreement in Westchester that property taxes are too high. But what is not obvious is whether the burden is being shared equally. 
 Consider this: The property tax bill on John D'Agnillo's three-bedroom Yonkers home is about $3,000, before a state tax break for older residents, Mr. D'Agnillo said. But his backyard neighbors, Julie and Michael F. Meyer, said they pay $9,500 in taxes for their three-bedroom house, which has a slightly larger lot. 
 The new owners of a six-bedroom Victorian house in Bronxville that they just bought for $3.25 million have a total tax bill of $30,000 in 2003, while the owners of a nearby five-bedroom split-level that sold recently for $1.95 million have a tax bill of $43,000 village officials said. 
Two homes on a single block in Chappaqua sold recently for about $3 million each. One, a four-bedroom house on four acres, with a pool and a pond, is taxed at $71,000. The other, a six-bedroom house on four acres, with a pool and tennis court, is taxed at $56,000 officials there said. 
Other examples abound. Inequities like these in Westchester County's residential property taxes are an integral part of the confusing, complex, and sometimes seemingly arbitrary tax system, one that levies the highest average property tax per household in the state of New York. 
Experts agree that the system is antiquated, inefficient, and, ultimately, deceptive. Yet it is unlikely to change any time soon, in part because there do not appear to be any political incentives to change it. Homeowners whine at length about their tax bills, and anti-tax groups mount occasional local protests, but Westchester residents have yet to unite in a midnight march on White Plains or Albany, or village offices, with pitchforks and torches.
"Westchester's ugly little secret is that its assessment practices are so antiquated and erratic, it's a real scandal," said Gilbert Mercurio, chief executive of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. "It's just an outrage that our tax system is so bush league compared to almost anywhere else." 
The only Westchester town to have updated its tax assessment system is Pelham, which now has annual revaluations; in addition, the Town of Rye is in the process of conducting a town-wide reassessment. Every other Westchester municipality, however, is taxing homeowners based on assessments that are, on average, 38 years old, and thus reflect and preserve quirky and even inequitable judgments. That excludes Mount Vernon, with an assessment roll that is literally an antique, dating all the way back to 1853, according to Anthony DeBellis, the commissioner of assessment.
Property tax bills are, of course, the result of many factors. Governments and school boards need money to pay for social services like Medicaid and education. Tax revenues from homeowners, industry and commercial enterprises are the primary source of that money. In places with more commercial and industrial enterprise -- say White Plains, with its bustling commerce, or Armonk, with I.B.M.'s headquarters -- residential property taxes tend to be lower. In places where there is little industry or commerce, like Pelham, residential taxes tend to be higher. Also, taxes seldom seem to go down; they only go up. 
These things seem never to change. But what most experts agree upon is that the assessments of housing values, the judgment of a house's worth, upon which taxes are levied, should change. They should be examined periodically and adjusted they are inequitable, so that owners of similar houses get similar tax bills, meaning that recipients of services share the burden equally. Assessed value is, theoretically, an estimate of how much a home would sell for, and in markets like Westchester's, that number can vary dramatically from year to year. "The longer you go without a reassessment, the more inequities in the system," said Frank Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, in Latham, N.Y., a nonprofit research organization that focuses on tax and public policy issues.
David Gaskell, a retired executive director of the Office of Real Property Services in Albany, which promotes and supports fairness in local taxes, added: "There's no question that the quality of assessing in Westchester, if not the worst, is close to worstin the state."
Tax experts say that property taxes in Westchester County are unfair on two levels. First, owners of similar houses in the same neighborhood, like the examples in Yonkers, Bronxville and Chappaqua, sometimes pay dramatically different taxes. Second. there is also a surprising inequity in the tax burden between the poorer cities and the wealthier municipalities in Westchester County. 
On the first point, it is often true that neighbors know of and discuss each others' tax issues. A loyal, born-and-bred Yonkers resident, 65-year-old Mr. D'Agnillo has made it his hobby to challenge his property assessment, which he has done twice in the last seven years. As a result, he got his assessment reduced by more than 20 percent. 
The Meyers, Mr. D'Agnillo's neighbors, have challenged their property assessment twice, but failed both times. When Mr. Meyer asked for an explanation from the Yonkers assessor's office, he said he was told that because he and his wife had made improvements, they did not qualify for a reduction, said Mrs. Meyer. She said all they had done was to paint the interior and refinish the hardwood floors.
In Bronxville, too, divergent assessments result in radically disparate tax bills.
Among the 15 houses sold by brokers this year that were built after 1945, the average tax assessment was about $50,000, with an average sale price of $1.5 million. But among the 9 houses sold by brokers this year that were built before 1910, the average tax assessment was much less, $43,000, despite a higher average sale price, $2 million, according to an analysis by Carolyn Martin, an associate broker with Bronxville-Ley Real Estate. 
It is common, she said, for newer homes and those that have been recently renovated to be assessed at higher amounts than older, unrenovated homes, and therefore to owe much more in taxes. It was this kind of inequity that fueled a thriving business of challenging property tax assessments in Westchester in the 1990's. Since 1990, for instance, The Home Team, in Pleasantville, has taken on 15,000 tax challenges, including Mr. D'Agnillo's, winning about 95 percent of those cases, according to the owner, Michael H McBride. 
"In the 1990's, we corrected a lot of high assessments," he said, "but because of the hyper-inflation that has hit the housing market, many houses in Westchester County are now under assessed." 
On the second point, inequity in tax burdens between richer and poorer cities, comparisons are difficult to make, because housing prices and tax rates differ so dramatically. 
One way to compare tax rates, however, is to compare tax bills by using the median sale price of a Westchester home, several experts agreed. 
That price, according to the Westchester Board of Realtors, was $570,000 during the second quarter of this year. Approximate tax bills for a $570,000 home in various municipalities varied widely -- based on figures published online by the Office of Real Property Services of New York State for 2002 at www.orps.state.ny.us. 
A resident of a house worth $570,000 in the low-income city of Mount. Vernon would pay about $14,000 in city and county taxes; in wealthy Bedford, though, the village, school and county tax bill on a home worth that amount would be about $9,000. 
"Richer communities tend to be taxed at lower rates," explained Jerald Benjamin, a dean at the State University of New York in New Paltz and a political scientist who specializes in real property tax issues. "In poorer towns, the base is smaller, so residents are taxed at higher rates," he added.
Mr. Benjamin was appointed to the Real Property Tax Administration System Alliance, a state-supported research group that has been asked to improve New York State's current tax structure, which the organization declared is in dire need of "greater equity and efficiency." 
The property tax problem is partly a result of the lack of oversight by the sate, which does not dictate a uniform percentage of assessed value for all municipalities, like 100 percent or 50 percent, or mandate reassessment every two or three years, as many other states do, Mr. Gaskell said. 
"The state of New York abdicated its responsibility and left each city and town on its own," Mr. Gaskell said. 
As a result, communities like Mount Vernon can choose not to update an 1853 tax roll. The only governing body that can institute a revaluation is Mount Vernon's City Council, said Mr. DeBellis, the Mount Vernon assessor, and the topic has never come up in his 26-year tenure. "Where am I going to find $1.2 million," Mr. DeBellis asked, "and why spend over a million dollars to do something that might hurt a lot of people?"
Westchester County has an extremely inefficient, decentralized system in which at least 25 assessing units impose literally hundreds of different residential property tax rates, a system so convoluted that neither the Westchester County Tax Commissioner nor the state comptroller's office can say for sure how many exist.
The number of jurisdictions in Westchester, and the lack of centralization, leads to inefficiency and expense, experts said. "The more numerous the governmental units, the less efficient and the more expensive the tax system," Mr. Brunori explained. 
Finally, the system is so complex, as well as mysterious, that it becomes almost deliberately deceptive - if you don't understand it, you can't criticize or change it.
In most municipalities in Westchester, a house's assessment is not its full value, but rather a state-mandated fraction of its true value. The only exception is Pelham, with full-value assessments. Thus, a house in Pelham with an assessed value of $570,000 is expected to sell for somewhere around that much. But a $570,000 house in Scarsdale will have an assessed value of about $12,400, because the percent of valuation used there in 2003 was 2.18 percent. 
This fraction is regulated by state law, so that all properties within the city, town or village are assessed at the same percentage of their full value, which must be stated on the property tax bill. These fractions are tied to the date of the last revaluation, so the more recently reassessed municipalities tend to use larger percentages. Homeowners tend to be confused when they see their home assessed at, say $15,000, when they know they can sell it for much, much more.
"Fractional assessment amounts are a way to obscure assessment biases, which are effectively concealed by this method," said Debra Chini Sullivan, a tax lawyer in Syracuse who is a member of the alliance.
The organization's official position is that if a house is worth $570,000, that should be its assessed value -- a method that makes taxes "more transparent, simpler to administer, and easier to explain and justify," according to one of the alliance's principles.
By this measure, then, the fairest taxing locale in Westchester County is Pelham, the only municipality that uses full-value assessments and has annual revaluations. As property values rise, so does nearly every assessment in Pelham, said Michele Casandra, Pelham's assessor. Still, residential property taxes in Pelham tend to be among the highest in the county, in part because the town of 12,000 supports its own school district, and also because the commercial and industrial tax base is so small. 
In addition, realtors and tax officials say, housing prices are slightly lower in Pelham than they are elsewhere in Westchester. Buyers get more house for $570,000 in Pelham than they would in Scarsdale, or other comparable villages, Ms. Casandra said, because the taxes are higher.
Fairness issues do not keep Pelham residents from complaining about their taxes. Property tax assessments are delivered every June in a notice that informs residents that they are free to challenge those taxes based on a procedure that involves seeking the assessments on comparable homes and posting a formal grievance, as mandated by New York State Law. Before revaluation, Pelham residents filed more than 300 grievances a year, but last year there were 189, said Ms. Casandra.
 So far, the only town to follow in Pelham's path is the Town of Rye, which is completing a revaluation, at a cost of nearly $1 million, to assess all 11,000 properties there. The process, initiated by the town supervisor, Robert Morabito, began the day he was first elected, in 1994, he said. 
Having run for re-election in 1999 on a revaluation platform, Mr. Morabito said he is determined that his town's assessments will be fair and equitable, regardless of the political cost. Indeed, he won re-election by a narrow margin earlier this month against a candidate who campaigned vigorously against the reassessment plan.
"We are the only municipality that had the intestinal fortitude to complete the process that we feel will benefit everyone," he said.
The issue is a hard one, agreed Linda G. Cooper, town supervisor of Yorktown, who also won re-election by a small margin against an opponent who took her to task for supporting a county-wide revaluation several years ago. Reassessment "is an easily distorted issue that incites people's fears, and nobody wants to take the political heat," she said.
"If we do a revaluation, the fact that we have high property taxes won't go away," she added. "It will just make the tax rolls more equitable."

How One Town Is Reassessing Property
One way to address inequities in tax assessments is what is being done in the Town of Rye. Town officials hired MJW Consulting Inc. of Flushing to reassess all residential and commercial properties in the almost seven square miles of Rye Brook, Rye Neck and Port Chester, which have a total assessed value of about $6 billion. 
"Our goal is to make sure every single property is treated by the same equitable standard," said the company's president, John M. Watch, who hired 14 employees to complete the nearly three-year-long process of evaluating the 9,900 residential and 1,100 commercial properties. 
It is Mr. Watch's belief that assessors should not have to enter any homes, so as not to bias the process against residents who allowed entry, who were most likely not to have made illegal additions or renovations. Thus, Rye's revaluation was done through extensively detailed exterior observations. The company took aerial photographs of the entire town, from 600 feet and 1,500 feet, in such detail that "you can see the type of car in the driveway," Mr. Watch said. The process produced 1,600 slide images, which Mr. Watch used to corroborate square-footage estimates, for instance, and the number of roof vents, which indicate the number of bathrooms in a house.
Two-person teams also photographed each property from street level at least three times, and answered30 detailed questions about every home. These included, for instance, the type of view from the house, the number of trees on the property, the roofing and siding material, even the number of fireplaces.
About 600 properties in Rye had unreported basement apartments, based on the number of doorbells and mailboxes visible from the street, according to Mr. Watch. In addition, nearly 1,000 properties had undergone significant renovations and additions that were never reported , he said, observations that were confirmed by aerial photographs. By the end of this month, homeowners in Rye will have received a mailing containing detailed information about their home and property, to be followed by a notice that will state the new assessment and the revised tax bill. 
"That's when we get out our flak jackets and our helmets and our earmuffs," Mr. Watch said. 
He expects 25 percent of property owners will see their taxes increase by more than 10 percent; the rest will either go down or remain within 5 percent of the former amount.
By law, homeowners may contest their assessments, and Mr. Watch's company has prepared to handle 4,000 people challenges, he said. If a resident refuses to accept the assessor's information, saying that there is no finished basement, for example, "they have to let us in to verify it, or a change will not be made," Mr. Watch said. Carin Rubenstein

HEADLINE: Energy Bill Could Upend Lawsuits Over Gasoline Additive 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
The Authors of sweeping energy legislation made public on Saturday said they believed they had assembled a balanced measure that would win Congressional approval, even as the proposal faced new criticism over its benefits to oil companies.
 In a decision that surprised advocacy groups following the measure, a provision protecting producers of a gasoline additive blamed for groundwater contamination was made retroactive to Sept. 5, potentially disrupting a number of actions to recoup cleanup costs that have been filed since then in New York, California, New Hampshire and elsewhere. 
 Robert Gordon, a Manhattan lawyer who has filed some of the cases involving the additive, MTBE, said the bill neutralized the kind of product-defect claim that has been the most successful argument used against the producers. He said he and others were stunned by the Sept. 5 date, saying it would throw into question lawsuits he has filed since then on behalf of 100 local governments and water companies seeking cleanup money.
"It hurts us tremendously and really threatens the ability of any town and village to clean up the mess," Mr. Gordon said. 
The provisions for MTBE, or methyl tertiary butyl ether, were promoted by Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader, and Republican Representatives Billy Tauzin of Louisiana and Joe L. Barton ofTexas. Both states are home to MTBE producers. The MTBE deal was tied to a plan to replace that substance as an additive to make cleaner burning gasoline with corn-based ethanol, which would see its use rise to 5 billion gallons annually by 2012. That ethanol initiative was a top priority of Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, and Midwestern lawmakers of each party.
The MTBE producers argued that they should be protected from liability lawsuits because the federal government promoted the additive as a fuel oxygenate to ease air pollution. Mr. Tauzin said the immunity was carefully tailored so that it did not extend to negligence claims. "Trial lawyers were trying to get into deep pockets," said Mr. Tauzin about the product liability cases.
That MTBE provision is among elements of the first major energy legislation in a decade that are likely to draw opposition this week as the Republican leadership attempts to enact one of President Bush's signature domestic priorities before adjourning.
While they concede that the protection for the additive will anger some lawmakers, backers of the Republican-drafted measure say they believe they have eliminated most of the major policy fights that would threaten the bill.
"We do not think that we have in here the kind of touchstone, litmus-test issues" that would endanger passage, a senior Congressional aide told reporters on Saturday.
The energy proposal also would create an organization to establish and enforce reliability on the power grid. Tax incentives would be provided to spur construction of coal and nuclear power plants. Loan guarantees of $18 billion would be available to build a natural gas pipeline from Alaska to Chicago. Small oil drillers would get tax breaks for pumping oil from marginally producing wells. And, corn growers would find a new market under the ethanol initiative.
The authors say the total direct cost, including tax breaks, would exceed $20 billion over 10 years. The measure also calls for spending tens of billions of dollars on an array of energy projects and programs, though that money would have to be approved in future spending bills. Congressional aides would not quantify the amount, but interest groups say it is at least $58 billion and potentially much more.
To the distress of critics, who see the bill as a collection of special interest provisions and pet projects, it would also allow selected cities to temporarily escape some requirements to reduce air pollution.
The measure has been almost three years in the making but gained new momentum with last summer's blackout. Its text was posted on a Senate Web site at noon on Saturday. That was an effort to comply with a promise by Republicans to give Democrats, who were shut out of House-Senate negotiations over the measure, at least 48 hours to review the plan before a conference committee meeting scheduled for Monday afternoon. It could be on the floor of the House as early as Tuesday.
Immediately after it was posted, industry and environmental organizations around Washington began scrolling through the legislation to determine how it affected their area of interest. Industry representatives, while saying the measure was not perfect, called it a needed step forward that could stimulate investment in the energy sector of the economy.
"There is no doubt that moving electricity policy from an uncertain legislative status to the regulatory arena is a positive development from a financial standpoint," said Lynne H. Church, president of the Electric Power Supply Association.
John B. Walker, chairman of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, said, "The proponents of this agreement should be applauded for recognizing this strategic industry and the needs of the nation."
But conservation and spending watchdog groups were aghast, saying the proposal was even worse than they anticipated with its generous benefits for the energy industry, relaxation of some environmental laws and larger than expected spending on special interest projects.
"The big winner is big oil. The big loser is anyone who breathes, pays a utility bill or drinks water," said Anna Aurilio, legislative director for the United States Public Interest Research Group, which has been fighting new energy legislation since a task force headed by Vice President Dick Cheney issued the Bush administration's energy policy in 2001.
Though the legislation was in the works before the blackout, the bill seeks to reduce the risks of power failures but puts off until at least 2007 a more sweeping electric industry restructuring proposed by federal regulators. It would lead to the creation of new reliability standards, allow voluntary membership in regional transmission organizations and let the federal government set power line routes if state and local governments fail to agree after a year.
"This is going to help a lot," Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said Saturday. "A lot of the hesitancy that has existed on investment has been based on a fear that people would start down the road of building new transmission lines and not be able to get them permitted."
In protecting manufacturers of MTBE, the bill also grants them a possible $2 billion in transition aid to switch from MTBE, an increase over the $800 million they were expected to get. The substance could remain in use until 2015, when it would be banned unless the president intervened.
Democratic Congressional aides were reviewing the measure Saturday, and the prospects for quick approval of the bill perhaps rested on the position Mr. Daschle and others would take. The authors of the measure included a host of projects to try and round up the largest number of votes they could.
For instance, one of the last additions to the bill was a $1 billion program to share more offshore oil and gas revenue with Louisiana and a handful of other coastal states for erosion prevention. The measure also includes language sought by Mr. Daschle and Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, to make it more difficult for states to seek exemptions from the new ethanol requirements.
The bill seeks to encourage new nuclear power plant development, a longtime priority of Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico and the lead Senate energy negotiator, by providing a production tax credit for the first 6,000 megawatts of new nuclear power to come online, a level aides said could subsidize three or more plants. The measure also extends the law protecting nuclear operators from liability.
